story:
My Story

Hi my name is Olivia; I am 15 years old and have been blessed with the opportunity to dance since I was 7. Even before I started dancing I imagined myself being a ballerina one day. I would walk around the house on my toes, watch ballet movies, and make up choreography to music in my living room. I think I wore out my VCR tape of “I wish I were a ballerina.” Many things satisfy me in life but nothing quite like ballet. I dance because it makes me happy and fulfills me like nothing else can. The way I feel when I dance it is my definition of what true love is and where I feel closest to God. When I think of a day where I am not able to dance anymore it breaks my heart. I can envision myself as a very old woman still dancing in my pointe shoes. It may be only in my dreams but I will be dancing.

My Biggest Supporter

My mom and dad got divorced when I was about 7. My mom thought that my sister and I needed something to focus on, so she put my sister in ice skating and I chose what I always dreamed of…ballet. I strongly believe that along with my faith, ballet saved me. It was the brightest of lights at the end of my darkest tunnel. It gave me something to look forward to everyday and showed me a love so rare I can’t imagine it missing from my heart. I would have never started dancing if my mom hadn’t encouraged me to take my first class, and I would definitely not be dancing right now if it weren’t for her constant love, support, and encouragement. I will never be able to repay her for that. However, being a single mom with one income, the cost of my monthly dance classes, pointe shoes, tights, leotards, etc. things have been very far from easy to pay for. To be quite honest it has put a financial strain on my family. My mom has given up so much for me to be able to live out my passion. Being able to dance is a privilege and both my mom and I put in an equal amount of effort to make it work. Although I do the actual work in class, she gets me to dance classes, carpools my friends, pays for everything with the help of my grandma, stays late and waits for me when we are in the theater, the list goes on and on. Not to mention the fact the she works a full time job and 2 side jobs. She also gives her time as the volunteer coordinator for our productions at my dance studio. She does this because I am already away from home so much; if she is with me at the studio it will give us more time together. Both of our lives are completely consumed by my dancing.


Senior Summer Intensive 2014 Texas

To dance professionally is my dream.  And to reach this goal I have to look for opportunities outside of my normal training to receive other instructor’s wisdom, teachings, and corrections. As I grow as a dancer the opportunities grow as well. This winter I applied to many summer dance intensive programs throughout the country and although I received other offers I was blessed to be accepted into one of my top choices. This Summer Intensive program offers a 6-week session of study for serious students who are seeking a professional dance career, like myself. This Intensive will give me a deeper understanding of ballet technique, focusing on pointe, variations, partnering and repertoire. I am excited to have opportunity to take classes with well-established modern, jazz and theatre dance teachers. Although this is a financial hardship, it is a step I feel necessary to take in order to become the dancer I am striving to be. My eyes are wide open to the fact that the ballet world is very difficult and extremely competitive. It is never easy and will never be easy. There is literally blood, sweat, and tears as well as daily aches and pains that get put into what I do. But every blister, ache, and pain is worth the fullness of my heart. It is the life that I have chosen and the only life I can imagine myself living. Without dance life would feel pointeless!

Olivia's feet en pointe 2012


The Need

100% of the money will go to Olivia’s summer intensive training.

There are many costs that are part of going to a summer program; training, housing, airfare, and pointe shoes are some of the main costs that total approximately $6800.00. The registration fee and airfare have been paid for totaling $2000.00.

Tuition $ 5915

Airfare $ 450

Pointe Shoes, Dance attire and Dance supplies $ 435

The Benefit

The first time I went away for a summer intensive was last year. I auditioned with several companies and chose to go to a Ballet Company in San Diego. Although I had done many intensives at my studio this would be my first away from home. I chose San Diego because my Aunt and Uncle live about an hour away and we could minimize housing cost by me staying with them. I felt it was a great first time away from the familiar and away from the help my mom offers me. I learned so much about myself during that summer and I grew immensely as a dancer. It took me out of my comfort zone and opened me up to new ideas. The teachers at my studio are wonderful but it is so beneficial to seek out training from others who have had different experiences and can offer their wisdom. I can’t wait to see the growth that this new opportunity will offer me.

Olivia at San Diego Summer Intensive with her teacher Maria Kowroski, principle dancer with New York City Ballet

Other Ways You Can Help

Other ways that you can help Olivia recognize her dream of becoming a professional dancer is:

  • Share with EVERYONE you can think of--and Share OFTEN!!!  If you use the sharing tools at the top of the page, once a day, letting everyone know how much you support Olivia, that will really help!  Indiegogo uses it's "GoGo Factor" to determine who gets to be on the home page. This is how we will find others who may want to help outside of our circle.
  • Put the link on your Facebook page and ask your friends to share it!  
  • Put it on your friends' walls!  
  • Send a Tweet!
  • And remember anything helps from the smallest donation to the largest!

Thank you so much for your consideration! I am honored that you have taken the time to read my story. Take a look at my gallery to view more of my photos.

~Olivia

story:
Short Summary

Hello! Writer and Director Ollie Clark and Co-Director Rebecca Horgan wish to take their original comedy up to Edinburgh Fringe Festival! 

We are both students from Queen Mary University London, and are passionate that the production has a lot of potential to be put on in a venue better than our university campus, following it's success! 

The comedy is based around three characters stuck in a lift, all slowly revealing their quirky and flamboyant characteristics, which made the show a joy to create, let alone watch as a member of the audience. Although set in a claustrophobic setting, the show is far from being static. With salsa dancing, a bottle of vodka and an elusive member of the cast, the dialogue is witty and will have audience members rolling in the aisles, thanks to a fantastic cast. 

By helping us reach our goal of Edinburgh, will greatly influence collaborations in the future, and to keep theatre fresh and relevant to our culture. With all the horrific and awful stories in the world, theatre has an amazing ability to keep the worlds smiling; and that is (as writer and director) our aim when producing this play. 



What We Need & What You Get

Taking a show to Edinburgh has it's costs! We will need to raise enough money to help our actors to survive whilst up in Edinburgh in terms of accommodation, travel and general living expenses.  

In terms of unique perks, we are offering the amazing (ahem) opportunity to receive a doodle of a cat that is used on the set of Hold for Three Seconds with a personal message of thanks sent out to you! If you are a truly wonderful person and you wish to donate a certain amount, we will produce a video of thanks to you in various mad, but entertaining ways!

The Impact

We personally believe the project is valuable to the arts and keeping interest in theatre, despite the cut in arts funding. 

By generously donating, you will increase a wonderful young writer's confidence to write more and more and take his ideas from ink on a page to staging his production! 

As well as being an amazing experience, we believe it also shows other younger people that you are able to fund your own projects and take your own aspirations further! The pressures of gaining a place at drama schools is overwhelming and to many people, failure to gain a place can lead to an individual giving up their chance in the industry.

As a writer and director, we both wanted to spread a bit of cheer, and responses on twitter have been very encouraging and also proof that the show was a great success! 

Here are a few examples of some amazing responses!

"Flawless in both acting and writing alike #HOLDFOR3"

"Hilarious from start to finish with an amazingly funny and witty script, brilliantly delivered by a superb cast #HOLDFOR3"

#HOLDFOR3 is literally the funniest play I have seen for ages! Such a clever script and top-notch actors.

"#holdfor3 made me do a v. unattractive snort/laugh/honk more than once - unapologetically silly, a whole lot of fun and perfectly presented."

Other Ways You Can Help

If you could share this link on facebook or twitter or whatever you youngsters are into these days, that would be amazing! 

Also, if you have seen 'Hold for Three Seconds' you could tweet what you thought of the show by writing #HOLDFOR3! 


Thank you so much!

story:
Coming this fall...

RedLeaf Theatre Co. is launching this fall with a production of Charlie Biscotto's Raise Me Up, which grapples with faith, hope, and fidelity in catastrophic situations. We'll be following that this spring with Odyssey, which will explore Homer's The Odyssey through six short plays written by six playwrights.  We're seeking to ask big questions and instigate bigger dialogues about our world and the craft of storytelling, and we want you to be a part of it.

Raise Me Up, opening September 4th at Under St. Marks in downtown Manhattan, follows the Reverend John Marigold Jr. as he attempts to repair his marriage while sheltered inside his church in the aftermath of the zombie-apocalypse. It asks important questions about how we handle faith at times of utmost despair.

Odyssey will feature six pieces written by Amy E. Witting, Daniel John Kelley, Georgette Kelly, Taylor J. Williams, Charlie Biscotto, and David M. deLeon, each taking up a separate episode of Homer's The Odyssey and examining storytelling, memory, and the idea of the classical hero.

What We Get/What You Get

We've received a grant through the Anne Freedman Student Theatre Production Fund, a program of the Department of Theatre at Hunter College, to cover some costs of Raise Me Up. This grant has helped us to secure a space and begin planning for the production, but there's a lot more that we need.

We want to pay all of our artists, because we think they deserve it. The payment will cover transportation costs for the duration of rehearsals and performances. We have a lot of artists working on these two shows, and we want to hold ourselves to the ideal that no work should be free work. By supporting this show, you're helping young, developing artists to be compensated for what they do.

The other costs are the costs of every show: rehearsal space, production space, sets, costumes, makeup, props. Our focus will always be on the story and the artists telling that story, so we're taking every step possible to minimize these costs in a way that does the stories and the artists justice.

No matter how small or large the donation is, we'll thank you in our programs for both of these shows. Beyond that, we're offering perks ranging from signed posters to access to invitation-only preview performances.

The Bigger Picture

RedLeaf Theatre's mission is to create theatre that starts a conversation. By helping us to bring these shows to life, you're helping also to bring that conversation to life. We believe that too many aspects of our life and our culture go unexamined, and that by bringing people together into the community of the theatre, we can open up a dialogue that changes that.

If Money's Not Your Thing

Then that's okay. Shoot our Artistic Director an e-mail at charlie@redleaftheatre.com and ask for other ways to help. We can keep you in the loop on all of our projects, whether you're interested in seeing them or getting involved as an artist in our future works.

story:
The Story....

When Chloe’s mom goes into the hospital to have the baby brother Chloe does not want, the only thing that can make it better is an evening at Grandma’s. Tonight, Grandma has something special: a book that’s been hidden away in the attic gathering dust. Soon an epic adventure begins, involving a prince, a servant, three circus performers, a pirate, a fairy, a witch, and a dwarf.

Part action, part romance, part adventure, part comedy, The Kingdom Next to Fid spins a tale of devotion that soon has Grandma and Chloe burning through the chapters (and the cookies) to find out if undying love will triumph at the end. Sword fights, chases, war, betrayal, kidnapping, a magic inn, loyalty, heartache and friendship all mix with a little bit of sorcery and a lot of heart in this original fantasy. A whole new world awaits as the audience is transported from the Valley of the Wandering Willows to the Fen of Infinite Funk; from Raethein, to Graomar, to Draewen, to Fid; from the Cacophonous Pearl to the Forest of Chirping Crickets. Heck, there may even be a unicorn.

Supporting the main action are a dozen or so “background” players who go from soldier to knight to pirate to villager plus a “living set” manned by actors who not only fluidly change the scenery but literally make the magic happen. A unique experience for both the actors and audience.

The Kingdom Next to Fid will enchant adults while still being suitable for children 10 and up. Don’t miss the world premiere of this magical play by two of MuCCC’s own artists in residence, who clearly have too much time on their hands! It’s the greatest story you never heard of.

The Cast

The Playwrights 

The Kingdom Next to Fid came to life because we wanted to tell an epic fantasy/fairy tale that would be appropriate for children while genuinely engaging and entertaining adults (there is, after all, a kid in all of us). We chose the genre because it allowed us to hit action, comedy, and drama all in one, plus we got to come up with some ridiculous location names like the Fen of Infinite Funk and the Cacophonous Pearl.  It also allows for us to do some pretty exciting things to push the community theatre envelope. After killing ourselves trying to find an old, public domain story we could adapt and finding only bits and pieces of plot that we really liked, we finally went, "Um, let's just write something ourselves." So that's exactly what we did!
~Meredith & Karen

Both Meredith and Karen are Artist in Residence at MuCCC Theatre and accomplished performers in the Rochester Theatre Community.


We Need Your Help!

Our missions with this production:

  • Create affordable, quality theatre the entire family can truly enjoy
  • Donate 100% of the ticket sales to MuCCC Theatre so they can continue to provide a performance space for many theatre groups and performing artists
  • Push the boundaries of what is possible, technically and artistically, in community theatre

This is a pretty ambitious play. Our budget is $5000. We have a large cast and some pretty cool effects. We are borrowing what we can from other theatre groups in the area (costumes, some props, etc.) but given the uniqueness of this play, there is a lot we cannot borrow.

We did the research, crunched the numbers, cut where we could, looked for the lowest princes possible and here is the breakdown:

Set build & Pieces:      $ 1,500
Costumes:                     $ 2,300
Props/ FX:                    $1,000
Promotions:                  $200

No gift is too small - every little bit helps! In addition, your donations are tax-deductible through the sponsorship of this production by MuCCC Theatre.

I'm not able to donate, but want to help. What can I do?

If you’re not able to donate but want to support us, please spread the word about this campaign. Share the link on your Facebook Page, email your friends, Tweet away! 

Follow us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/kingdomnexttofid for updates on the show and entertaining tidbits, and share our page with friends who might be interested in seeing the show or the work that we do.


Show runs from Aug 1st  - 10th 2014!!

photo by Annette Dragon

story:
Hi!

My name is Daisy Jorgensen, and I have written a one act play, called Silent Wings.

The play is inspired by 'I Have Not Seen A Butterfly' around here - a published collection of artwork and poetry created by children living inside Terezin, a concentration camp set up by the SS during World War Two.

It all started as my final year dissertation submission whilst in training as an actor at The prestigious Guildford School of Acting. Then in 2013 I was kindly offered a platform to showcase a 20 minute excerpt of the piece by the 20:20 Vision Writing Festival. After seeing talented actors bring it to life, and generous audiences responding well, I went back to the script, and decided it had legs (maybe). After seeking advise from playwrights, theatre makers, and actors alike, running R&D sessions and workshops, then editing and improving the script, the opportunity came along to stage the full length play for a two night run at the wonderful Burdall's Yard venue, as part of the Bath Fringe Festival 2016.

This is SO exciting, however like most creative opportunities, this one comes hand in hand with certain costs. Although much of the work so far has been self-funded, in order to allow the play to reach it's full potential, I have decided to set up this campaign to enable me, and the wonderful team working alongside me to deliver a more high quality peice to Bath theatre goers! 

Any generous contributions will go directly back into the project, supporting the actors, director, musicians, technicians, and crew, all offering up their time to make my little vison a reality, alongside the creation of costumes, publicity, a set, and hopefully an enjoyable and reflective couple of evenings for our audience. 

Equally if you can't contribute at the moment, but could share this campaign online, buy a ticket to see the finished product, or just tell your friends to check us out - we would hugely appreciate your time & support!

A very humble thank you for reading, this is a story I really want to tell! 

Daisy & the Silent Wings team!

story:
Our Story 

Concord Floral, and Theatre 44 as a whole, is an initiative to promote camaraderie and collaboration between the current actors at the Ryerson School of Performance who, since our move from 44 Gerrard Street, have lost the essential building, and green room, that allowed for this more easily in the past. 

There wasn’t yet an open forum collaborative space available to all of the acting years: it never happens in the pedagogy of our program.

That's why we started this. 

Our cast consists of a diverse group of young actors from years 1, 2 and 3 of the Performance Acting program. We are eager, ambitious artists dying to get out there and tell stories. 

For many of us, Concord Floral will be our first time acting in a professional theatre show and first crack at producing and mounting indie theatre in Toronto. 

What We Need

The money raised from the campaign will go to renting our space, the rights to the show buying costumes, props, building our set, rights to music and marketing. All of this will go to bringing this story to life in its fullest potential! Producing theatre as young artists with minimal income is difficult. That's why we need you! 

Other Ways You Can Help 

Donating isn't the only way you can help us. Using IndieGogo share tools and spreading the word about us on social media is also incredibly valuable! 

 

We are eternally grateful for any way you can help bring this beautiful story to life. Thank you for being there for us.

story:
Our Mission

Founded in 2011, Artemisia, A Chicago Theatre produces plays that empower women, gives playwrights career-altering opportunities and brings groundbreaking new theatre to Chicago audiences, who are a vital part of Artemisia's play-selection process. 
  • Artemisia's Annual Fall Festival of Staged Readings features six new female-driven plays offered FREE to the public.
  • The audience chooses  Artemisia's next hit show to be produced as a world or American premiere in an upcoming season.
  • Core values are empowerment, diversity and inclusion. Reload this page to check out Artemisia's 2015-2016 Talent at the beginning of our video.

Our Most Recent Success

  • Belfast Girls by Jaki McCarrick was chosen out of six new plays by Artemisia's Fall Festival audience.
  • The play was produced in Spring 2015 to rave reviews by audiences and critics alike.
  • Samuel French published Belfast Girls in conjunction with the premiere.
  • Artemisia nurtures writers and Jaki McCarrick's new play, Bohemians, is one of the six new plays featured in the 2015 Fall Festival.


So what's going on in 2015-2016?

  1. Artemisia Fall Festival 2015
  2. The premiere of Chewing on Beckett by Ed Proudfoot
  3. We're moving to Edgewater! (Thank you, Jackalope and The Frontier!)
Read more about the six new Fall Festival plays at ArtemisiaTheatre.org


Why do we need your help?

Making theatre takes money. Lots of money.


This campaign will raise 20% of Artemisia's total Production Expenses for the 2015-2016 Season.

Where will the money go?

  • Every dollar raised will be used for production.
  • Twenty percent of the funding will help produce the Fall Festival.
  • Eighty percent of the funding will help produce Chewing on Beckett.

Where does the rest of the money come from?

Good question! Artemisia, A Chicago Theatre, has received generous grants, corporate sponsorships and support from:
  • The Gaylord and Dorothy Donnelley Foundation’s Gen Ops Plus Initiative
  • The Elizabeth Morse Charitable Trust
  • Illinois Arts Council Agency
  • The Saints, Volunteers for the Performing Arts
  • Mutual of America
  • Windy City Irish Radio
  • Artemisia's Amazing Individual Donors - see ArtemisiaTheatre.org for a full listing.
Individual donors and ticket buyers like you make Artemisia possible.

What We Need and What We Want to Give Back

Up there on the right is a list of Asks and the Perks that you will receive for your generous contribution to female-driven theatre. We won't go over them again here, but we will thank you again. And again. And again! No contribution is too small and all your shares on Facebook, Twitter and the like will help us go to the Edge.


What is the Edge?

The Edge is short for Edgewater which is about twenty minutes north of downtown Chicago. It's a vibrant, hip, sexy, creative community that many think is the next great neighborhood for some of the best theatre in the city. Artemisia is lucky to be in partnership with Jackalope, which received the 2015 Emerging Theatre Award. Not only that, Jackalope is so cool that they rent a second space called The Frontier, where Artemisia will be performing in 2015-2016 and Beyond!

We can't think of a better place to continue Artemisia's journey than at The Frontier and we hope to see you there! Thank you so much for your generous support of female-driven theatre and the dozens of artists and administrators that make it.


Hey, Wait, I Want to Help!

Awesome! Here's what you can do right this very moment.
  • Contribute for a Perk and Help Artemisia Go To the Edge!
  • Use the share buttons to help us get the word out.
  • Email a friend or two and talk us up.
  • Come see six new plays at the Fall Festival for free and cast your vote for Artemisia's next hit show!
  • Buy tickets for Chewing on Beckett.
Thanks for Helping Artemisia Go to the Edge!
Artemisia, A Chicago Theatre is a 501(c)3 Not-for-Profit organization. Your donation is tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
WHAT'S HAPPENING?

The Instigators are a troupe of dynamic actors who create stories that entertain and provoke audiences by embracing theater's potential as both an art and a sport. We are ambitiously moving forward by producing two plays in simultaneous rep at the Secret Theatre in LIC: Hedda Gabler by Ibsen and The Importance of Being Earnest by Wilde. Staged in the thrust, these shows immerse audiences into the theatrical world of each play. Our last production, Golden Boy by Clifford Odets, was described by Theater Pizzazz as "striking, no-nonsense portrayal of a classic work" by a "heavy-hitting company of talented young artists."**

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

  • Throw some $$$ our way!

​​The money we raise will go directly to renting The Secret Theatre, paying for rehearsal space, purchasing props and costumes, printing and distributing marketing materials, and compensating our designers, artists, and production team. Your financial support enables us to exist. All donations are deeply appreciated.

  • Spread the word!

We need butts in seats. Buy your tickets here: http://instigatorsnyc.brownpapertickets.com/ 

WHO'S WHO and WHAT'S WHAT?

Hedda Gabler

Written by: Henrik Ibsen

Adapted & Directed by: Fergus Scully

Starring: Isabel Cade, Mark Couchot, Alice Anne English, Taylor Petrack, Laird Reghenas, Dana Saffran, Jenna Sander

Hedda is an unhappy newlywed. Bored with her new station in life, she can't resist creating catastrophe when the means to do so present themselves. Her desire to control cannot be satisfied until she, herself, becomes the object. Written with an eerie silkiness, this play effortlessly builds to a horrific climax, with plenty of comedy, character development and plot twists along the way.

Show Times:

Thursday, Oct. 6 @ 7:30PM

Saturday, Oct. 8 @ 7:00PM

Sunday, Oct. 9 @ 7:00PM

Wednesday, Oct. 12 @ 7:30PM

Friday, Oct. 14 @ 7:30PM

Sunday, Oct. 16 @ 3:00PM

Tickets: http://instigatorsheddagabler.bpt.me

The Importance of Being Earnest

Written by: Oscar Wilde

Directed by: Christine Zagrobelny

Starring: Brian Dunlop, Kazuhiro Imafuku, Leslie Marseglia, Kaitlin McKendrick, Jessica Mosher, Fergus Scully, Sarah White, Blake Williams

Both Jack and Algy pretend their names are Ernest. Jack loves Gwendolyn. Algy loves Cecily. Both women love "Ernest." Miss Prism loves Rev. Chasuble—a celibate—and Lady Bracknell doesn't love anything much at all! Confusion ensues and tempers flare in this witty, scandalous farce.

Show Times:

Friday, Oct. 7 @ 7:30PM

Sunday, Oct. 9 @ 3:00PM

Tuesday, Oct. 11 @ 7:30PM

Thursday, Oct. 13 @ 7:30PM

Saturday, Oct. 15 @ 7:00PM

Sunday, Oct. 16 @ 7:00PM

Tickets: instigatorsbeingearnest.bpt.me

 

ANY MORE INFO?

Our website: http://www.instigatorsnyc.com/

The Secret's website: http://www.secrettheatre.com/

 

The Secret Theatre is located in Long Island City, Queens and is just one subway stop from Manhattan. Take the E, M, G or 7 train to Court Square / 23rd Street and walk a block to 44-02 23rd Street

**http://theaterpizzazz.com/rise-of-a-golden-boy/

story:
HELLO!!

My name is Alden Adair, I’m the producer and director behind Queen Henriette. As an actor’s life “ebb’s and flows like the moon” its important to have self-created work to keep in practice. Queen Henriette began as a need to create and work at a time when I wasn’t working in my artistic field. Over the past two years, this show has changed its form as I searched for what this story could say about today’s social climate.

Queen Henriette explores gender and the social expectations of women and men within the framework of an adapted King Henry IV pt. I by William Shakespeare. Language is mutable: words and language used in different situations have different meanings and weight. Shakespeare is a master at using language to play with meaning. So what would happen when women stepped into these roles originally designed for men? How does the existing language inform their experience? What text remains the same, and what needs to change to suit our adaption? How does a person’s social image affect their actions? How are they treated differently if they fall within or outside of the social norms? These are some themes we are eager to explore in this great play.

 

NEEDS

Funds raised will be going to three areas. Space. Bells. Desk.

Space is what we need to move and breath. We need a place to rehearse, to speak, to fight, to get it wrong, and then get it right. Then we need a space to present. A space where the artists and community come together to share the experience of this event.

-Rehearsal space

-Performance space

 

Bells is everything that makes our senses jingle jangle, from our eyes to our ears. This includes costume pieces, and music. Production value is what some call it, I prefer bells. 

-Costumes

-Sound and Music Design

 

Desk is about the paper work. While this is an artistic venture, we need to do a lot of administrative work to get the production running. We need to protect our artists, ourselves and our renting partners. We need the up front cash to promote our show, otherwise you’re the only one who’s gonna hear about it ;) We also need lots of paper and ink as we make our cuts and edits.

-Administration 

-Insurance Costs

-Publicity, Posters, Bills

-Script Printing

 

IMPACT

Actors need to act. That’s how they grow. Putting an artist onstage makes them stronger, and the stronger they are, the greater the collective artistic wealth becomes. Actors need to act. So women need to play more roles that are more diverse, and different from what they commonly have access to. This show will give some fantastic women the opportunity to explore “an undiscovered country” of character that they have yet to have chance to explore. Actors need to act. For artists from outside of Ontario, the move to Toronto can be a hard challenge, and the opportunity to perform onstage in Toronto can be scarce. We have a predominantly Saskatchewan cast and production team, and this show will give some of these artists their first time to perform onstage in this great city.

But more than the artists, having a space where people can experience and SEE women in places of power and influence adds to the movement of equality within our City and our Country. 

 

SHARE

The most important aspect of all is to get the word out! So if you like what you’ve seen, please share our FB and Twitter pages with your friends and colleagues. Use the IndieGogo sharing tools for your ease, and to help direct everyone to our IndieGogo page!


The Elucidate Project presents
Queen Henriette


A play by William Shakespeare
Directed by Alden Adair

Dec. 8-11
8pm Thurs, Fri, Sat - 2pm Sat, Sun
Tarragon Theatre Extraspace
$25, $15 Arts Worker/Student
@ElucidatePlay

story:
Short Summary

The Arkadina Project is one of the few shows that have been selected for the 2016 International Fringe Theatre Festival. FringeNYC, the largest multi-arts festival in North America, will present the 20th Annual Festival from August 16 – 27, 2016. 

TAP is a comedy so dark you'll feel guilty for laughing so hard. With high-tech elements such as live go-pro performances, actors lit entirely by cell phones, and a set dressed with projections the audience is sure to forget this was once considered a classic.This hilarious, high-tech modernization of Anton Chekhov’s “The Seagull”  follows Kostya, Nina and Masha on their struggles with celebrity obsession, unrequited love and parental suffocation.  Sex Scandals, Sell Outs, and Smirnoff. But no Seagull. 


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise at least $3500 for this project. All the proceeds that have been so generously donated to us will go into making this show truly spectacular (i.e. sets, electronic equipment, salaries, etc.)! Every year, the NYC Fringe festival receives thousands of plays, and we are fortunate enough to be one of the proud few who have made it in. THIS IS A BIG DEAL!!!

In addition to getting a warm fuzzy feeling after you realize you've contributed, for a donation of $25 or more, your generous contribution would be highlighted by:

· Featured recognition in playbills

· Premium reserved tickets and seating

· Arkadina Project Memorabilia

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, that's totally fine! We also need help with props, electronics and volunteers! Another way to support is to simply follow us on all the social media and share our journey with family and friends. The greatest marketing tool we have is you guys! And, of course, be sure to check out the show at The New York City International Fringe Festival August 16-27. We look forward to seeing you!


Facebook: The Arkadina Project

Instagram: @taproject_

· Arkadina Project Memorabilia

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate money, that's totally fine! We also need help with props, electronics and volunteers! Another way to support is to simply follow us on all the social media and share our journey with family and friends. The greatest marketing tool we have is you guys! And, of course, be sure to check out the show at The New York City International Fringe Festival August 16-27. We look forward to seeing you!
Facebook: The Arkadina ProjectInstagram: @taproject_

story:
Dearest Indie-goer, 

GIRLS WILL BE GIRLS is having her world premiere at The New York International Fringe Festival this August & we need your help to get us there!

Turns out, high school boys aren't the only ones trying to get laid. Filthy, funny, and relentlessly honest, this provocative new play follows four New York teens as they stumble towards the brink of womanhood. This is unapologetic girlhood, a peek inside the girl’s club that outsiders didn’t even know existed. GIRLS WILL BE GIRLS is a snapshot of the moment in which they must first confront their sexuality, autonomy, and all that it means to grow up girl in the digital age.

This campaign 

We are seeking the funding needed to produce GIRLS WILL BE GIRLS at the 20th Annual New York International Fringe Festival, August 12-28 2016. Producing a full length play is expensive! We need sets, props, rehearsal space, playbills, a lighting designer, sound designer, set designer, costume designer and of course, actors and crew. Compensating artists is important to us. This production will employ 4 lead actresses, a supporting actor, and at least 7 members of crew.

What is FringeNYC?

The New York International Fringe Festival, or FringeNYC, is a fringe theater festival and one of the largest multi-arts events in North America. It takes place over the course of two weeks every August, spread on more than 20 stages across several neighborhoods in downtown Manhattan. Attendance in 2009 topped 75,000 people. Unlike most Fringe festivals, FringeNYC uses a jury-based selection process. Around 200 shows, out of a much larger pool of applicants, are selected for inclusion each year. FringeNYC has also been the launching pad for numerous Off-Broadway and Broadway transfers, long-running downtown hits, and regional theater productions including Urinetown, Dog Sees God, Debbie Does Dallas, Matt & Ben, Never Swim Alone, and many others! FringeNYC alumni include Bradley Cooper, Melissa Rauch (Big Bang Theory), Morgan Spurlock (Supersize Me, CNN’s Inside Man), Mindy Kaling, Tony Award winner Diane Paulus (Pippin), Alex Timbers (Rocky), Leigh Silverman (Violet), W. Kamau Bell (Totally Biased), Michael Urie (Ugly Betty), Naomi Grossman (American Horror Story) and Chris Lowell (Enlisted), among countless other success stories.

The team



Jolie London Glickman, playwright & actress - Jolie wrote GIRLS WILL BE GIRLS last year as a 21-year-old NYU drama student. After spending years searching for juicy, honest, and funny roles for young actresses and not finding much, she decided to write it herself. Jolie tweets under the alias @princess_labia, where she promotes self-empowerment as well as works to destigmatize mental illness. PAPER Magazine included her in their “Amazing Women to Follow on the Internet in 2016 (and Always)” article and Mashable listed her in their “40 Times Ladies Ruled the World in 2015” issue. She created (and curates) #selfiearmy as well as last summer’s body-positive #thighreading. People Magazine, the Today Show, MTV, Cosmopolitan, Buzzfeed, Women’s Health, and BBC have all written about Jolie’s social impact. Jolie recived her BFA in Drama from NYU/Tisch School of the Arts a few weeks ago, where she studied at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute and Stonestreet Studios; she also studied playwrighting and screenwriting at NYU’s Rita & Burton Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing. Jolie is very proud to be making her NYC debut (outside of NYU) as a playwright and actress in this year’s FringeNYC.
www.JolieLondonGlickman.com


Shira-Lee Shalit, director - Shira-Lee is an award-winning film and theater director. Steven Spielberg chose her out of 12,000 directors, as one of 18 Finalists for the show, On The Lot.  Shira-Lee recently directed Fault Lines by Stephen Belber (Tape, The Muscles in Our Toes) at the Barrow Group Theatre and has directed for the LAByrinth Theater Company, Barefoot Theatre Company, Nylon Fusion Theatre, Vertigo Theater Company, The Jewish Plays Project, Stonestreet Studios, NYMadness, Thespis Theatre Festival, The Lark, and the Writers Guild East Screenplay Series.  Shira-Lee was awarded the prestigious Presidential Scholar of the Arts Award at the White House,  and won the National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts Award.  Shira-Lee is a graduate of NYU (BFA Acting) and Columbia University (MFA Directing). A member of the Actors Studio Playwrights/Directors Unit, Shira-Lee teaches master classes for the LAByrinth Theater Company and is an Associate Director with the Barefoot Theater Company. Shira-Lee is on faculty at both Columbia University and at NYU. 
www.Shira-LeeShalit.com

Corinne Woods, producer - Corinne Woods is a Brooklyn-based theater maker, producer, and arts administrator. She is the General Manager of Ma-Yi Theater Company, and the founder of Not Without Rage, a queer theatre collective. She has worked with a range of theater and dance companies including All For One, Random Access Theatre, Untitled Theater Company #61, The Lark Play Development Center, Ballet for Young Audiences, and Snorks and Pins Productions.

Every bit of love helps

No donation is too small! Getting the opportunity to stage this production is a dream come true, and from the bottom of our hearts, we thank you for any help you may offer. If you would like to support our production, we have a few small perks to offer, though we could never express our full gratitude. 

Spread the word!

Whether or not you can donate, you can still support GIRLS WILL BE GIRLS by telling your friends and family about our production. Tweet about us, Facebook about us, mention us when there's an awkward silence on your Tinder date. Word of mouth is everything! If you receive GIRLS WILL BE GIRLS stickers and feel so inclined to beautify the world with them (especially if you live in NY) go right ahead! You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to help this campaign, as well as the hashtag #GirlsWillBeGirls on Twitter to be retweeted by the playwright!

Your support means the world. Visit www.GirlsWillBeGirlsThePlay.com for more updates. Tickets for GIRLS WILL BE GIRLS go on sale July 15th.

story:
Scavenger Hunt:

Congrats you found the first of the clues, next visit the site all about views and check out Sapphire’s eye shadow hues...


Our Initiative 


   At Open Air Productions we are working together to create Snow Queen for our fourth year thesis project. This production has become more than a grade to the team, as we are dedicated to bringing the first annual holiday drag show to Toronto, Canada. It is an opportunity for young members and supporters of the LGBTQ Community to showcase the talent that is bursting at the seams inside the Church and Wellesley Village. All ticket proceeds from the event will be donated to support a local charity dedicated to providing a safe space for members of the LGBTQ Community. Help us bring Snow Queen to life by funding this project and supporting the initiative behind it!

Open Air Productions was founded by 7 fourth year students from The RTA School of Media at Ryerson University. Members of the team are skilled in studio productions and live events. Their most recent project was producing The RTA School of Media's annual student award show at the CBC Glenn Gould Studio in April 2014. 

Open Air Productions:
Executive Producers: Alanna O'Connor & Sachil Patel 
Director: Vivian Ming 
Writing/Casting Director: Daniel Rostas
Marketing Director: Ally Sebben
Technical Producer: Ashley Gheerawo
Segment Producer: Heather Selmayer

The Goal 

We need to raise $2000 in the next 30 days. This money will go towards offsetting the costs of expenses for the total budget. We are hosting the event at one of Toronto's historic theatres, Winter Gardens Theatre, so we want to ensure every aspect of our production is nothing short of perfection. From the queen's costumes to rehearsals spaces, we need all the help we can get.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Thank you to those that choose to donate to our project! If you want to continue to support Snow Queen, make sure to check out our website snowqueen2014.ca and like our social media pages. As well, we would be honoured to have you attend the show on December 12th, 2014 at the Winter Garden Theatre on Yonge Street in Toronto! Also don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
ABOUT THE DANCE

"LINE 0" by EstadoFlotante is a dance performance that explores different human connections through the concept of energy transformation, using a dynamic and intense physicality. Energy has the characteristic of traveling through the body, the objects, and the space; therefore, this transformation also influences the environment and the atmosphere. Line 0 is rooted in the search for a primal connection that moves the dancers to exist in the present moment, the movement and people around them, surfacing the emotional qualities based on their own decisions and experiences.

I started this process in 2013 where I tried the central ideas of this work, My intention was to develop a dance from physical reaction, in a way that we discover the piece each time it is performed. Now after almost two years I restart the process with a completely different group of dancers and collaborating with a costume designer and a music composer; we get to complete the work and discover new things each time. It doesn't stop surprising me all the mystery hidden that a group, a dancer, a movement, and a performance situation can reveal.

LINE 0 will be presented at GREEN SPACE STUDIO (in full length) in Long Island City the upcoming March 20th and 21st and an excerpt in BROOKLYN FIREPROOF at Bushwick in April 3rd and 4th.

ABOUT THE CHOREOGRAPHER 

Alvaro Gonzalez Dupuy is a Chilean Dance Artist currently based in Brooklyn. He Completed his dance studies in Santiago de Chile Based in Laban/leeder technique and served as a prominent performer for renowned choreographers while he started to explore choreography on his own. When coming to New York, as an emerging dance artist, he started to explore his ideas in dance movement and choreography to create dance performance under the name of EstadoFlotante. (check www.estadoflotante.com)

WHAT WE NEED

We previously received enough donations from generous individuals to pay for rehearsal space but now we are in need of $5000 to compensate our dancers, music composer, Costume designer, and Cover other technical expenses.

Dancers compensation: $4000 ($500 each for 8 dancers)

Music Composer: $400

Costume designer: $300

Technician: $300

We work hard to get this project going, dancers expose their bodies to intense physical work every day in addition to the love and passion that they put on the scene for the audience to experience a connection and the joy of their dance. your donation will help to provide modest compensation for their dedication and professionalism.

If we don't reach our goal we will use whatever money is raised to cover production expenses. any remaining funds will be split evenly among the performers.

 
PLEASE HELP US SPREAD THE WORD. SUPPORT CAN BE EXPRESSED IN DIFFERENT WAYS. THIS PERFORMANCE WOULDN'T BE THE SAME WITHOUT IT.
AND ALSO WE HOPE YOU CAN MAKE IT TO OUR PERFORMANCES!

story:
Particle # B is having a presentation!

After working on this insane project for the last 2 years, we are finally at the last stretch. In the end of August the team will be going in to a residency at the beautiful VALSPEC theater in Valleyfield and you are all invited. Since this residency is really at the final stages,  so are the funds. I set up this mini campaign for those friends and loved ones who would like to attend the presentation and are interested in giving a little something in return. There will be no official ticket sales, this page is just so you can give a small amount if you want to help out. The money will go directly to the expenses of the residency and to paying my amazing creative team. 

After all this work, I don't know what to say. I can't wait for you all to see my quantum baby.  

-K

story:
Can you spare $25 for the sake of art?!

Modern Times Stage Company in association with Crow’s Theatre presents Russian playwright Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard during the period of March 26 to April 13, 2019 in Toronto.  I have been really taken by the work of Soheil Parsa over the years and therefore wanted to reach out to some of my closest friends, family and/or likeminded creative aesthetes! - to assist in raising additional resources for this upcoming spectacular production!

It is a large-scale production and is going to need more money than it currently has to support a 10 + cast! My goal is to raise $5000 and thus am reaching out to a select group hoping that if each person can donate $25 I will reach my goal!

All money raised will go directly to production costs and you will receive a tax receipt for your donation. It would be incredible if you can help out here and of course -  hope to see you at the show as well!

MORE ABOUT THE SHOW

The Cherry Orchard has been described as "a theatre poem of the suffering of change" or a poem about life and death, transition and change. The Cherry Orchard unearths and explores the human comedy in the most tragic conditions. It is a comedy of life, with characters who are simultaneously ridiculous and touching. Modern Times' simple, imagistic and minimalist approach offers a new look into this timeless classical masterpiece. In a production filled with vitality, intimacy, poetry and fluidity, director Soheil Parsa explores the human capacity for self-destruction and self-deception, the mystery of life, loss of values, human loneliness and the inability of people to comprehend the world in which they live.

Cast

Arsinee Khanjian as Lyubov
Cliff Saunders as Gayev
Tara Nicodemo as Varya
Keshia Palm as Anya
Oyin Oladejo as Lopakhin
Aaron Willis as Trofimov
Steven Bush as Simenov-Pischik
Alix Sideris as Charlotta
Courtenay Stevens as Yepikhodov
Andrew Scorer as Firs
Diana Tso as Dunyasha
Colin Doyle as Yasha

 

Get your tickets too!

https://www.crowstheatre.com/whats-on/view-all/the-cherry-orchard

https://moderntimesstage.com/

https://www.facebook.com/moderntimesstage/

 

Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who Is Bridging Souls Productions?

Bridging Souls Productions come from the thoughts and dreams of myself, Tamara Prince-Parrish. I have been able to birth a company of professional contemporary modern dancers and choreographers that have come together for the past 4 years and produced 7 shows. SPRING AWAKENING will be our 8th show produced. Every show is designed to bring a professional aspect of dance to the Mid-South without having to travel far by offering different themes which fuses much variety combining genres such as:

  • Modern & Contemporary
  • African
  • Yoga
  • Hip Hop
  • Ballet
  • Jazz Dance

BSP has also opened doors to collaborate with other local companies, choreographers, musicians, and poets like OutLoud Artistry, Memphis Raqs, Rafael Tillery, Juju Bushman, Vicskeyas Faith Moore, and Marion "Gran Gran" Hooper, to name a few.

Where Your Help Comes In & What You Get (THANK YOU!)

Your generous donations help us produce shows that include hiring and paying the lighting designer, the sound engineer, paying for the rental of the theatre to host our shows and rentals for rehearsal space to produce our shows, and pay the dancers performance fee and the choreographers fee. Without your donation and contribution we will not be able to pay the wonderful people who make these beautiful shows possible.

  • You get quality, wholesome, and family friendly dance concerts that make you want an Encore !
  • You get a very appreciative Thank You from BSP!
  • You get tickets to SPRING AWAKENING!
  • You get a BSP T-shirt!
  • You get FREE private dance lessons and a month of FREE contemporary dance classes!
  • You get an autographed signed 20 X 30 poster from the dancers!

About The Show

    May 16-18, 2014
    Become renewed through the experience of random acts of faith, the action of life, and happy exploration of the human spirit in SPRING AWAKENING. Witness works from Dayton Contemporary Dance Company Member and University of Memphis Alumni Dorse Brown, New Ballet Ensemble Dancer Steven Prince Tate, and Freelance Performer and choreographer Frankie Fernandes with many others. 

    TIME: Friday/Saturday 8:00pm & Sunday 2:00pm
    LOCATION: Evergreen Theatre (Midtown Memphis) 1705 Poplar Ave, Memphis, TN 38104
    TICKETS: General Admission $20 in advance and at the door, Students, Senior Citizens & Children under 12 $10 
    CONTACT: 901-240-7879
    info@bridgingsoulsproducti

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially, don't worry you can share our campaign and spead the word about how wonderful our shows are:

  • Share the campaign link through email, Facebook, text, and twitter.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo link to make some noise for BSP!

We Appreciate You!!!!

story:
2016 SPRING SEASON: BROOKLYN

GMA returns to Brooklyn to premiere a cache of exciting new works. Our 2016 Spring Season includes:

  • A first glance at Rebecca Gushue's brand new never before seen Hen Hous.
  • And One Lap a current collaboration between Rebecca Gushue and fellow choreographer Nicole Kaplan.
  • And the New York city premiere of Charles Gushue's The Augur and the Amateurs: a half-evening experience not to be missed.

Our story...

We're Charles and Rebecca Gushue. In 2014 we launched Gushue Moving Arts(GMA), a multimodal dance organization. We're a small a fiscally sponsored dance organization run by a team of two who really love dance! We are raising $4,000 to help fund our 2016 Spring Season. 

Our ask...

Please consider donating $25, $50, $100, $250, or $500 to our SPRING SEASON 2016 giving campaign.

  • We are raising $4,000 by May 10th, 2016. All funds contributed go to our Spring Season in New York. 
  • Your donation will be used to cover dancer pay, rehearsals, space rentals, travel and lodging, and general operations, etc.

Here's a breakdown of what that looks like in dollar bills!

Eight dancers at $200/dancer... $1,600
Rehearsal and space rentals... $500
Travel and Lodging... $1,250
Costume design, construction, and care for three works... $350
Publicity, Marketing, and Promotion... $300

  • If we don't reach our ask, we'll keep on hustling. This campaign is one of several ways we fund our company, to find out more about our operations please visit our website at www.gushuemovingarts.org.
  • Keep your eyes on Facebook for surprise perks and prizes.
  • If all this digital hogwash makes you feel icky we're happy to send you our campaign information by SNAIL MAIL. Just email gushuemovingarts@gmail.com with your mailing address.

Top of your list...

We know you have lots of choices when considering charitable giving. Here are a few thoughts on why GMA should be at the top of your give list!

  • We're small, so your dollars go far in helping us achieve our goals.
  • You probably know us personally or have a loved one who is involved with our organization.
  • Gushue Moving Arts is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Gushue Moving Arts must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

We believe... 

Here's some of the things we believe at GMA...

  • We believe everyone impacts art and artists daily. Yes, even you!
  • We believe what we do and make as artists reflects and projects our relationships and communities. You're a part of that!
  • We believe that dance changes the world, and the world changes dance one rehearsal at a time. And we rehearse several times a week...so that's a lot of change!

Remember, we believe everyone impacts art. Today we're asking you to impact art with your wallet. 

We understand not everyone can contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Buy tickets to our show May 6th and 7th, 2016 at Triskelion Arts, Brooklyn, NY. 
  • Liking and sharing is free, so push that share to Facebook button and pat yourself on the back!

If you made it to the bottom, thanks for listening to our pitch, and we'll see you in NYC and beyond!

story:
J.A.S.O.N.

Myth, Murder & Mayhem 

in a Punk Rock World.

A comic re-imagining of

The Argonautica
&
Euripides’ Medea

Retold as a Punk Rock band

on their one-and-only tour

and staged at Club Bohemia

downstairs at the Cantab Lounge


Ever wonder about that title? Ever ask a playwright, “Where do you get your ideas?” In the case of J.A.S.O.N. the answers are one-and-the-same: the PBS news series Nightly Business Report.

That’s right, inspiration can come from anywhere. It was a bar graph of stock performance throughout the year and at the bottom of each bar was the first letter of each month. I couldn’t help noticing that the months July through November spell out J.A.S.O.N. and an idea was born.

What story could I tell in five scenes taking place over those five months? Maybe it’s the Greek in me, but I knew that it would have to involve that legendary leader of the Argonauts in the quest for the Golden Fleece - but how to make it work?

It was a short leap from a mythical band of heroes to a one-hit-wonder band of Punk Rockers and their biggest fan, a groupie named Medea. Still, there was the Golden Fleece to consider. What could stand in for such an iconic object as that? Then, it struck me:

MEDEA: Are you kidding? My dad runs this burg.
MELEAGER: Really?
MEDEA: Sure. Nobody makes a move in Colchis Aeëtes doesn’t know about.
MOTHER: You’re the daughter of Aeëtes?
MEDEA: You know him?
MOTHER: Only by reputation. He’s all mobbed up.
MEDEA: He’s a legitimate businessman. He owns the Dodge dealership.
MOTHER: Drives an old classic Dodge.
MEDEA: That’s right.
MOTHER: Customized.
MEDEA: All pimped out.
MOTHER: Has a solid gold hood ornament.
MEDEA: A golden ram.
EUPHEMUS: Sounds expensive.
MEDEA: It’s a bitchin’ ride.

Thank the gods of Olympus, Thalia the muse, the Dodge brothers and the company’s 1932 line of cars.

You may have noticed that no names were changed to protect the innocent. That’s right, this is a “classical” story, told through the point-of-view of the band. In fact, the seemingly titular Jason doesn’t even appear in the story, but remains an off stage presence. So, who are our heroes?

Euphemus, the last of his kind (various)
Nestor, an energetic youth, (drums) 
Meleager, a brawny outdoors man (guitar) 
Orpheus, a burn-out (vocals, bass)
Heracles, the most interesting man in the world (guitar)
Peleus, a surfing legend (guitar)
Atalanta, an athletic huntress (vocals, bass)
Medea, a groupie
Daughter of Euphemus
Mother of Euphemus

Why tell the story from the band’s P.O.V. and not depict Jason? Maybe it’s because I was an enlisted man and not an officer, but mostly it’s because I wanted to explore the group dynamics of a bunch of “A” type personalities in a back up role.

EUPHEMUS: Some wine, Heracles?
HERACLES: I don’t always drink wine, but when I do -
EUPHEMUS: Oh, just take the goatskin.
HERACLES: I could drink all of you under the table.
PELEUS: What about that night with Dionysus?
HERACLES: An aberration. The man’s not human.
PELEUS: Then you joined his cult for awhile.
HERACLES: It’s not a cult.
PELEUS: Following in procession.
HERACLES: It’s not a cult.
PELEUS: Do they get religious tax breaks?
HERACLES: It’s not a cult! — But, yes. They do get religious tax breaks.

What We Need & What You Get

We’re looking to raise $7,000 in 35 days. For those like me, who can’t do long division in their head, that’s $200 a day.

Where will these funds go?

Payroll (actors and production crew): $1,650
Musical Instruments (not a musical, but a play with music): $600
Space rental (audition, rehearsal, performance): $2,261
Set, lighting, costumes, props & blood. Lots of blood (you remember what happens to Medea’s brother, Apsyrtus, don’t you?): $2,200
Printing: $289 (Why not $250 or $300? Because what kind of numbers are 6,961 or 7,011?) TOTAL: $7,000

First person to contribute exactly $39 ($6,961+$39=$7,000) receives a great, one-of-a-kind perq.

Should we not reach a fully funded goal those funds released will be prioritized as follows: Space rental, payroll, production values and finally music. As written, each scene ends with just a bit of live music - we’ll go canned if we must - and the play closes with a full on Punk version of… You'll be surprised.

What we're offering - besides the chance to be part of a rockin' story in a non-traditional venue - is a veritable cornucopia of incentives. Poster? DVD? Wineskin of Orpheus? Yeah, we got that.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute? Don’t feel bad. You can still be part of the effort. Share our campaign with friends, family, lovers, fans of theatre, mythology & music. Help us get out the word about the epic journey upon which we are about to embark!

They do get religious tax breaks.

Lots of blood (you remember what happens to Medea’s brother, Apsyrtus, don’t you?): $2,200Printing: $289 (Why not $250 or $300? Because what kind of numbers are 6,961 or 7,011?) TOTAL: $7,000

As written, each scene ends with just a bit of live music - we’ll go canned if we must - and the play closes with a full on Punk version of… You'll be surprised.

What we're offering - besides the chance to be part of a rockin' story in a non-traditional venue - is a veritable cornucopia of incentives. Poster? DVD? Wineskin of Orpheus? Yeah, we got that.
Other Ways You Can Help

story:
The Scandinavian American Theater Company (SATC) is a collective of theater artists founded to provide Scandinavian perspectives through a new generation of Scandinavian playwrights and theater artists. We present contemporary plays and inventive takes on the classics from the Nordic region, including Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Denmark, Greenland and the Faroe Islands.  We are committed to strengthening the relationship between Scandinavia and the United States through collaborations and interdisciplinary artistic exchanges that examine and challenge the cultural status quo.

In celebrating our 5th Anniversary, Bastards of Strindberg represents the first fully commissioned project by SATC in our continuing effort to bring international artists together to create unique, exciting and meaningful theatrical experiences. American playwrights Dominique Morisseau and David Bar Katz along with Swedish playwrights Lina Ekdahl and Andreas Boonstra were each asked to write an original, short piece based on August Strindberg’s classic play, Miss Julie. The four distinct works will be performed each night by an ensemble of actors who will take part in each show. Bastards of Strindberg will be presented at Theatre Row from September 4th - 21st.

With this show in particular, we intend to explore and display the full potential of theatrical collaboration...and we would love your help to see it through! Donations of any kind go directly into supporting lighting, set, costume and sound design, as well as rehearsal space rental and marketing materials. Every dollar will be spent creating and promoting three weeks of this unique and exciting night of theater.

Companies like SATC would not be able to continue to provide quality without help and blessings from the theater-going public. Even if you are unable to donate at this time, please do not hesitate to pass along this campaign or our mission to those you know who may be interested in helping SATC continue to strive for excellence and diversity-of-thought in independent theater in New York City and abroad. 

THANK YOU! 

The Scandinavian American Theater Company

story:
Short Summary

"I'm a really good girl!  I don't even have a traffic ticket!"  That's the note I sent to the house mother of The Rehearsal Club back in 1970.  I got a cot in a room with 4 other young women -- all of us pursuing a dream in the theater.  Two weeks later I was on Broadway, met my husband of 40 years and, here I am, trying to help "preserve the name of The Rehearsal Club, tell its story and inspire future generations."  That's our Mission Statement.

Now?  The site of our lovely home is now a vacant lot.  We, the women of The Rehearsal Club, are heightening the awareness for the City of New York to understand how very important that dilapidated, old brownstone was to the many young professionals trying to stay in New York and get a foothold in one of its most challenging professions.

  • July 1, 2013 is our Centennial
  • Women from all over the country are coming to renew friendships.
  • Our collaboration has inspired a documentary, a book and a new musical.

None of the women of the RC were born with a financial cushion.  All we had were big dreams.  Some of us achieved fame -- like Carol Burnett & Blythe Danner -- many of us had our 15 minutes on Broadway, film and TV.  Me?  You may remember me as "Katie Parker" on The Guiding Light, but like The Rehearsal Club, that's gone too except in hearts of our many fans.

What We Need & What You Get

All funding is TAX-DEDUCTIBLE.  We're setting a first goal of $5,000 which will primarily fund The Players Club space and catering for other "free" spaces donated by the Museum of Modern Art and the Erarta New York Gallery.

We are ALSO taking seed money from anyone who would like to target the development of the new musical, "Good Girls Only," currently in development.  A staged reading is set for March 13, 2013 in New York with a stellar Broadway cast.

  • Some events are open to the public - like the Lincoln Center Library presentation on June 27, 2013.
  • $1,000 donors, however, will get a seat at our exclusive Players Club Dinner and get a chance to mix and mingle with the stars!
  • Other donors will receive our exclusive merchandise (while supplies last).
  • Large Donors (potential producers) to the musical will be invited to the first presentation.

The Impact

The women of the Rehearsal Club represent collaboration and support.  That first job I got on Broadway?  One of the RC girls coached me on my song for the call back.  The rest of my Cinderella life is history.

  • This Centennial is NOT just a "reunion." 
  • We will be spotlighting attention on the need for affordable arts housing in New York.
  • This Centennial will also debut the collaborative efforts of the alum through the documentary trailer, the book and the new musical. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word! 

  • "Like" our Rehearsal Club page.
  • Join us as a "Friend of The Rehearsal Club" at www.rehearsalclubnyc.com!

Large Donors (potential producers) to the musical will be invited to the first presentation.


The Impact
The women of the Rehearsal Club represent collaboration and support.  That first job I got on Broadway?  One of the RC girls coached me on my song for the call back.  The rest of my Cinderella life is history.

This Centennial is NOT just a "reunion." 
We will be spotlighting attention on the need for affordable arts housing in New York.
This Centennial will also debut the collaborative efforts of the alum through the documentary trailer, the book and the new musical. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Help us spread the word! 

"Like" our Rehearsal Club page.
Join us as a "Friend of The Rehearsal Club" at www.rehearsalclubnyc.com!

story:
The Teeth of Haros

  • Cowards and Kings is a new theatre company founded by young aspiring theatre makers Joshua MacGregor and Chomba Taulo, actors-in-training who have a strong passion for theatre and new writing. Josh's rich history in dance and creative writing have allowed him to create characters who are living, breathing, and can inhabit the theatre space. Chomba's extensive knowledge of acting theory, hunger to always learn more, and eagerness to explore the arts make him a driving force of positive change in the world and the perfect man to be directing the company's first play.

 

  • As theatre practitioners, we believe that the Edinburgh Fringe is the ideal stage for upcoming companies to create and present new work, and would be an invaluable opportunity for us to learn more about our craft and to come into contact with our fellows, the next generation of theatre makers.

 

  • Making it to this festival will go a long way to launching our emerging theatre company out into the world. Doing so with minimal financial strain will allow us to place all our efforts into creating a piece of work that is sophisticated, powerful, and meaningful to today's society. The closer we get to our goal, the easier it will be to make this possible and continue our work in future years. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • This Indiegogo campaign is the first stage of our fundraising. Our £800 goal will go a long way to helping us pay our registration and venue fees which make up our largest expenses. 
  • In the event that we do not reach our goal, the money raised here, alongside our other means of fundraising, will still go towards getting to the Edinburgh  Fringe. 

 

The Impact

  • While this is the first undertaking of our company, our stage manager, Victoria Lewis, has had previous experience and success with taking shows to the Edinburgh Fringe.
  • As we all know funding for theatre is incredibly hard to come by. Many high quality productions often go unseen due to lack of funding and we feel that this play deserves to be seen and shared.

The Teeth of Haros
Cowards and Kings is a new theatre company founded by young aspiring theatre makers Joshua MacGregor and Chomba Taulo, actors-in-training who have a strong passion for theatre and new writing. Josh's rich history in dance and creative writing have allowed him to create characters who are living, breathing, and can inhabit the theatre space. Chomba's extensive knowledge of acting theory, hunger to always learn more, and eagerness to explore the arts make him a driving force of positive change in the world and the perfect man to be directing the company's first play.
 
As theatre practitioners, we believe that the Edinburgh Fringe is the ideal stage for upcoming companies to create and present new work, and would be an invaluable opportunity for us to learn more about our craft and to come into contact with our fellows, the next generation of theatre makers.
 
Making it to this festival will go a long way to launching our emerging theatre company out into the world. Doing so with minimal financial strain will allow us to place all our efforts into creating a piece of work that is sophisticated, powerful, and meaningful to today's society. The closer we get to our goal, the easier it will be to make this possible and continue our work in future years. 
 

What We Need & What You Get

This Indiegogo campaign is the first stage of our fundraising. Our £800 goal will go a long way to helping us pay our registration and venue fees which make up our largest expenses. 
In the event that we do not reach our goal, the money raised here, alongside our other means of fundraising, will still go towards getting to the Edinburgh  Fringe. 

 

The Impact

While this is the first undertaking of our company, our stage manager, Victoria Lewis, has had previous experience and success with taking shows to the Edinburgh Fringe.
As we all know funding for theatre is incredibly hard to come by. Many high quality productions often go unseen due to lack of funding and we feel that this play deserves to be seen and shared.

story:
The Skinny

  • Bringing a production to life that small companies don't often mount.
  • Allowing artists and designers an opportunity to build historically accurate pieces.
  • Contributing to the creation of an original cello composition.
  • Emboldening L.I.P. Service to tackle larger scale productions in future seasons.
  • Building the foundation for the growth of the company.
  • Helping to produce and give voice to one of the great outcasts, Mr. Merrick.

We want to build to a place of art that attracts the best from our community. Not only for theatre, but for all facets of artistic expression. The company has boldly expanded to 8 productions this season; and, that's in no small part due to the donations and support from contributors like yourself. #ItsAllAboutTheArt

story:
Hello! We are Kate Dickinson and Justin Goodemoot, co-Artistic Directors of APT Theater. We are thrilled to present The Return, our first full-length, fully-staged production in New York. We've come a long way to get here and we need your help to get a little further!

We grew up three fields apart in rural Michigan. Since those early days of dirt roads and back yards, we've been writing and performing. We were cast in our first show together when we were fourteen and collaborated on our first original piece of theater at seventeen. We auditioned for the same college theater and discovered we were accepted on the same day. After graduating, we moved to New York, where we embarked on separate, weirdly parallel, careers as professional actors and writers. When we discovered we had the same goals for what we wanted to create, we vowed to once again become allies! Shortly after, we wrote and produced our first in a continuing series of one-acts called The Apartment Plays, performed in, you guessed it, apartments around the city.

From there, we have continued to grow. Our network of artists and collaborators is constantly expanding as our projects broaden in seemingly limitless scope. Fifteen years after we met, and six hundred miles away, we finally gave ourselves a name – APT Theater. 

And now we’re producing our first full-length, fully-staged play and we need YOUR support!

THE PLAY

The Return 
by Justin Goodemoot

After a night of partying yields tragic results for five friends, they are forced to confront long-hidden truths about themselves and each other.

July 18 - 28, 2013
The Gallery at Access Theater
New York, NY

THE COST 

Producing a play in New York is very expensive. A few of the costs we’re about to encounter include:

Rental fees for rehearsal studios and the Gallery Theater
Insurance for the cast, crew, and audience
Stipends for the hardworking cast and crew
Marketing materials, including posters, postcards, and listings
The set, including custom-made doors, and furniture, including a couch and a refrigerator
Props and costumes

HOW YOU CAN HELP!

Help our new theater company accomplish its first major milestone by donating as much as you can today. After you donate, tell your friends (by liking us on Facebook and sharing this page) and encourage them to throw a few bucks our way too! If you can’t donate to get the show on its feet make sure you come see it this summer - we're assembling a killer cast and crew and know it will be an event you won't want to miss!

THANK YOU!

- Justin and Kate

story:
DONATIONS and PERKS:

Your donation goes directly to indiegogo.com, which will make a single payment to Shots in the Dark Independent Theatre Company, and it is not tax-deductible as a charitable donation. We thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

All promotional items provided directly by Shots in the Dark Independent Theatre Company as a gift to fan supporters. Indiegogo is not responsible for providing any of the stated perks.

Our Story

During the summer of 2007 several students at The Columbus Academy formed Shots in the Dark Independent Theatre Company to provide performance opportunities for students not getting the chance to perform. The Columbus Academy graciously allowed us to perform in their theater. Our first production, The Long Red Herring, turned out to be a greater success than expected. We used the donations from the show to grow. We formed working relationships with Parks and Recreations Departments and other community theaters to perform in some of the most beautiful theatre spaces in Central Ohio. We celebrated our fifth anniversary season with an expanded production schedule including our inaugural winter season. Starting with this past season Shots in the Dark shifted focus to producing new work, work new to Columbus, or work rarely produced in Columbus. This past summer, operating under this philosophy, we produced three new plays including the award-winning shows "Swing of the Sea" and "Lunch Lady: Tater Tots of Love" which played a sold-out run. We earned 19 BroadwayWorld Columbus award nominations, and won 9! We are in the process of obtaining our non-profit 501(c)3 status so patrons can enjoy the tax benefits of sponsoring a non-profit corporation. As a non-profit, professional theatre company, Shots in the Dark continues to rely on sponsorships and donations for our continued success. 

What We Need & What You Get

Shots in the Dark is at a crucial time in our development.  We are producing our largest season yet with more actors and technicians than we've ever had. We are producing 2 premiere productions, 1 critcally acclaimed revival, and 1 fan-favorite not seen in Columbus for years!

Your contribution will play a key role in the financing of such a large undertaking. With your donation, large or small, you will pledge that you believe, like us, that theatre is the most important story telling medium and people of all ages and experiences should be given the chance to perform. By supporting us, you will become a member of the ever-growing Shots in the Dark family!

You will also directly contribute to the strengthening of communities. Our goal isn’t just to make art but to make art that empowers, and celebrates the bond that is a group of people working together to make life a little better - for everyone. And we haven't even begun to mention the perks that come with your donation. Check them out!

In recognition of your support, certain "perks" will be made available. Everything from recognition on our highly trafficked website to VIP tickets to the opening night of the Columbus premiere of Next to Normal are available as a thank you for your contribution.  Please, pledge today.  We deeply appreciate your help.

The Impact

Your donation will help Shots in the Dark provide professional and amateur performance opportunitues to over fifty actors ranging in age from 12-65 and over twenty technicians and directors ranging in age from 20-60! You will also be helping bring new and popular work, never before seen in Columbus, to our beautiful city.

Other Ways You Can Help

Talk about us!  Learn about our company, and talk about the shows and their message with your families and friends.  Please visit our website (shotsinthedarkitc.com) to learn more about our shows. Like us on Facebook and follow us on twitter. We can't spread our message with out your help. Pledge to Shots in the Dark today!

story:
Help us achieve a Dream!

We're college students doing our final project and we decided to go a little further than we were asked to. We always dreamt of making musicals, so we're doing one. We're doing all the production, adaptation, translation, direction, choreography, vocals, scenery, costumes, makeup, etc. Our actors are a triple threat, they act, they sing, they dance and they're so passionate about what they're doing that you can feel the energy rushing your way when you see them perform.

You will help us achieve something our teachers told us was impossible, for it's not the ordinary school production, it's in a bar, the staff and waiters greet you characterized at the door, it has a live professional orchestra, and as soon as you step into the venue, it's a revival of the 1930's in Germany. The tables, the menus, the pictures in the walls and the decorations glow in candlelight as you wait for the show to begin. The characters come to your table during the performance, and make you part of the experience.

We need the funding for material. We design and make everything, but we need fabrics, wood, paint, makeup, microphones, etc.

If you help us, besides tickets and a vip table to watch our show, you'll get from a poster signed by the cast or a dvd of the show signed by the cast, to a free dinner after the show attended by our 1930's staff and a backstage pass. And also, you could get our main character's BRA/HAT signed by our super hot cast.
