MARIANELA NUNEZ, Royal Ballet 
FEDERICO BONELLI, Royal Ballet 
VALENTINO ZUCCHETTI, Primo Solista The Royal Ballet Company Londra (Inghilterra)
GIADA ROSSI, Solista Compagnia Nacional De Danza Madrid (Spagna)
LORENZO SILINGARDI, Ballerino SNG Opera Ballet Ljubiana (Slovenia)
ROSA PIERRO, Choryphée Polish Dance Company (Polonia)
RINALDO VENUTI, Solista Polish Dance Company (Polonia)
ALESSANDRO RIGA, Primo Ballerino Compagnia Nacional De Danza Madrid (Spagna)
HARUHI OTANI, Solista Compagnia National De danza Madrid (Spagna)
CHIARA RONTINI, Ballerina MIR Dance Company di Gelsenkirchen (Germania)
MM CONTEMPORARY DANCE COMPANY diretta da Michele Merola
 Ma non finisce qui! In quel weekend si svolgeranno master classes per studenti di balletto con alcuni dei grandi nomi in programma come Federico Bonelli (Primo Ballerino Royal Ballet Company Londra), Valentino Zucchetti (Primo Solista Royal Ballet Company Londra), Pino Alosa (Ballet Master Internazionale).Inoltre «Metti le Ali al Talento» è onorata di ospitare l’Audizione per il Corso Estivo della prestigiosa scuola American Ballet Theater con i Maestri Franco De Vita e Raymond Lukens.Per tutte le informazioni relative agli eventi del 26 e 27 ottobre 2019 visitate il sito www.mettilealialtalento.it   Ateneo Danza: ci presentiamo La scuola ATENEO DANZA nasce nel 1993 a Forlì e, fin dalla sua fondazione, svolge un'importante funzione di promozione della danza e costituisce un punto fermo di riferimento per tutti coloro che desiderano avvicinarsi al mondo della danza e delle arti in genere; l'alta preparazione, qualificazione e professionalità dei docenti e dei maestri ospiti è sicuramente la garanzia più importante che ha fatto crescere negli anni la realtà del centro.ATENEO DANZA svolge anche una fondamentale azione di formazione e divulgazione nelle scuole del territorio di riferimento: da anni ormai collabora con grande successo con alcune scuole materne ed elementari della città per avviare progetti di inserimento della danza all'interno di tali strutture, in collaborazione con le insegnanti di attività motoria.Il grande punto di forza della scuola è la stretta collaborazione con docenti e direttori provenienti dalle principali accademie professionali internazionali, grazie ai quali gli allievi hanno la possibilità di aprire gli orizzonti e fare tesoro di grandi insegnamenti. Grazie a queste magnifiche opportunità negli ultimi anni tanti, tantissimi studenti hanno lasciato ATENEO DANZA per inseguire un sogno internazionale e diversi di loro, già diplomati, sono ora affermati professionisti in carriera.www.ateneodanza.it_____________________English version LET’S GIVE THIS TALENT WINGS: Dance scholarships. Help us fund scholarships for talented young Italian dancers! OUR PROJECT“Dancing is just discovery, discovery, discovery.” ― Martha Graham We often hear how essential dance is for growth, especially that of children. Indeed, it develops balance and coordination, helps master the concept of space and enhances both visual memory and intuition.What we learn through dance will stay with us forever, guiding us for the rest of our lives without us even realising!Dance is for everyone, of course, but for some it is also the vision of a working future. Countless young students invest in this great passion, trying to turn it into a profession. Not finding the right opportunity to develop and enhance their skills in Italy, many decide to look abroad.The “Let’s give this talent wings” project was created for this reason, from a need to offer talented young Italian dancers the chance to develop their professional skills and take flight, going abroad both to become great artists and for educational experiences that characterise them for life.We need €6000 to develop this project - and you can donate, too! HOW WE WILL USE YOUR DONATION We will create scholarships for talented young Italian students through the project and with your donation, thus helping families support their studies abroad.The number of scholarships to be awarded will be decided based on how much we collect: the more funds we have, the more opportunities we’ll be able to give these youngsters!We need your support to reach our goal of €6000 and why not, collect even more if you involve your friends, too!The staff of LET’S GIVE THIS TALENT WINGS has been working for months to turn a dream into reality, planning a whole host of dance events in order to do so. 26th-27th OCTOBER 2019: a weekend dedicated to the beauty of dance Besides a crowdfunding campaign, we decided to create an amazing event to promote our project. Two days of dance workshops, masterclasses and auditions will end with an International Grand Gala of dance hosted on the stage of the prestigious Bonci Theatre in Cesena.It will be with great pleasure, as well as pride and excitement, that we will watch talented Italian students performing on the beautiful stage of this prestigious theatre in Cesena on Sunday 27th October at 8.45p.m..We’ve been talking to a lot of people, many of whom are backing our project. The Municipality of Cesena, for example, has understood the uniqueness and importance of what we’re doing and shown its support by granting us Patronage for this extraordinary event. Indeed, it’s being announced as one that is not only regional but national and international, too!Many young Italian dancers who have flown abroad after signing contracts with some of the most prestigious dance companies in the world will perform during the show. Moreover, career prizes will be awarded to two dancers considered to be amongst the most important on the current world dance scene: Federico Bonelli (The Royal Ballet) and Marianela Núñez (The Royal Ballet) who, along with many other extraordinary professional dancers, will receive their awards from Ms. Carla Fracci.

story:
If you have a donation, please make it to me directly through Paypal or check. This will avoid unnecessary processing fees and us losing money. If you have a Paypal account you may send money to my account by using this email: elizabethsballetboutique@gmail.com.  Checks should be written to "Elizabeth A. Ives" and can be given to me personally if you know me, or mailed to my address at 469 SW Boston Way, Beaverton, OR 97006, Thank you!

Hello, my name is Elizabeth Ives. I am a dedicated, and passionate ballet student.  I have been studying ballet from age 4 to 17 years old presently (13 years) and have trained in Pointe, Pas de deux, Modern, Jazz, Character, and Acting as well. For the last several years I have been training under John Magnus, former Artistic Director of The Joffrey Ballet Academy. I have played key roles in "The Nutcracker" including Marie (Clara), and The Snow Queen; along with Mirlitons, Spanish, Flowers, Snowflakes, and many other roles.  Presently, I have been accepted to and am attending the School of Oregon Ballet Theatre.  I have been accepted to San Francisco Ballet Summer Program, and we will soon find out my results for American Ballet Theatre's Summer Program.  I have also been invited to audition for the Royal Ballet School in London, England, which we will need to raise funds for me to go.  It has been my lifelong dream to become a professional ballerina and this is the next step on my way there.  John Magnus highly recommends me as a talented and promising student.  In school, I earn straight A's and when I set a goal I will do my utmost best to make it happen.

This year I have been accepted to the San Francisco Ballet Summer Program (SFBallet) and hope that we can raise enough funds to make it possible for me to attend it or the American Ballet Theatre Summer Intensive (ABT).  I have also been invited to attend an audition for The Royal Ballet School's year round program in London, England, so we need to raise funds for this trip too.

What are these programs?: San Francisco Ballet and American Ballet Theatre's summer intensives are world-renowned, highly acclaimed, and excellent programs where I can polish and finely tune my technique, skill, and artistry as a dancer and performer.  During a summer intensive I will spend on average 4-5 hours a day, 6 days a week dancing and training with master teachers.  I will take classes in ballet as well as other dance forms such as modern, character, and conditioning.  Seminars and lectures provide me with knowledge on dance history, nutrition, injury prevention, and other important information.  This intense and enriching experience is significant to my ballet training and contributes immensely to my journey to becoming a professional.  I have attended these programs in the past and have gained a wealth of knowledge and experience.                                                      The Royal Ballet School Covent Garden is world renowned school of ballet and it is an honor to even be invited to audition.  The program that I am auditioning for is a comprehensive 3-year course in classical ballet in conjunction with excellent academic provision.  In the first two years the student trains in ballet, pas de deux, solos, repertoire, character, contemporary, stagecraft, body conditioning and gym work alongside academics. The third year's focus is performance experience, with an emphasis on performing with The Royal Ballet or Birmingham Royal Ballet.  This is one of my favorite ballet companies and schools and it would be a dream come true even to just audition there.

This training is expensive and I won't be able to attend without aid financially. San Francisco Ballet Summer Program costs a total of $4800, including housing.  When we reach this goal in donated funds then we will use this money to pay for the program.  Additional funds raised will go towards buying a plane ticket and paying for a trip to fly to London, England to audition for the Royal Ballet School year round program.  I have trained since I was 4 years old, and spent many hours working with my teachers to develop strong technique and beautiful grace in my dancing.  I have grown and came a long way, but I still have a ways to go to accomplish my goal, and I want to make my teachers proud after all they have done for me.  I need your help to fund this next big step in my ballet career so that I can continue to express God's glory through my dancing, develop my artistic skills, and become a professional.

Thank you for your consideration and support to sponsor me.  I look forward to hearing from you.  Every little bit helps and with enough people I believe that we can make this possible!

If you aren't able to donate, you can still help by spreading the word! Please share my campaign on Facebook, email and tell your friends about it!

Rewards:

I appreciate every little contribution made to help me attend this program and fulfill my potential, so everyone who donates will receive a gift.  Everyone who contributes will be listed on this page if they like, with special listing for the higher amounts donated. Depending on the amount donated, sponsors will receive emails and other types of gratitude including cards, recordings, and pictures.  For donors that donate $500 and above, I will send you a special postcard from the city where I attend the intensive.  For a $1000 donor, they will receive a handcrafted pair of socks made by me (I also know how to crochet).  Immense gratitude is extended to all that contribute to reach this goal!!

Referral Contest:

If you are unable to donate or you would like to do even more to help, you can still participate and help me raise these funds by sharing this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, links or email.  The contest is based on how many funds are raised (contributions made) through your referrals. If you qualify for one of these rewards, make sure that I know the right contact information to be able to send it to you.

Referral Contest Rewards: Based on how many funds are raised from your referrals.

1. $100 raised: A listing as an excellent referrer on this page. A thank you email with digital thank you card created by Elizabeth.

2. $500 raised: A listing as an outstanding referrer. A thank you email with digital thank you card created by Elizabeth, and ask Elizabeth a question relating to her dance training in email.  

3. $1000 raised: A listing as a top referrer. A thank you email and an artistic card handmade by Elizabeth mailed to your address; Ask Elizabeth a question relating to her dance training; A thank you phone call from Elizabeth.

The time period for this contest is from Jan. 26th-March. 17th, 2015. Rewards will be given in April, 2015 after the campaign.

Risks:

Of course we all hope that nothing serious will rise up as an obstacle to this campaign and to stop me from accomplishing my goal, but things sometimes happen and I am willing to realize and address those things. 

One obvious obstacle is money. My family is not rich, but we do the best we can to afford education to pursue our goals and careers.  This fundraiser should help me to afford to attend this summer program and ensure that I can continue in my ballet training.

I have attained an advanced level of ballet training through my hard work and dedication and I plan to continue this process and grow into a beautiful professional ballerina.  I am prepared to meet any challenges and obstacles with confidence, determination, and creativity to overcome them.  Your donation will help this project be a success!


Funders:

I am so happy with the amount that we have already raised!! Every little bit helps and this is going to be a huge help so that I can attend one of the programs this summer.  Thank you so much everyone!!

List of Supporters:

Heather Vogel Frederick

Margie and David Beckett

Anonymous Donors: 3

story:
ABOUT THE SHOW

So glad you’re here! We’re creating a new musical — a creative, positive approach to an issue that divides us all too often. Our work has been called fresh, sensitive, and entertaining, and we hope you'll want to lend your thoughts and your support. 

The show is called A Pint of Understanding: The Professor, the Policeman and the President, and it all started with a true story. Remember the controversial arrest of a famous African American professor by a white police officer? The media ran away with the story, and that led to the “Beer Summit” with President Obama at the White House. The whole thing got intense very quickly, and almost as quickly, it was swept under the rug.

And then Trayvon Martin and Eric Garner; Donald Sterling and Ferguson… and here we are, one nation, indivisible ... ? Our team, the Pint Collaborative, felt we had to do something, and for us, that meant writing a musical. (What? More on that and the team in a minute.) Everything we’ve learned from working together during the last 18 months has made clear that most of us Americans — most of us humans — want the same things. We want harmony. Respect. Change for the better. (To love and be loved. The list goes on.)

We believe A Pint of Understanding is an important work, a rejection of this painful divide, a revolt against complacency, a creative and positive contribution to the progress our country can make — if we all insist on it.

And we think it’s a really great show.

Creatively, A Pint of Understanding might feel both familiar and adventurous to you. It’s an experiment in hybridity: It makes the most of the power and immediacy of live theater, but it also feels like a movie. The music has a jazz sensibility, but a number of genres come into play — blues, rhumba, gospel, R&B and hip hop, to name a few. And ultimately, the show will make use of projections and multimedia to depict the influence of the media on society.

The Pint of Understanding family includes an extended group of people who are passionate about bringing this musical to life. They have generously given their time, talent, and resources to help us get us to the point where we can produce a workshop this February in Boston. We’re talking about the complete work — all the music and a revised book (the play) based on feedback we’ve gotten from two previous developmental readings and performances. We’ve been doing this independently, but now it’s getting real, the stakes are higher, and we’re ready to take it to the next level. But we can’t make it happen without you. 

We need your help and we hope you’ll join with us.

The dubious arrest of the Professor Henry Louis Gates, Jr. was the inspiration for our story — but A Pint of Understanding is a work of fiction. It ventures off and explores the issues broadly, imagining how things might have gone if the president had appointed the professor and the police officer to work together. We bring all points of view into focus and introduce characters we hope you’ll come to love. Plus, they can sing!

Our story offers a few twists that we think you’ll enjoy, some points to reflect on, and — believe it or not — a lot of laughs. As Chekov said, "Tragedy is about the difficult. Comedy is about the unbearable.” In other words, comic relief gives us some room to breathe and the opportunity to laugh at ourselves and then … get back to it.

Our creative team, “The Pint Collaborative,” consists of not one but two composers, Joel LaRue Smith and Joseph Smith, lyricist/book writer Lee Phenner, director Benny Sato Ambush, and music director Scott Nicholas. In a sense, our diverse backgrounds and experiences actually bring to life the central messages of A Pint of Understanding. We did that on purpose. You can learn more about us below.

A forum for discussion: When we say we’re inviting you in, we really mean it. The February 2015 workshop will feature a post-performance discussion where the audience, cast and an expert in cultural studies will discuss their views in an open and constructive way. And of course we’re online, building our community on Facebook and Twitter. Like us, follow us, join us, and we’ll have some great exchanges. (See the links on this page.)

WHAT YOU’RE HELPING TO CREATE

The February workshop of A Pint of Understanding will feature top talent and a skilled crew, and we’ll get the word out through strategic promotion and audience and civic engagement. Along with the goal of creating exciting theater that people want to see, we hope to encourage discussion and foster empathy through online and live forums. 

We have big dreams. The February workshop is the first major milestone toward professional staging and ideally will be presented at a level that will attract a development partner/producer.

The cast consists of nine singer/actors: four in lead roles and five chorus members who play a number of parts. We’re casting performers with a strong command of their craft and exceptional versatility. Production costs include space rental, performer fees, and crew fees over a two-week rehearsal and performance period in late February.

The work has to be documented with video, audio recordings, and still photography to continue promoting the work so that development can move forward.

There’s the less glamorous side of the project involving essentials like marketing and promotion, as well as legal and accounting fees.

We’re building this work page by page, measure by measure. Truly, any amount you can give will help. No contribution is too small.

YOUR IMPACT

It’s personal: If you love music. If you love musicals. If you love theater. If you care about social justice. If you share our values — unity and respect, empathy, beauty, truth and relevance, and hey, a dash of humor — you’ll be adding your voice to this chorus.

It’s societal: Our country’s been grappling with these issues for too long, and we need to find a healthy way to connect, to talk and explore and really see and hear each other. We hope to add something meaningful to that conversation.

Our track record: As a team, we’ve produced two successful developmental readings, each with an engaging, stimulating discussion afterwards. We are grateful to have received funding and in-kind support from the Puffin Foundation, Eastern Bank Foundation, the Bob Jolly Charitable Trust, Emerson College, Tufts University, Berklee College of Music, and Northeastern University, as well as some generous individuals. So we know we can take the project to the next stage — the full workshop in February.

in addition, the credentials and accomplishments of the individual artists on the creative team suggest that this project can be created and produced to the highest standards.

PERKS

Our perks run the gamut. Some are fun, useful items that symbolize your commitment to music, theater and the arts as a path to positive change — like our official A Pint of Understanding pint glasses, our official tote bag, and the Pint of Understanding unity scarf;

Others are mementoes that relate to our February 2015 workshop performance — your very own photo of the cast or perhaps a signed script.

And some are up-close-and-personal: dinner with a member or two of the creative team and schmoozing at an after-party with the Pint team and cast.

As one of our songs goes, “We can lead a sea change.”

But only together.

We hope you’ll get in on the ground floor with A Pint of Understanding, our new musical in development. It’s a great story with incredible music, and it delivers an important message. It’s a project, it’s a community, and it could be a movement to overcome discrimination and live up to the principles on which the United States was founded. Let’s have A Pint of Understanding. Thanks!

(Incidentally, you can choose to give without receiving a perk. Click the red "Contribute Now" button near the top of the page and enter any amount. (You can also contribute more than a designated perk amount.

GIVE, SHARE, SUPPORT

Here's something important: your gift is tax-deductible. A Pint of Understanding: The Professor, the Policeman and the President is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas. Among other advantages to this partnership, Fractured Atlas extends its nonprofit status to us so that your gift will be a write-off. Bonus, right?

When you give, Fractured Atlas will email you a receipt.

So please join us. Here are some ways you can help:

>  Make a contribution: Any amount adds to the mix.

>  Spread the word: You can raise awareness about A Pint of Understanding by sharing news on Facebook, Twitter and wherever else you hang out. Please let others who love the arts and care about equality and social justice know we’re here and ask them to give what they can.  

Thanks for taking the time to support us. We look forward to connecting online and in person! 

The Pint Collaborative


THE TEAM: THE PINT COLLABORATIVE

Our creative team consists of an accomplished, award-winning, and very nice group of artists. 


Joel LaRue Smith, composer

Since 2013, Joel LaRue Smith has served as Cultural Envoy to Central America for the U.S. Embassy and Department of State. A pianist, composer, arranger, producer, and educator, he has toured extensively, performing jazz, classical, gospel and Afro Cuban repertoire throughout the U.S., Europe, Africa, Asia, Central America, and the Caribbean. Joel has performed at Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center, The Whitney Museum, The White House, Symphony Hall in San Francisco and Boston, London’s Royal Albert Hall, and at The Hellenic Music Festival in Athens, as well as at the 2013 and 2011 Costa Rica International Jazz Festival, the 2011 Guatemala International Music Festival, and various noted jazz clubs like the Blue Note, The Village Gate, the Jazz Dock in Prague, and The Blue Frog in Mumbai. He has performed with the New York Philharmonic, The Toledo Symphony, The French National Orchestra, Mario Bauza, Kenny Burrell, Tito Puente, Junior Cook and Wayne Andre. Joel is the recipient of six Meet the Composer grants, a grand prizewinner for the grant in musical composition from the Queens Council for the Arts, and has won ASCAP’s distinguished George and Ira Gershwin Award. In addition, he was the featured pianist in the 2011 Annual John Coltrane Memorial Concert in Boston. His debut CD, September’s Child, featuring seven original Afro-Cuban Jazz compositions, was released in 2008 and received rave international reviews. Joel is planning the release of a new Afro Cuban Jazz compact disc, The Motorman’s Son, and a solo piano CD of classical European music, The Colossus Piano Collection.


Joseph Smith, composer

A composer, arranger, orchestrator, producer, performer, educator, and college administrator, Joe Smith has a broad and diverse musical vocabulary spanning many genres, with professional experience in all. As a composer, arranger, and orchestrator for film and television, he has worked on a range of projects including Star Trek: The Next Generation and Deep Space Nine, National Geographic, Bull Durham, and Missing in Action 3. Joe also served as Dean of the Professional Writing Division at Berklee College of Music for 10 years and was a Professor in the Film Scoring and Contemporary Writing and Production Departments. As a performer on French horn and electric bass, he has played in ensembles ranging from blues bands to symphony orchestras. As a composer and arranger, he has contributed to live and recording projects for such artists as Kenny Loggins and Leni Stern; musical reviews; jazz ensembles; television; films; and studio orchestras. Joe holds a bachelor’s degree in music education from West Virginia University, a professional diploma in arranging and composition from Berklee College of Music, and an M.M. in media writing and production from the University of Miami. He is a member of The Society of Composers & Lyricists, ASCAP, and the Los Angeles Musicians Union. He currently lives in the Berkshires with his wife Christianna Kavaloski (a brilliant and talented ballet teacher) and their dog Henley (a professional foodie).


Lee Phenner, Lyricist/Book Writer

An award-winning writer, Lee Phenner holds an M.F.A. in creative writing from Emerson College, where she received Duprey awards for screenwriting and poetry and was selected for the Ploughshares International Fiction Seminar at Kasteel Well, Netherlands. Her creative works include the screenplay Celia Now and Then, which placed in the MORE Women in Film Screenplay Contest, and "Circle of the First," a choral work co-written with Robert D. Terrio that premiered in 2010. She is a member of the Martin Luther King, Jr. Committee in Arlington, Massachusetts, StageSource and the Small Theatre Alliance of Boston, and is an associate member of the Dramatists Guild of America.


Benny Sato Ambush, director

Benny Sato Ambush is a professional SDC stage director, former producer/artistic director of professional theaters, educator, consultant and published commentator. Currently, he is Senior Distinguished Producing Director-In-Residence, Emerson College's Emerson Stage and serves on the acting and directing faculty of Emerson College's Department of Performing Arts. He has a B.A. from Brown University and an M.F.A. from the University of California, San Diego. Prior artistic leadership experience includes: Producing Director, Oakland Ensemble Theatre and Producing Artistic Director, Richmond, VA's LORT C TheatreVirginia (one of only 14 people of color to have ever been Artistic Director of a LORT Theatre). He was Associate Artistic Director of Anna Deavere Smith's Institute on the Arts & Civic Dialogue at Harvard University, summer 2000. His many directing credits include: Old Globe Theatre; Geva Theatre; American Conservatory Theater; Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Portland; Playwrights Horizons; Ford's Theatre; South Coast Rep; Lyric Stage Company of Boston; A.R.T. Institute. Benny is a double IRNE Award Winner (Best Director -  Midsize Theater and Best Production - Midsize Theater) for “Master Harold”…and the Boys at Gloucester Stage Company, summer 2012. He is active nationally in the advocacy of cultural equity, non-traditional casting and pluralism in the American theater.


Scott Nicholas, music director

​Scott Nicholas is an accomplished pianist who has appeared throughout the U.S. and internationally in solo and chamber performances and has served as the rehearsal and performance pianist for groups and events including the Tanglewood Festival Chorus, the Borromeo String Quartet, the Boston Pops, Minnesota Opera, and E.C. Schirmer's Philovox Ensemble. He has accompanied such preeminent singers as Nancy Armstrong, Robert Honeysucker, and Jessica Cooper, and is featured on a CD of new works by Graham Gordon Ramsay. He has served as music director for the New England Conservatory Opera Workshop and Suffolk University. Scott holds a B.A. in music education from The College of New Jersey and an M.M. in accompanying/coaching from the New England Conservatory.

ABOUT THE VIDEO

All credit and our deepest thanks where they're due: our Indiegogo video was produced by Kat Baker and Joe Wrinn, edited by Kat Baker. Intro music by Terry Vital of terryvitalmusic.com. We got a major assist from Joe Smith. Video footage of A Pint of Understanding by Joe Wrinn and Mary Dean Taylor.

CONTACT US

You can reach us on our social media pages (see the links on this page) or directly at info@pintmusical.com. We'd love to hear your questions, comments, and suggestions.
story_txt:
ABOUT THE SHOW

So glad you’re here! We’re creating a new musical — a creative, positive approach to an issue that divides us all too often. Our work has been called fresh, sensitive, and entertaining, and we hope you'll want to lend your thoughts and your support. The show is called A Pint of Understanding:
The Professor, the Policeman and the President, and it all started with a
true story. Remember the controversial arrest of a famous African American
professor by a white police officer? The media ran away with the story, and that led to the “Beer Summit” with President Obama at the White
House. The whole thing got intense very quickly, and almost as quickly, it was
swept under the rug. 
And then Trayvon Martin and Eric Garner; Donald Sterling and Ferguson…
and here we are, one nation, indivisible ... ? Our team, the Pint Collaborative, felt we had to do something, and for us,
that meant writing a musical. (What? More on that and the team in a minute.) Everything
we’ve learned from working together during the last 18 months has made clear
that most of us Americans — most of us humans — want the same things. We
want harmony. Respect. Change for the better. (To love and be loved. The list goes on.)
We believe A Pint of
Understanding is an important work, a rejection of this painful divide, a
revolt against complacency, a creative and positive contribution to the
progress our country can make — if we all insist on it. 
And we think
it’s a really great show. Creatively, A Pint of Understanding might feel both familiar and adventurous to you. It’s an experiment in hybridity: It makes the most of the power and immediacy of live theater, but it also feels like a movie. The music has a jazz sensibility, but a number of genres come into play — blues, rhumba, gospel, R&B and hip hop, to name a few. And ultimately, the show will make use of projections and multimedia to depict the influence of the media on society.
The Pint of Understanding family includes an extended group of people who are passionate about
bringing this musical to life. They have generously given their time, talent,
and resources to help us get us to the point where we can produce a workshop
this February in Boston. We’re talking about the complete work — all the music
and a revised book (the play) based on feedback we’ve gotten from two previous developmental
readings and performances. We’ve been doing this independently, but now it’s
getting real, the stakes are higher, and we’re ready to take it to the next
level. But we can’t make it happen without you. We need your help and we hope you’ll join with us.
The dubious arrest of the Professor Henry Louis Gates, Jr. was the inspiration for our story
— but A Pint of Understanding is a work of fiction. It ventures off and explores
the issues broadly, imagining how things might have gone if the
president had appointed the professor and the police officer to work together. We
bring all points of view into focus and introduce characters we hope you’ll
come to love. Plus, they can sing!
Our story offers a few twists that we think you’ll enjoy, some points
to reflect on, and — believe it or not — a lot of laughs. As Chekov said, "Tragedy is about the difficult. Comedy is about the unbearable.” In
other words, comic relief gives us some room to breathe and the opportunity to
laugh at ourselves and then … get back to it.
Our creative team, “The Pint Collaborative,” consists of not one but two
composers, Joel LaRue Smith and Joseph Smith, lyricist/book writer Lee Phenner, director
Benny Sato Ambush, and music director Scott Nicholas. In a sense, our diverse
backgrounds and experiences actually bring to life the central messages of A Pint of Understanding. We did that on
purpose. You can learn more about us below.
A forum for discussion: When we say we’re inviting you in, we
really mean it. The February 2015 workshop will feature a post-performance
discussion where the audience, cast and an expert in cultural studies will
discuss their views in an open and constructive way. And of course we’re
online, building our community on Facebook and Twitter. Like us,
follow us, join us, and we’ll have some great exchanges. (See the links on this page.)
WHAT YOU’RE
HELPING TO CREATE
The February workshop of A Pint of Understanding will feature top talent and a skilled crew, and
we’ll get the word out through strategic promotion and audience and civic engagement. Along
with the goal of creating exciting theater that people want to see, we hope to encourage
discussion and foster empathy through online and live forums. We have big dreams. The February workshop is the first major milestone toward professional staging and
ideally will be presented at a level that will attract a development
partner/producer.
The cast consists of
nine singer/actors: four in lead roles and five chorus members who play a
number of parts. We’re casting performers with a strong command of their craft
and exceptional versatility. Production costs include space rental, performer
fees, and crew fees over a two-week rehearsal and performance period in late
February.
The work has to be
documented with video, audio recordings, and still photography to continue promoting the work so that development can move forward.
There’s the less
glamorous side of the project involving essentials like marketing and
promotion, as well as legal and accounting fees.
We’re building this work page by page, measure by
measure. Truly, any amount you can give will help. No contribution is too
small.YOUR IMPACT
It’s personal: If you love music. If you love musicals. If you love theater. If you
care about social justice. If you share our values — unity and respect, empathy, beauty, truth and relevance, and hey, a dash of humor —
you’ll be adding your voice to this chorus.
It’s societal: Our country’s
been grappling with these issues for too long, and we need to find a healthy
way to connect, to talk and explore and really see and hear each other. We hope to add something meaningful to that conversation.
Our track record: As a team,
we’ve produced two successful developmental readings, each with an engaging,
stimulating discussion afterwards. We are grateful to have received funding and
in-kind support from the Puffin Foundation, Eastern Bank Foundation, the Bob
Jolly Charitable Trust, Emerson College, Tufts University, Berklee College of
Music, and Northeastern University, as well as some generous individuals. So we
know we can take the project to the next stage — the full workshop in February.
in addition, the credentials and accomplishments of the individual artists
on the creative team suggest that this project can be created and
produced to the highest standards. 
PERKS
Our perks run the gamut. Some are fun, useful items that symbolize your
commitment to music, theater and the arts as a path to positive change — like our official A Pint of Understanding pint glasses, our official tote bag, and the Pint of Understanding unity scarf;
Others are mementoes that relate to our February 2015 workshop
performance — your very own photo of the cast or perhaps a signed script.
And some are up-close-and-personal: dinner with a member or two of the
creative team and schmoozing at an after-party with the Pint team and cast. As one of our songs goes, “We can lead a sea change.”But only together.We hope you’ll get in on the ground floor with A Pint of Understanding, our new musical in development. It’s a great story with incredible music, and it delivers an important message. It’s a project, it’s a community, and it could be a movement to overcome discrimination and live up to the principles on which the United States was founded. Let’s have A Pint of Understanding. Thanks!(Incidentally, you can choose to give without receiving a perk. Click the red "Contribute Now" button near the top of the page and enter any amount. (You can also contribute more than a designated perk amount.
GIVE, SHARE, SUPPORT
Here's something important: your gift is tax-deductible. A Pint of Understanding: The Professor, the Policeman and the President is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas. Among other advantages to this partnership, Fractured Atlas extends its nonprofit status to us so that your gift will be a write-off. Bonus, right?When you give, Fractured Atlas will email you a receipt.So please join us. Here are some ways you can help:
>  Make a contribution: Any
amount adds to the mix.
>  Spread the word: You can raise awareness about
A Pint of Understanding by sharing news on Facebook, Twitter and wherever else you hang out. Please let others who love the arts and care about equality and social justice
know we’re here and ask them to give what they can.  

Thanks for taking the time to support us. We look
forward to connecting online and in person! The Pint CollaborativeTHE TEAM: THE PINT COLLABORATIVEOur creative team consists of an accomplished, award-winning, and very nice group of artists. 
Joel LaRue Smith, composerSince 2013, Joel LaRue Smith has served as Cultural Envoy to Central America for the U.S. Embassy and Department of State. A pianist, composer, arranger, producer, and educator, he has toured extensively, performing jazz, classical, gospel and Afro Cuban repertoire throughout the U.S., Europe, Africa, Asia, Central America, and the Caribbean. Joel has performed at Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center, The Whitney Museum, The White House, Symphony Hall in San Francisco and Boston, London’s Royal Albert Hall, and at The Hellenic Music Festival in Athens, as well as at the 2013 and 2011 Costa Rica International Jazz Festival, the 2011 Guatemala International Music Festival, and various noted jazz clubs like the Blue Note, The Village Gate, the Jazz Dock in Prague, and The Blue Frog in Mumbai. He has performed with the New York Philharmonic, The Toledo Symphony, The French National Orchestra, Mario Bauza, Kenny Burrell, Tito Puente, Junior Cook and Wayne Andre. Joel is the recipient of six Meet the Composer grants, a grand prizewinner for the grant in musical composition from the Queens Council for the Arts, and has won ASCAP’s distinguished George and Ira Gershwin Award. In addition, he was the featured pianist in the 2011 Annual John Coltrane Memorial Concert in Boston. His debut CD, September’s Child, featuring seven original Afro-Cuban Jazz compositions, was released in 2008 and received rave international reviews. Joel is planning the release of a new Afro Cuban Jazz compact disc, The Motorman’s Son, and a solo piano CD of classical European music, The Colossus Piano Collection.
Joseph Smith, composerA composer, arranger, orchestrator, producer, performer, educator, and college administrator, Joe Smith has a broad and diverse musical vocabulary spanning many genres, with professional experience in all. As a composer, arranger, and orchestrator for film and television, he has worked on a range of projects including Star Trek: The Next Generation and Deep Space Nine, National Geographic, Bull Durham, and Missing in Action 3. Joe also served as Dean of the Professional Writing Division at Berklee College of Music for 10 years and was a Professor in the Film Scoring and Contemporary Writing and Production Departments. As a performer on French horn and electric bass, he has played in ensembles ranging from blues bands to symphony orchestras. As a composer and arranger, he has contributed to live and recording projects for such artists as Kenny Loggins and Leni Stern; musical reviews; jazz ensembles; television; films; and studio orchestras. Joe holds a bachelor’s degree in music education from West Virginia University, a professional diploma in arranging and composition from Berklee College of Music, and an M.M. in media writing and production from the University of Miami. He is a member of The Society of Composers & Lyricists, ASCAP, and the Los Angeles Musicians Union. He currently lives in the Berkshires with his wife Christianna Kavaloski (a brilliant and talented ballet teacher) and their dog Henley (a professional foodie).
Lee Phenner, Lyricist/Book WriterAn award-winning writer, Lee Phenner holds an M.F.A. in creative writing from Emerson College, where she received Duprey awards for screenwriting and poetry and was selected for the Ploughshares International Fiction Seminar at Kasteel Well, Netherlands. Her creative works include the screenplay Celia Now and Then, which placed in the MORE Women in Film Screenplay Contest, and "Circle of the First," a choral work co-written with Robert D. Terrio that premiered in 2010. She is a member of the Martin Luther King, Jr. Committee in Arlington, Massachusetts, StageSource and the Small Theatre Alliance of Boston, and is an associate member of the Dramatists Guild of America.
Benny Sato Ambush, director
Benny Sato Ambush is a professional SDC stage director, former producer/artistic director of professional theaters, educator, consultant and published commentator. Currently, he is Senior Distinguished Producing Director-In-Residence, Emerson College's Emerson Stage and serves on the acting and directing faculty of Emerson College's Department of Performing Arts. He has a B.A. from Brown University and an M.F.A. from the University of California, San Diego. Prior artistic leadership experience includes: Producing Director, Oakland Ensemble Theatre and Producing Artistic Director, Richmond, VA's LORT C TheatreVirginia (one of only 14 people of color to have ever been Artistic Director of a LORT Theatre). He was Associate Artistic Director of Anna Deavere Smith's Institute on the Arts & Civic Dialogue at Harvard University, summer 2000. His many directing credits include: Old Globe Theatre; Geva Theatre; American Conservatory Theater; Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Portland; Playwrights Horizons; Ford's Theatre; South Coast Rep; Lyric Stage Company of Boston; A.R.T. Institute. Benny is a double IRNE Award Winner (Best Director -  Midsize Theater and Best Production - Midsize Theater) for “Master Harold”…and the Boys at Gloucester Stage Company, summer 2012. He is active nationally in the advocacy of cultural equity, non-traditional casting and pluralism in the American theater.

Scott Nicholas, music director
​Scott Nicholas is an accomplished pianist who has appeared throughout the U.S. and internationally in solo and chamber performances and has served as the rehearsal and performance pianist for groups and events including the Tanglewood Festival Chorus, the Borromeo String Quartet, the Boston Pops, Minnesota Opera, and E.C. Schirmer's Philovox Ensemble. He has accompanied such preeminent singers as Nancy Armstrong, Robert Honeysucker, and Jessica Cooper, and is featured on a CD of new works by Graham Gordon Ramsay. He has served as music director for the New England Conservatory Opera Workshop and Suffolk University. Scott holds a B.A. in music education from The College of New Jersey and an M.M. in accompanying/coaching from the New England Conservatory.ABOUT THE VIDEOAll credit and our deepest thanks where they're due: our Indiegogo video was produced by Kat Baker and Joe Wrinn, edited by Kat Baker. story:
Mordine & Company Dance Theater is engaged in COLLISIONS, a multi-year project that addresses ideas of immediate impact on our lives; tensions between generations, cultures, and climatic changes. It seeks to reveal the value and experience of what the aging performer and dancer bring to the audience. This project is a culmination of the depth, history, invention, teaching, and collaborations that Shirley Mordine has experienced in her years as Artistic Director. The project includes a duet composed and performed by Hema Rajagopalan and Mordine to contrast aging dancers from different cultural traditions; a work choreographed by the Company dancers and set on Mordine to examine the role of age in relation to teaching, learning, voice and author; a work composed by puppeteer Michael Montenegro that will pair Mordine with a life-size puppet operated by two dancers; and a piece for five dancers that focuses on the evolution and changes of natural elements as witnessed in nature. An additional component of this project is a public conversation series that will explore these topics with a wider audience. 

UPDATE: The April 2016 performances of COLLISIONS at Links Hall Constellations have been postponed at this time. The project will continue with showings and performances scheduled for future dates over the 2016-17 season. 

ARTISTS:  Director: Shirley Mordine; Collaborators: Michael Montenegro, Hema Rajagopalan, and Mordine & Co. Dancers: Danielle Gilmore, John Jandernoa, Melissa Pillarella, Emily Stepleton, Rachel Vogeney; Lighting Design: Josh Weckesser

Consultant: Beth Corning, Artistic Director of CORNINGWORKS in Pittsburg. Beth presents multiple productions annually in Pittsburgh including THE GLUE FACTORY, productions created on nationally and internationally recognized performing artists over the age of 45.

YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL HELP SUPPORT: 

*Dancer pay

*Space Rental

*Production costs 

        __________________________________________________________________

ABOUT THE COMPANY: Mordine & Company Dance Theater has played a seminal role in establishing and advancing the contemporary dance scene in Chicago for the past 47 years. The Company creates new choreography, collaborates with distinguished guest artists, and mentors young dancers and choreographers. Recognized for its distinct approach to choreography rooted in theatre and dance, Mordine & Company is committed to expanding the possibilities for contemporary dance through the revelation of story, deeply felt kinetic and visual images, and sophisticated performance. The Company’s work explores how the use of metaphor connects individuals to the global community. 

In 1969, Shirley Mordine established the Dance Center of Columbia College Chicago to provide a base from which the art form could grow, an opportunity for young artists to evolve, a base for her company, and a platform for presenting local, national, and international companies in Chicago. Mordine served as Chair of the Department and Director of the Dance Center until 1999. During her tenure she helped to develop the artistic and teaching voices of  generations of artists who are now working locally and nationally. 

Under the direction of Shirley Mordine, Mordine & Co. Dance Theater has produced works whose coalition of choreography and theatre has won critical acclaim. Praised for original choreography combining wit and sheer movement with technical sophistication, Mordine is renowned for her craftsmanship. As stated by the Chicago Reader, “Her canny manipulation of the raw material of dance - sheer movement of space and time - knows no peer." Over the years, Mordine & Company has had the honor to work with a number of illustrious collaborators from diverse artistic disciplines, including choreographers Miguel Mancillas, Ishmael Houston-Jones and Hema Rajagopalan; composers Tatsu Aoki, Henry Threadgill, Shawn Decker, Richard Woodbury, David Pavkovic, and Peter Ferry; visual designers John Boesche and Ken Bowen; puppeteer Michael Montenegro; and video artist Miroslaw Rogala. The Company has consistently created new work and collaborated with artists from different genres to examine and explore current events.

story:
What We Are Doing

This spring, Entropy Theatre will proudly present its inaugural production of a grimm thing, an original queer epic that re-imagines popular and lesser known stories from the Grimms’ Fairy Tales.

This new work centers on beloved sweets-loving Gretel and her journey from stock fairy tale character to woke badass capable of writing her own story, thank you very much. In an evening hosted by Gretel's self-appointed guardian, a witch called Frau Trude, audiences will journey from familiar places inhabited by needy frog princes and childhood disobedience to unfamiliar places with fur disguises, a fat-sipping cat, and a sausage that cooks (seriously). Bring your sweet tooth!

 

Who We Are

a  grimm thing was originally conceived by Entropy Theatre’s founding Co-Artistic Directors, Joe Juknievich and Kayleigh Kane, whose recent collaborative directing and acting credits include All My Sons (Praxis Stage), Jesus Christ Superstar (Firehouse Center for the Arts), and the IRNE-nominated world-premiere of James Wilkinson’s Nurse Play (Exiled Theatre). In addition to his aforementioned directing credits, Joe worked as the Artistic Fellow at SpeakEasy Stage Company for the duration of their 2017-2018 season, where he directed Gary Garrison’s Game One for Boston Theatre Marathon XX and assisted Paul Daigneault on his production of Allegiance: The Musical. Kayleigh has also recently worked as a choreographer for the Freelance Players, and has coached performers in intimacy, character movement, and physical storytelling for various projects at ImprovBoston, Arts at the Armory, and Gann Academy.

 

How You Can Help

We have budgeted out the full cost of the production to be about $3,500. This number includes the cost of renting rehearsal and performance spaces, acquiring costumes, props, and tech equipment, and paying all of our actors and directors/choreographers. We are hoping to use a combination of crowdsourcing, grant money, and ticket sales to fund the production. We will use anything we raise to help cover the costs mentioned above, with our first priority being compensating the efforts of our artists.  

If you're unable to make a donation at this time, please spread the word about the campaign and the show, as word-of-mouth is our greatest marketing tool! 

 

Why We're Doing It

Entropy Theatre produces bold theatrical experiences that entertain and meaningfully engage its audiences on a cerebral and emotional level. We foster a safe creative atmosphere where the possibilities of theatre can be tested, thereby advancing the art form and bolstering our audiences’ imaginative capacity, sense of humanity, and compassion for one another in a trustful and respectful manner. We also work with diverse artistic voices and emphasize theatrical elements such as movement, ensemble-building, process, artistic authorship, and the audience-performer relationship. To this end, we aim to create work that promotes both audience inclusivity and open-hearted artistic collaboration.

story:
Short Summary

June 15-July 1st. Just 9 shows in June, help us get those performances up on stage. This play can't happen without you, we'd love for you to be a part. IN THE SEATS or IN THE PROGRAM AS A SUPPORTER:

  • Scott and Zach, longtime friends, have been acting and living in LA well over a decade.
  • The A STEADY RAIN team wants to bring challenging and engaging work to the community.
  • Your pre-sold ticket purchases & donations literally bring the production to the stage.

What We Need & What You Get  ( see PERKS ---->  )

  • We need to rent the space and hire the technicians.
  • That means paying for a lighting designer, equipment, and operation.
  • Additional time in the theater before we open to program lights, sound etc.
  • (SEE FULL BUDGET BELOW)

    (ASR Koozie)

The Impact

Now more than ever is the time to Support the Arts. This play begins the discussion on many relevant topics.

  • Police protocol
  • Racism
  • Family, Friendship

Can you join us?

If you can donate, you'll be helping get this masterfully written story in front of audiences.

  • You can click BACK IT (top right) and decide whatever sum you see fit to support the play
  • Or pre-order a ticket and get a perk.

 

PERKS

Lots of fun perks, check them all out on the right  ----------------------------->

Choose from tickets to the play, poems or letters, a unique ASR drink koozie, delivered dinner for two, a facial, photo prints, discount from Hemingway and Sons, and much more:

 

 

Here's artist Lindsay Minnich's postcard artwork selections to choose from:

 

 

Budget breakdown

 

As production nears our budget will push us over the $5,000 mark, but we want to try and keep our number as low as possible with the crowdfund so we can reach our goal and we'll try and make up for the difference later on. We really appreciate your consideration and support of the project and hope to see you at the theater and/or on the donation page! Many thanks!!

See detailed budget below:

 

Do get a hold of us if you have questions/comments:

aSteadyRainSilverlake@gmail.com

  • thank you!
  • see you at the theater!

And that's all there is to it. T H A N K Y O U !!!!!

 

Additional Perk info:

 

Get 10% online or in the store at Hemingway and Sons http://shophemingway.com/

 

Hydrofacial in Marina Del Rey (retail value $175)

 

George Byrne Print

George Byrne’s L.A series ‘Local Division’ resonates with a quiet, deductive intensity. Borrowing from the clean, vivid clarity of modernist painting, Byrne also references the New Topographics photography movement via a subject matter firmly entrenched in the urban everyday. Byrne’s oeuvre is to spin L.A.’s most disposable architecture and redundant landscapes into seismic moments. He seeks the subliminal and sublime in the everyday.

Come have homemade dinner with us !!

 

 

THANK YOU FOR SUPPORTING AND BEING A PART OF "A STEADY RAIN" :-)

story:
Hi everyone! This is Matt Sternberg, producer of Jeff Goode's The Eight: Reindeer Monologues. I've wanted to put this show up for a long time and I'm finally able to make this dream come to life. So, I need your help.

What your contribution will mean:

Your donations will mean that we can afford the following costs:

Theater rental, rehearsal space, set dressings, marketing, costumes, and a whole lot of thank yous from our company of artists that want to bring you something stimulating and awesome.

We have these amazing perks (some handmade and some not) from our team of designers and artists. These perks are something personal that you can hang on to and as the PSA video says, help these reindeer shine bright.  

The Impact:

This show was written in 1993 and its themes are more relevant now than ever!  As the description above says: Santa's eight reindeer speak out about his "un-Christmas" like behavior and hold nothing back. Funny and touching, this show is a site to behold. This Jew is for You Production Company is doing something different and visually fantastic to set us apart. 

I started this grassroots production company with these artists and actors to give our talent a platform to thrive. This is our first production and it's our introduction to the world. We want to continue with future projects and trust that you can help us make that happen. Most production companies need to start somewhere and the time for us is right now!

Other Ways You Can Help:

We understand if you can't contribute; however, please SHARE, SHARE, SHARE (via social media) the love and what we stand for and get the word out there about our little band of artists! That's one of the best gifts you can give us. Thank you!

story:
PWR Presents: WASSAILMANIA

Party World Rasslin' is Austin, Texas's huge, invulnerable beacon of Ultimate Party Violence and Total Party Excess. It is a unique and miraculous spectacle celebrating friendship, beer, lore, and wrestling. Last time we gathered, we watched in mute horror as a Highland Park, Dallas-based oilman played dirty and one-upped a beloved community organizer in a display that put the “rudge” in “grudge match.” But that’s not where his reign ends… Nothing ever ends… it is time to return to the font of MAXIMUM PARTY VENGEANCE!

 

WINTER WONDERSLAM VI

 

It’s cold time! The cold world approaches! Imagine… A great and friendly log, set ablaze with kindness... Cocoa, pronounced with three syllables… Snow for dogs to play in… Chompis in his tattered bathrobe… it’s “WINTERMAS”! A perfect time to return to the ancient custom of visiting breweries in beer-producing regions of Austin, reciting incantations and singing to the trees to promote a good harvest for the coming year. Wow! This is… WASSAILMANIA!

We'll be transforming 4th Tap Brewing Co-op (10615 Metric Blvd, Austin, TX) into haunted chillscape, complete with gleaming lights, cold nights, wintry frights, and gourds of all shapes and sizes. Here, at 6:30pm on December 7th, PWR's epic PARTY COMBAT will be waged once more. Will our bowl be crowned with lambswool, or will we be made a damnfool? Will our Partyweight Champion, Big Daddy Bolero, be bested in the name of holiday decency, or will his reign of hot terror ruin another family get-together? This crucial spectacle will be illuminated with a full professional lighting system, shout with a clear and juicy sound system, and broadcast on 3 screens and beyond with a sweet 3-camera video setup! Wow

It wasn't always like this, though. Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—this thing has become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. In 5 years we've gone from a handful of people messing around in a homemade ring to the glorious spectacle we know today.  We continue to do a safer-space DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us. The show remains FREE TO ATTEND, even as we mount mammoth costs.

 

THE STORY SO FAR

 

At GHOST MALL, the ghost of a mall, we picked our collective jaw off the beer-spill’t ground as Dallas magnate BIG DADDY BOLERO, assisted by coffee pervert RALF MACCHIATO, handcuffed ALEXANDRA CAGE to the ring and retained the PARTYWEIGHT CHAMPIONSHIP BELT. 

The ambitious and towering BDB remains shielded from interference by the Mother Worm, and can pursue his goal of total domination and utter development of the Multiverse. That’s sour news! But can he bulldoze and jack up the price of… holiday cheer itself? He intends to find out!

Only one person… one nymph… stands between Big Daddy and his big scheme: SWEETIE TUFF! They watched their beloved CRYBABY die away at the hands of a cyber-assassin Bolero hired, and now they’re thirsty for two things: Apple wassail, and revenge!

Gather round the yule log and gaze into the fire… this combat is going to be hot!

FULL CRIMBO CHEER awaits: as the usual PARTY ATHLETES explore the universe of story: Luigi Primo, Bull DeCroix, The Dumpster Babes, Sweetie Tuff, Dock Master, Pastaman, Bench Horse, The Valkyries Ralph Machiatto, Sprida , Arbitro Obscuro, Hot Dog, and MORE!

 

What is this money used for?

 

$6000 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR's quarterly Austin shows are free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on one of the largest free events in Texas. Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spend north of $10,000 on each of our shows.

We diligently budget and carefully save so that we can ask for an amount that is sustainable. We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; our rigorous planning -- combined with your support -- have allowed us to do this without our costs ballooning to a hellish degree! It's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than five years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT

Some of the cool things your donations will help us do include:

Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a mall horizon at our last show! This time, we're turning the brewery into an incredible gourd frenzy! Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

Air Conditioning. Not a concern this show!

Paying artists. We work hard to make sure everyone who contributes to our production gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our A/V crew.

Safer space/security. PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

Projection and lighting. PWR has some of the most advanced lighting for an independent wrestling show in the country! And we built it ourselves, with your help. We always have tweaks to make to reach towards our goal of TV-quality lighting. If you saw our lights at the last show, you know how shockingly powerful our latest generation is! Also, our projection system allows people to watch the show from 3 different places in the venue, each with different sitting and standing options! Plus, we now STREAM our shows over twitch, and your support helps us improve the quality of it.

Training. Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  

Profit split. after we cover all our costs, we take 20% of our profits and reinvest it in PWR. We split up whatever is left among performers and staff who worked on the show.

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a big chunk of them. Below is our complete operational budget.

Show Expenses: $2115.00:

Art Supplies: $400.00

Equipment Rental and Accessories (AC units, Video/Sound, Generators, etc): $250

Construction Supplies: $50

Insurance: $455.00

Performer Assistance Fund: $200.00

Ring/Facilities Maintenance: $175.00

Office Supplies: $30.00

Props/Costume: $75.00

Security Phone: $60.00

Transportation: $350.00

Service Subscriptions: $70

Operational Expenses: $4470:

Artist and Staff Pay: $4070

New Projects Capital: $400.00

Indiegogo Reward production and fulfillment: $2912

Indiegogo and credit card fees: $548.709


Extremely Hype Swag

As always, your donation comes with a cool perk! Check out this incredible design by Nat Bradford, available in 2 fabric colors as a t-shirt or a sweatshirt!



How about Sweat...PANTS!


And hey, PWR candles are BACK! You can get these grey-black ones with the DRAGON BLOOD scent!



Or, GREEN-hued candles scented of CHRISTMAS THYME (pics forthcoming!)

Risks and Challenges

 

As PWR continues its evolution from backyard party to professional art-collective, we never want to lose the heart of partying and stupidness that makes it good. We aim to balance a relentless work ethic with a light touch and and inviting environment for our attendants, volunteers and staff. It's hard wrangling 80 people to put on a huge free show, but knowing others will join us to reap the rewards makes it worth it one million times. Rest assured we're working tirelessly to have the time of our lives on December 7th! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and WASSAILMANIA!

Here is the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/400645253943039/

HMW

story:
re: LET ME IN

Who is LMI?

  • LET ME IN is a theatre company run by Justine Christensen and Patrick J. Horan.

  • The company began three years ago in theatre school, when Justine and Patrick discovered a mutual obsession with the artistic possibilities of adaptation. This came about after working together on a year-long "found text" project that forced them to look at classical work in a new way. 

  • Since then, LMI has been interested in producing impulsive work that disrupts perceptions of gender in classical and contemporary theatre. LMI’s projects are fuelled by appropriating "classical" works and thrusting them into a contemporary theatrical landscape by remixing, altering, satirizing, and breaking old plays.
     

What We Need 

Here we are, doing the Fringe again! We are so excited about this show. We're sure you will be, too.

  • We are looking to raise $2000.  Not a lot of money, but trust us, it would make a world of difference. Scroll down for a more detailed breakdown of what we need this money for. 
     
  • The Fringe Festival is the most exciting Toronto theatre event of the year!
    We're here to contribute a quality piece to this year's festival - at the historic
    Tarragon Theatre Mainspace no less. 
     
  • We hope to reach our fundraising goal. But no matter how much we raise, it will be an enormous help in supporting the final phase of bringing this show to the public. 
     

The Impact

  • 'The Bird Killer' is LMI’s next step towards acting on our mandate of making funny, socially conscious, fast-paced theatre for a 21st century audience. Banking on audiences’ potential familiarity with this classic work, met with our own brand of modern “meta”, we have adapted a favourite of the theatre canon to make a fresh piece of contemporary theatre.

  • Last year's The Miserable Worm (Annex Theatre) was our Fringe debut. The show was well-received, fulfilling for us and our audiences alike, and was met with much praise and support. 
    As emerging producers and theatre-creators, this is Justine and Patrick's second larger scale-production - a big step in their careers, and a chance to give opportunity to talented up-and-coming Toronto actors.
     

Risks & Challenges

This is only our second show! Though we were granted an OAC Recommender's Grant from Pat The Dog Theatre Creation, funds are scarce for emerging theatre-makers. 

  • We want to pay our team. Your money goes towards supporting artists who are doing high-quality, socially-concious, skilled work. We appreciate that your donation can help make that work possible.
  • Other expenses: 
    -Rehearsal space
    -Promotional materials
    -Transportation 
    -Set, props, and costumes
  • We're an innovative bunch that can make magic on a dime. But your donation allows our work to grow and improve, knowing that ticket sales, grants, and in-kind donations are not our only means of generating revenue and salaries for our team. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Attend this show! You'll have a ton of fun, and probably have lots of feeling too. 
We would love to see you there!

  • On sale now!  TICKETS:​  https://fringetoronto.com/festivals/fringe/even...
  • Follow LET ME IN on FB: https://www.facebook.com/LetMeInTheatre/
  • While you're on FB, hit "Going" on our event: https://www.facebook.com/events/979608902220470...

Thanks for your support.
-LMI

The Impact

'The Bird Killer' is LMI’s next step towards acting on our mandate of making funny, socially conscious, fast-paced theatre for a 21st century audience. Banking on audiences’ potential familiarity with this classic work, met with our own brand of modern “meta”, we have adapted a favourite of the theatre canon to make a fresh piece of contemporary theatre.
Last year's The Miserable Worm (Annex Theatre) was our Fringe debut. The show was well-received, fulfilling for us and our audiences alike, and was met with much praise and support. As emerging producers and theatre-creators, this is Justine and Patrick's second larger scale-production - a big step in their careers, and a chance to give opportunity to talented up-and-coming Toronto actors. 


Risks & Challenges
This is only our second show! Though we were granted an OAC Recommender's Grant from Pat The Dog Theatre Creation, funds are scarce for emerging theatre-makers. 


We want to pay our team. Your money goes towards supporting artists who are doing high-quality, socially-concious, skilled work. We appreciate that your donation can help make that work possible.

Other expenses: -Rehearsal space-Promotional materials-Transportation -Set, props, and costumes
We're an innovative bunch that can make magic on a dime. But your donation allows our work to grow and improve, knowing that ticket sales, grants, and in-kind donations are not our only means of generating revenue and salaries for our team. 


Other Ways You Can Help
Attend this show! You'll have a ton of fun, and probably have lots of feeling too. We would love to see you there!


On sale now!  TICKETS:​  https://fringetoronto.com/festivals/fringe/even...

Follow LET ME IN on FB: https://www.facebook.com/LetMeInTheatre/

While you're on FB, hit "Going" on our event: https://www.facebook.com/events/979608902220470...


Thanks for your support.-LMI

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing

TYA Professional Training Program provides high-quality professional musical theatre training to young artists while producing award-winning and cutting-edge theatre. We also have a strong history of producing area premieres, and this season is no different.  This January, TYA Professional Training Program will produce the area premiere of new American musical, Hands on a Hardbody. Based on a documentary film of the same name, the show follows ten contestants in a competition at a local car dealership who compete to win a Nissan hardbody pickup truck. The last contestant who has his or her hands on the truck wins it. Throughout the musical, the audience learns the background of the characters in the competition.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

The central set piece (and a character in the play in its own right) for Hands on a Hardbody is a pickup truck. That’s right—we have to get a pickup truck on our stage to tell this story. We’ve already located the perfect truck, which is perfectly outfitted to be in the show. Now we just need the funds to purchase it and get it here. We remain committed to providing a theatrical education to any student accepted into TYA, and we don’t raise tuition when production costs like pickup trucks find their way into a budget for a show we’re producing. It does mean that we need to get creative with getting it here, and that’s why we’re turning to you. Please consider supporting this campaign to get TYA’s hands on this hardbody truck.

We're aiming to raise at least $2,500 to cover the cost to purchase, transport, and install the truck in our space.  We have some great perks to reward those of you who would like to support this project. Bring home a piece of #TYAHandsOn memorabilia like a limited edition t-shirt or trucker hat OR make a lasting memory with a pre-show photo opportunity in the passenger seat of the truck and front row seats to this exciting area premiere.

The Impact

Funding this project will ensure that we are able to continue to provide a well-rounded theatrical education to advanced theatre students. In addition to working with professional directors and designers to produce high-quality, professional, cutting edge theatre, our students also learn character development and arts management skills through work on dramaturgy projects and marketing teams. By bringing this truck to our stage through this crowdfunding campaign, we can make sure that all tuition these students pay continues to go directly to the education they receive rather than to  the expenses of the production. 

Risks & Challenges

We have tackled many theatrical challenges over the course of several seasons of cutting edge theatre with TYA professional training program. These include:

  • Building a chic NYC restaurant on stage for First Date

     
  • Thrilling tumbling and stunts in Bring It On

     
  • Blowing up a high school gym in Carrie: the Musical

     
  • Magic and illusions live on stage with Ghost the Musical
  • Building a revolve for Les Miserables... and so many more!

There are inherent risks in creating theatre, but we've navigated through many and are confident in our abilities to execute another challenging piece of live theatre. We are fortunate to have found a truck that has already been outfitted for a production of this title. Our largest obstacle right now is the cost to bring it here. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in a position to contribute right now, there are still ways for you to help!

  • Share this campaign. You never know who you know that might be interested in contributing to this project. Use Indiegogo's share tools on this page to easily spread the word.
  • Get a ticket and come out to see the show. These kids will be ready for an audience this January! Tickets are on sale December 1st at http://dramalearningcenter.com/tya-teen-professionals.

Williams Theatre Group d/b/a Drama Learning Center is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Williams Theatre Group must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I'm Val Dunn and I'm gathering my community to drink beer, express rage, and hex Mike Pence. The play's called Now More Than Ever; it's a dark comedy about our commitment to rage and ineffectual activism. Come join us in a secret West Philly attic hideout where we've kidnapped the vice president and America is magically fixed! Maura Krause is directing this jawn featuring the work of Zandra Espinoza, Alison Ormsby, Minou Pourshariati, Sara Outing, Eliana Fabiyi, & more. I'm not saying this play will actually solve anything. I'm just saying you look like you need to take a 70-minute time out to drink a beer and cast aside empathy. Now More Than Ever will be my premiere in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival; I'm excited to come out with your support. Cheers! 

~:~:~:~

Val Dunn is a Philadelphia-based playwright & deviser who creates plays, performance art, and rituals. Val enjoys fighting fascism with radical queer joy (primarily in the form of foolish dancing to the West Philadelphia Orchestra). She is an alumna of the Foundry and a current member of Writers on the Rocks with whom she has developed A Shock of Wheat, I Know the Wind for the Things It Touches, and Down in the Holler (Play Penn 2018; semifinalist, Bay Area Playwrights Festival 2018). Val’s work has been supported by the Orchard Project, Centrum, Juniper Productions, The Bearded Ladies Cabaret, Azuka’s Spotlight Series, SANDBOX, and Philly Plays @ the Drake. The day after this show closes she will flee America to hike 177 mile hike along Offa's Dyke on the English/Welsh border. If this play doesn't fix everything, Val may never return... Support her art while you still can!

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to raise $1,300 to cover the cost of a bare bones production. Your contribution will go directly to invaluable expenses such as props, air conditioning for the attic, and performer fees. If we exceed our goal, we get to pay our artists sums closer to what they actually deserve! (Wow! Artists should get paid adequately for their work, what a concept?!)

The Impact

Can theatre really change things? Fuck if I know. But I guess it's worth risking a $5 donation on the chance that our play could contribute to getting rid of the Trump/Pence regime. You'd buy a beer for $5. Heck, some of you might buy half a beer for $7 at Local 44. Why not throw $5 toward the kind of scrappy-as-hell art ritual that's the reason the NEA no longer has funding?! 

Maura Krause is an expert producer/artistic director/director/dramaturg/kick-boxing-witch-goddess & I'm really enthusiastic! And WOAH have you seen our cast & creative team?! Together, I think we can make this jawn happen! All we need is your dirty money*!

*and universal healthcare, clean water for Flint, basic rights for Trans folx, open borders, $15 minimum wage, regulations of carbon emissions... 

Risks & Challenges

I am fronting all of the money to put on this bare bones production. If we don't meet our fundraising goal, I will become a full-time employee of Federal Donuts, and the Philadelphia Theatre Community will never see the like of me again. Save yourselves from that fate! 

Creating any piece about contemporary issues runs the risk of becoming prematurely irrelevant. On the off chance that our earnest Facebook posts and leftist in-fighting fix all of the issues discussed in this play (TW: Trump, Pence, fascism, capitalism, white supremacy, white feminism, nationalism, homophobia, transphobia, etc.) before September 14th, 2018... we will use this money to throw a giant bacchanalian party. 

Also, apparently it’s not illegal to put children in cages but it is illegal to threaten public officials. But what is art if not taking risks? I’m not suggesting that this show condones violence… but neither will it inspire you to fly an American flag from your Baltimore Ave. anarchist co-op.

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to contribute but can’t spare the $? No worries, all money’s dirty money! Here are some other ways you can help hex the grand ole party:

  • Share our fundraising link. Tell your rich friends! Tell your not-so-rich friends who want to support the arts anyway.
  • Come see the show, September 14 - 23. More info at valdunn.com. 
  • Can’t afford a ticket? Email Val to volunteer (valadunn@gmail.com) at our box office and receive a FREE ticket in return.
  • Call your representative; occupy ICE; call your representative WHILE occupying ICE!*
 

*This action will not directly help our production but is inarguably way more important than supporting our lil ole theatre play.
