story:
ABOUT the Studio


Hi! We are Aiko Kinoshita, Amelia Reeber, Alice Gosti & Tamin Totzke, the current and dedicated stewards of Open Flight Studio (OFS). OFS is a beautiful and historical art space in the heart of the University District in Seattle, WA. Run by artists since 1954, OFS is a community space for artists to research, experiment, develop, teach, dialougue and perform. 

We are asking for your support so Open Flight can serve artists, movers of all levels, and audiences for years to come.

 

++++ WE NEED YOU ++++

 

Open Flight is an essential gathering space for artists in Seattle. The studio has been in use for almost 60 (!) years and we want to continue the tradition. We hope you'll pitch in so OFS can  serve the art community even better.

Because of your help with our 2016 fundraising campaign we were able to buy a new sound system, vacuum, re - instate the Flight Deck Summer Residency and keep the space affordable for artists. We couldn't do any of that without you. So thank you! 

We are eager and excited to keep the momentum going because there is still much work to do.

This fundraising campaign we are focusing on being able to continue our Flight Deck Summer Residency and our Artist in Residence program. Funds will also help to cover necessary studio maintenance and any unexpected equipment purchases.

 


 

Flight Deck awards up to 40 hours of studio space to artists to use however they choose. In the past artist have used the residency to research a brand - new idea, workshop a work in progress or complete a creative project. At the end of the residency, artists share what they have been working on in an informal performance.

The Artist in Residence Program offers artists subsidized creative space for periods of three to six months with priority booking and regular weekly hours at a steeply discounted rate.

Former Flight Deck Residents include  Zoe Scofield, Jody Kuehner, Wade Madsen, Alice Gosti, Rosa Vissers and so many others. It's an incredible program and we want it to continue!

 

 

Give a little, give a lot. Any gift makes a difference.

 

YOUR SUPPORT WILL FUND

  • Keeping the Flight Deck Summer Residency & Artist in Residence Program going
  • Operational costs for upkeep and maintenance
  • AND will help keep the space affordable for artists

The time to support is now! Please share the love with OFS and keep the longest running dance space in the city alive and thriving. Help us cherish this amazing space!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute but love our work? Please share this campaign with your people and networks. It’s easy: just use the tools provided by Indiegogo.  

 

WE THANK YOU SO MUCH!

Yours, The OFS Team

story:
Short Summary

Recognize Theatre is comprised of one director, Kristin Heckler; three actors, Jacob-Sebastian Phillips, Sarah Raimondi, Pauline Sherrow; and one producer, Aurea Tomeski. We are a small team with a powerful story. Recognize Theatre is dedicated to rebuilding society's image of the sexual woman into a positive one, and Exposed is no exception. With this production, we hope to get reviews, additional producer and hopefully, a next production or a tour!

Our play presents the story of the Duke Pornstar, renamed Ariel Cox (:-)). We seek to humanize this celebrity and force each person to ask themselves what they thought when they heard about the scandal. The play juxtaposes choreographed staged porn scenes with original scripted scenes created by the team. The audience follows our heroine from hidden high school masturbation through the thrill of her secret porn career through the violent tweets and derisive talk show hosts to her standing up for herself and the consequences of her choices.

The writing process has been unique. The first draft contained only found text from articles about the incident, actual tweets and verbatim interviews. The "Twitter Storm" and "Talk Show" have barely changed since that first draft but we realized we wanted to breathe real life into this girl and the people surrounding her. We began improvising some "day in the life" style scenes and the new structure built from there. The four of us work together to determine which snippets of her life we need or want to see in order to stitch the major plot points together. Jacob, Sarah and Pauline then improvise the scene, Kristin records it and then writes a draft scene based on that improv. The next rehearsal, the draft scene is read at the table, discarded, more specific goals are determined for the scene and the actors improv the scene again. We continue in this pattern until the scene feels completed. The script at that point is frozen with the understanding that small words or sections of sentences will always change, even in performance. Although it's always true for theatre, each performance of Exposed is truly different.

This play is unique and the story is sensational, literally, but NYC is inundated with live theatre and we need to get the word out there! That's where you come in.

We've secured the funds for our venue and have cleverly built a low budget production but we want to hire a PR Agent to let everyone know about the show. We've found someone who can get our show the coverage we need for $2000.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $2000 for a NYC PR Agent

    The Impact

    Recognize Theatre has been producing theatre in New York for three years, including at the New York International Fringe Festival. We have upheld our mission to present theatre which challenges society's preconceived ideas about what is feminine and what is masculine with plays like How I Learned to Drive and Paraphilia: Everyone Has A Sexual Disorder. 

    In this play we tackle the ever burgeoning issue of "slut-shaming" and the double standard men and women experience with regard to sexuality. Women are encouraged to be a "lady in the streets but a freak in the bed" and men are often encouraged to "sow their wild oats" and "play the field." But some women want to wear their sexuality on their sleeve and some men want monogamy, or even other men. What about them?

    If it was discovered that a male freshman was doing porn to pay for his tuition, would people have encouraged him to kill himself? 

    The Duke pornstar chose to perform in rough, BDSM porn and was told that she couldn't be empowered while several dudes ejaculated on her face. Can you tell someone that they aren't empowered when they say they are? Can a woman be empowered by being subjugated?

    On The View, the Duke pornstar said she watched porn since she was 12 and the hosts were scandalized, shocked. Would they have reacted that way if she were a boy? Do they know girls experience puberty, and therefore sexuality, before boys?

    How can a woman be a freak in the bed if she also isn't expected to learn or think about sex?

    Why did everyone care so much that this girl did porn? Is it because she's smart? Or because she defended her choice? Or because she considered this option to begin with?

    These questions need to be asked and our play asks them. 

      Risks & Challenges

      Exposing New Yorkers to Exposed is our biggest challenge! We've got the show ready to go, we need the people!

      All of our other combined costs total; $8,000, three weeks at our venue being the largest expense at $6,900. 

      The investment of our time, two years of rehearsals and productions, and money would all be wasted if we aren't able to propel the show to the next level. We want to get the attention of producers so we can work toward moving the show to either a national tour or an Off-Broadway house. To do that, we need reviews. To get reviews, we need a PR agent.

      More important than press is an audience. We've got 3 weeks, 11 performances, and 550 seats to fill and a PR agent helping to spread the word will get people to our show!

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you can't contribute, don't worry! Share our Indiegogo page on your Facebook or better yet, COME SEE THE SHOW! Check out www.recognizetheatre.org for details about how to get tickets.

        Recognize Theatre is a sponsored project of FracturedAtlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Recognize Theatre must be made payable to FracturedAtlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

We have upheld our mission to present theatre which challenges society's preconceived ideas about what is feminine and what is masculine with plays like How I Learned to Drive and Paraphilia: Everyone Has A Sexual Disorder. 
In this play we tackle the ever burgeoning issue of "slut-shaming" and the double standard men and women experience with regard to sexuality. Women are encouraged to be a "lady in the streets but a freak in the bed" and men are often encouraged to "sow their wild oats" and "play the field." But some women want to wear their sexuality on their sleeve and some men want monogamy, or even other men. What about them?
If it was discovered that a male freshman was doing porn to pay for his tuition, would people have encouraged him to kill himself? 
The Duke pornstar chose to perform in rough, BDSM porn and was told that she couldn't be empowered while several dudes ejaculated on her face. Can you tell someone that they aren't empowered when they say they are? Can a woman be empowered by being subjugated?
On The View, the Duke pornstar said she watched porn since she was 12 and the hosts were scandalized, shocked. Would they have reacted that way if she were a boy? Do they know girls experience puberty, and therefore sexuality, before boys?
How can a woman be a freak in the bed if she also isn't expected to learn or think about sex?
Why did everyone care so much that this girl did porn? Is it because she's smart? Or because she defended her choice? Or because she considered this option to begin with?
These questions need to be asked and our play asks them. 


Risks & Challenges
Exposing New Yorkers to Exposed is our biggest challenge! We've got the show ready to go, we need the people!
All of our other combined costs total; $8,000, three weeks at our venue being the largest expense at $6,900. 
The investment of our time, two years of rehearsals and productions, and money would all be wasted if we aren't able to propel the show to the next level. We want to get the attention of producers so we can work toward moving the show to either a national tour or an Off-Broadway house. To do that, we need reviews. To get reviews, we need a PR agent.
More important than press is an audience. We've got 3 weeks, 11 performances, and 550 seats to fill and a PR agent helping to spread the word will get people to our show!


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, don't worry! Share our Indiegogo page on your Facebook or better yet, COME SEE THE SHOW! Check out www.recognizetheatre.org for details about how to get tickets.
Recognize Theatre is a sponsored project of FracturedAtlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Recognize Theatre must be made payable to FracturedAtlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Short Summary

MonoMyth Theatre is raising contributions for its inaugural production. We will be mounting Lojo Simon's Controlled Burn, a play about dying and living and how we find our way through both, at the Slate Theatre in Seattle, WA, December 1st - 10th 2016.

  • This campaign will help us compensate our esteemed actors, procure set pieces, props, and costumes.
  • By supporting us you will be supporting new, original works as well as local artists!

What We Need & What You Get

  • In order to reach our goal, we are looking to raise $5000.
  • We have varying levels of contribution starting at as little as $5, all the way to Season Sponsor level of $1000.
  • IndieGoGo's Flexible Program allows us to receive the funds earned even if we don't reach our whole goal - regardless, all funds will put into the show! If we achieve more than our goal, those additional funds will go towards our Spring Short Play Festival!

The Impact

  • As we state in our Mission Statement on our website -"Theatre and performance art in its many forms is meant to not only entertain and bring us together but to also act as a mirror of our truth - shedding light on our similarities and differences, both the beautiful and the unsightly." Controlled Burn deals with universal issues of love, loss, grief in its many manifestations as well as mental illness and how we hang on to hope no matter how dire the circumstances may seem. We want to tell stories that challenge our audience and showcase the human condition in all of its imperfect glory.
  • The entire MonoMyth team have individually worked on various successful theatre and film projects in Seattle in varying capacities from acting, directing, lighting design, producing, and more. This is our very first project bringing all of our strengths together in one beautiful production written by our dear friend and former classmate at U of I, Lojo Simon, a noted playwright whose plays have been presented  in Arizona, California, Connecticut, DC, Florida, Idaho, Montana, New York, Ohio, Oregon, Tennessee, Wisconsin and Washington.
     

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! As a new theatre company, we need as much exposure as humanly possible so please tell your friends and family about us!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and post our campaign on your social media pages!
  • Feel free to reach out directly to monomyththeatre@gmail.com for information regarding becoming a volunteer if interested - we love helping hands!

Thank you!

story:
Something Ever After
A New Musical

Music & Lyrics by Sasha Bartol

Book & Lyrics by Jeffrey Morse

Directed by Sophie Thomason

 

WITH:

TYLER ELLIS as Ben Harris

ADDY STAFFORD as Nancy Harris

DAVID SHADMAN as Andrew Harris

SARAH ROSENTHAL as Rachel Harris

ANTHONY BUZBEE as Chris Beckett

CAITLIN ODEN as Emily Gibson

SELENE KLASNER as Wendy Cruz

TAYLOR KASS as Alex Conway

ANDREA TORRE as Lindsay Lloyd

NIRVAN PATNAIK as Peter Donahue

 

Lighting Design by EDWARD HANSEN

Sound Design by DOMINIC TORQUATO

Stage Managed by MEGAN BURNS

Produced by TYLER ELLIS & SEAN SOPER

 

Joyce J. Cammilleri Hall

at the USC Brain and Creativity Institute 

Saturday, October 14 at 8:00 PM

Sunday, October 15 at 2:30 PM and 6:30 PM

 

WHO ARE WE?

Musical Theatre Repertory at USC

Musical Theatre Repertory at the University of Southern California was established in 2005 and is dedicated to enriching students’ lives through the production of quality musical theatre. As the only student theatre group committed to producing musicals at USC, our goal is to provide students with the opportunity to participate in musical theatre pieces supplementary to those produced by USC. Find us online at www.uscmtr.com about the company, donations, ticketing details, upcoming events, production stills, and even a few production videos! Thank you for supporting the arts and we can't wait to see you at our upcoming shows!

WHAT WE NEED

MTR is run exclusively by USC students. We receive no outside support from faculty or professional companies. Since our company is entirely student-run, each one of us puts in an enormous amount of time and effort to bring our productions to the stage. That being said, our financial resources are limited and our student production designers rely on the support of our donors to bring their designs to life.  Funds we raise will be used to cover costs associated with lighting, sound, venue rental, and much more. These key elements are vital not only in helping our production reach its full potential but also in providing design students with valuable production opportunities!

WHY SOMETHING EVER AFTER?

Inspired by a real life community, Something Ever After will strike a chord with not only a USC audience of mostly students, but also mothers, fathers and adults who have experienced great struggles and dealt with loss.

When Ben Harris, a high school senior struggling with the pressure of college admissions, family fights, and his own secrets, decides that he can no longer cope, an entire community is forced to deal with his decision. With his family torn apart and his relationship put to the test, Ben must learn to accept who he is and the life he’s been given in this touching new musical that takes a tragedy and finds light.

Additionally, and the most exciting aspect of the project, this production is a brand new musical written by MTR's very own Sasha Bartol. After working on this project for several years, it is ready to come to life and MTR wants to make this a reality for her in the best way possible. Your support can help make that happen.

THE IMPACT

This campaign will drastically increase the caliber of our performance, and we hope that by producing high-quality independent student productions, we can support other student groups to provide as many opportunities as possible for USC students! MTR has been producing musicals for and by the students during the past two decades now. Our goal for this year is to expand and further support the SDA community by providing valuable career and professional events, such as dance workshops, alumni networking events, audition preparation workshops and more. If you would like to learn more about all that we do as a company, check out our website. 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Program Ads

We are selling advertising space in our show program that will be distributed at every performance. Want to wish a cast member good luck? Are you a company looking to promote your own event? You've come to the right place. Please contact our producer Sean Soper (ssoper@usc.edu) for more information.

Attending a Performance

Aside from helping us achieve and surpass our $1,000 goal, there are many other ways to get involved and support our mission of producing quality musical theatre for the USC community! 

Whether you can offer financial support or not, please join us in Cammilleri Hall October 14th and 15th. We look forward to seeing you there.

Learning More and Spreading our Mission

You can also support us by simply spreading the word! Please share this page and find us on Facebook (MUSICAL THEATRE REPERTORY AT USC), and Instagram (@musicaltheatrerepertory).

We are always interested in getting other students involved in MTR. If you have any interest in joining our team, working on one of our shows, or getting some more information, email us at uscmtr@gmail.com. We would love to hear from you! 

Thank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!

story:
East by Southeast: A Festival of Asian-American Voices

We're teaming up 2 incredible and generous theatres with the dates and times below:

Horizon Theatre (1083 Austin Ave NE, Atlanta, GA 30307)

  • Sunday August 5th @ 1:00PM
  • Monday August 6th @ 7:30PM
  • Tues August 7th @ 7:30PM

Aurora Theatre (128 E Pike St, Lawrenceville, GA 30045)

  • Sunday August 19th @ 7:00PM

Each performance will consist of different pieces and artists ranging from theatre, music, and dance. Following the performances will include a community conversation. For more information on the program line-up or general inquiries about the festival, visit our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/unproducibleplays/

Our Story

After reading a couple of plays from the Kilroys list featuring an Asian playwright about Asian characters, questions continued to come about:

"Why haven't these plays been produced? Why couldn't these be done in Atlanta?"

Amee Vyas, Pam Joyce, and I (Michelle Pokopac) decided to challenge these questions by producing a 3-part series of events under the title Unproducible Plays: Year of Asian Voices. Our goal was develop and showcase local Asian artists in Atlanta and create conversations with the community on topics about cultural inclusion, representation, what is a universal story, and the challenges Atlanta theatres and artists face on producing Asian work which seems "unproducible".

Our first 2 events were a great success! You may have seen us at:

(11/17/17) 7Stages: Reading of Art of Gaman by Dipika Guha (part of the Homebrew Series

(4/23/18) Salon Style Reading in Morningside/North Decatur Presbyterian: Reading of Orange by Aditi Kapil

Our Challenges

Help us cover our production costs! UPP is not a professional theatre company, a non-profit, nor any sort of sponsored or funded entity. It is simply a passion project with a purpose to bring the Atlanta community together and supporting Asian inclusion. We are not interested in making profits off of anyone. We want to be able to financially compensate our artists for their work. Funds will go towards the artists and cover costs for equipment and supplies for the festival. We appreciate any and all donations! We'd love to meet you and hope you will join us at the ExSE Festival!

story:
Summary

  • My name is Monique. I have been writing this show my entire life without knowing it. I am a singer, songwriter, playwright and truth seeker. I grew up afraid of everything and everyone, which meant I did a lot of observing from afar. But with that distance came a longing to be connected to people. I've spent my life exploring what it means to be honest, authentic and your full self. I've traveled the world entertaining international audiences including foreign dignitaries, high class prostitutes, oil tycoons and I'm sure at least one spy.  I coach people to use their 'voice' to express their greater 'Voice' in the world. 
  • This campaign is important to me because I believe the story I'm telling is a universal one. Yes, it's main character is a mixed race woman, but we have all struggled to find and claim our own identity. This show allows audiences to witness a fellow human being's journey and at the same time, reflect on their own journey. It will make you laugh, cry and open your heart in a way that will have you wanting to connect with people you've never noticed before. Or one better, it'll have you feeling more empowered to connect with people you've wanted to but were too afraid or felt too awkward to do. 
  • By contributing to this campaign, you will help make a dream come true. This show is a trailblazer and leads the way towards more understanding of yourself and those around you. By contributing to my campaign you will support great theater. I have the intention of having this show land on Broadway- with your contribution, you can get in on the ground floor and say that you knew it would make it!

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • My intention is to raise $12,000.  This money will cover production costs (set design, lighting and audio design, the theater tech), theater rental and PR to get the word out. The theater rental alone cost over $6000! 
  • The perks offered are few, but great. You can support at any level and receive my original music, performance tickets for the spring run, one on one holistic voice sessions with me or your own masterfully curated performance for your friends or your organization. This show is an awesome conversation starter and can be beautifully used in a corporate setting as well. The perks will continue to be revealed as the campaign goes on...
  • If we don't reach the entire goal, please rest assure that every cent that we DO raise will go right into the production. 

The Impact

  • This project is valuable to the world because our country is in a state where we can no longer be satisfied from seeing each other as different, less than or asshole-y (yes that is a word). This show lays the foundation for those who get to see it (and those who simply get to hear about it) to begin the beautiful process of self-reflection and connection in a time when we're desperate for it. 
  • I've written and recorded two albums (which you can take home as a perk!) and have also just completed a third one which will be released later next year. I am a mother of two young  boys whom I adore. I am responsible person, especially with other people's hard earned energy. I am so enthused and inspired by this project because I know its value when it's experienced. I am absolutely committed to making this show happen in March. 

Risks & Challenges

I honestly don't see any risks or challenges to making this show a success in the spring. I feel like a lot of the heavy lifting has been done all this year in writing the show. It took every ounce of courage to write the stories that are shared in this show. I always felt that my life, my experiences weren't mine to share because other people were involved in them. It took being diagnosed with a health condition to help me realize that I am not responsible for anyone's experience but my own. And me keeping all my stories locked inside was impacting my health, my life force. 

No more. 

All of 2017 has been spent writing, crafting and workshopping this show. I truly believe the hard part is behind me and with your financial contribution, we can tell this story to so many more people. Will you help me do that?

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that we are all not able to contribute financially. I get it. If you fall into that category, I know your energy is valuable and I would greatly appreciate you helping in other ways:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Sharing the link on your social media, telling your friends, coworkers, strangers about the show. (What a great excuse to speak to someone you've been wanting to connect with!) 
  • If you're able to share the word with 5 people in a tangible way (sharing the link on their walls, snapping a picture of you with the person you tell about it with Hashtag #MulattoMath, I'll happily give you a shout out on social media. It will be fun!)
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for your time and the energy it took to read this. I know our time and attention are our two most precious resources.  I don't take you for granted. 

Help me raise the funds needed and let's get Mulatto Math out into the world!

Love and light.
Monique

If you're able to share the word with 5 people in a tangible way (sharing the link on their walls, snapping a picture of you with the person you tell about it with Hashtag #MulattoMath, I'll happily give you a shout out on social media. It will be fun!)

story:
There is not a person alive who has not in some way been touched by Alzheimer's Disease. And while we pray that one day soon scientists will discover a cure or prevention, in the interim, we must find ways to seek comfort and a deeper understanding of the emotional aftermath of this devastating illness.


At Luna Stage, we don’t look for the most popular plays or the plays that will make the most money.  We look for the plays that will change lives. For 23 years, Luna Stage has been developing and producing new plays that foster a sense of community and spark honest, heartfelt discussion, even around the most sensitive of subjects.



And so it is with great pride and anticipation that this spring, we will produce the world premiere of Old Love New Love, a beautiful and life-affirming new play by Laura Brienza about the challenges of caring for a loved one with Alzheimer's and the lengths one often has to go to in order to truly honor a life.


It is difficult to put into words the array of emotions one feels when faced with a diagnosis of Alzheimer’s in one’s family. Denial. Anger. Despair. Sadness. Confusion. Helplessness.

Three years ago, we came across a play that we felt touched upon all of these emotions in a funny, moving and ultimately hopeful way.  We wanted to produce the play immediately, but with a cast of 7 characters, it was prohibitively expensive for us. 

So, we put it on the proverbial “shelf”.

But we have decided that the play is simply too important to sit on that shelf any longer.  We have decided to take the plunge and commit to producing this powerful piece of theatre in the spring of 2016, and to reach out to you—all of you who have been affected by this disease—and ask you to help us bring this beautiful story to the stage. It is our hope that this play will offer catharsis and solace to those who have been called upon to meet the often unfathomable demands of remaining true to a life-long love in the face of this devastating disease.


We are looking to raise $25,000 to help us cover the costs of artist salaries and community outreach activities around this production.

The size of this production is a stretch for us.  We are a small regional theater and generally keep our cast to just a few actors, but we feel the subject matter and this playwright’s vision are well worth the additional risk.

So we humbly ask you to consider how this disease touches all of our lives and to take an active role in helping us to bring this play to the stage.

With your help, we can spark a dialogue and promote healing throughout our entire community, across boundaries of gender, age and social class.

With your help, we can host post-performance talkbacks with professionals in the field of elder care and off-site programming at assisted living facilities, extending the impact of who the play reaches and what voices are heard.

With your help, we can create an on-site Context Room, an interactive space for audiences to listen to pre-performance talks, to explore the issues and emotions raised by the play, and to share their own experiences.

We want to create a movement around this play—but we need you.


Luna Stage is committed to producing this play, regardless of whether our entire funding goal is reached.  Whatever funds are raised will go toward the production, and we will find a way to fund the rest.  We always do. The show must go on! Without your help, this will truly be a great stretch for us.  But with your help, if we are successful in raising $25,000, we will end our fiscal year on much stronger footing and be in a much better position to produce the next really important play that comes our way.


At the risk of sounding naive, the most important thing you get by contributing to our campaign is the joy of being a part of something positive - something bigger than yourself.  You get to give hope and support to those who need to know they’re not alone. You get to honor a loved one, gone too soon, and the people who cared for them.

This is a horrible disease that we cannot yet control or overcome.  But human beings are resilient, and artists perhaps most of all.  We cannot yet defeat this disease, but through art and community, we can seek solace and comfort in our shared experiences, and honor lives well-lived. This is why we do theatre.  It is not for a paycheck or for fame or praise.  It is to transform the world one life at a time.

All donors contributing $25 or more will receive our sincere thanks, an acknowledgment in our playbill, and a chance to share a photo or memory of a loved on our dedicated Facebook page.  Larger gifts will receive additional perks as itemized in the "Select A Perk" section.


Plays developed by Luna Stage have gone on to be produced in New York and around the country.  In the last few years alone, our premieres have been produced in New York City, Chicago, and Cleveland.  The Whipping Man by Matthew Lopez, developed and premiered by Luna Stage, has been one of the most produced plays in the country for the last three years running.

We expect Old Love New Love to have a long life beyond our premiere production.  We are investing in this play, and asking YOU to invest in this play, because we believe it has the potential to speak universally to audiences across the country.

We believe Old Love New Love can get people talking and thinking about Alzheimer's Disease the way Wit made people think about cancer and The Laramie Project made people think about gay rights.  Our production—OUR production—could be the spark that starts a flame: a flame of healing, of increased awareness, and of action.


Producing theatre is a crazy business.  Government and corporate support for the arts is dwindling, and the massive explosion of technology competes for everyone’s attention and dollars.  But still, we persevere. Why?  Because we believe that as people become less and less connected to their families and their neighbors and their communities, that live theatre becomes more vital that ever.

Because of how much we value that responsibility, we pick plays that start hard conversations and share uncomfortable truths. We pick plays that ask our audiences to dig deep into their empathy. We pick plays that resonate in the here and now and that will challenge our audience to see their world and themselves a little differently. Those kinds of plays aren’t always easy to fund.

And perhaps most importantly, we produce new plays.  Plenty of theatres produce the classics of the American Theatre and there is a place for that.  But we're looking to identify the next classic, the new voice that will alter the course of the American theatre, and thus our lives.

This is inherently risky.  There is no name recognition with a new play. You can't count on getting reviews. You can't control it when the weather forces you to cancel performances. 

But we can rely on this. For 23 years we have watched audience members of all ages and backgrounds walk into our 99-seat theatre and 90-120 minutes later walk out transformed. This is what theatre can do.  It can hold a mirror up to our society and ourselves, and in that dark room, where you can see the sweat forming on the face of an actor and feel the subtle movements of the person sitting besides you, one is reminded that we are all human, and that we all share the same origin and ultimately the same fate. But in that time in between, we are capable of greatness.


Donate! We mean it when we say that a donation of even $10 takes us closer to our goal.

Can’t donate? Here are some other ways you can support our production.

  • Help us share our message! Use the Indigogo Social Media tools to help us spread the word.
  • If you're local to West Orange NJ, let us know about a support group or organization that might be interested in getting involved with our campaign.
  • And of course, come see the show!


Luna Stage is the little engine that could. We are a small, but mighty professional theatre company located in Essex County, NJ, just under 15 miles from New York City.  Through dedication, talent and perseverance, we have earned a national reputation for developing outstanding new plays for the stage and for taking on challenging and provocative subject matters in our work.  In addition to our Mainstage productions, we offer play readings, classes for children and adults, a Jazz series and developmental programs for emerging artists.

To find out more about all of our programming, visit Lunastage.org




Here’s the synopsis: 

Gloria and Michelle have enjoyed good marriages, but now this mother and daughter both suddenly find themselves having to navigate the choppy waters of infidelity under very different circumstances. Gloria's husband Colin has fallen for another Alzheimer's patient at the facility where he resides. Michelle's husband Matt has strayed for more traditional reasons: a mid-life crisis. Old Love New Love is a funny, moving and life affirming play about what we can't remember and more importantly, what we can forgive. 

Old Love New Love by Laura Brienza will premiere in the spring of 2016. The production will be directed by Nancy Robillard.


Meet the Writer


Laura Brienza (Playwright) is a writer from New Jersey. Her plays have been seen in New York, New Jersey, Rhode Island, Pennsylvania, and Washington, DC. Her play Scared of Sarah recently played in Pittsburgh at Carnegie Stage after being developed by the Kennedy Center's Page-to-Stage Festival, the Lark Play Development Center, and FringeNYC. Other plays include The Bunk Bed in Heaven, War Zones and Bacha Posh. She is the author of two nonfiction books for Globe Pequot Press: Discovering Vintage Washington, DC and New York's Historic Restaurants, Inns, and Taverns. Her work has also appeared online and in print publications such as IndyBuild, Woman Around Town, and Flavor & The Menu. She also writes for film and television and a was recently named a Fellow in the Lifetime Writers Project. She is a graduate of Georgetown University and enjoys racing triathlons.

Meet the Director


Nancy Robillard (Director) Directing credits include productions on Broadway, Off-Broadway, and in regional and summer theatre. World premieres: Honor and the River, Rosemary & I, Rosa Loses her Face, Slow Dance with a Hot Pickup, and the off-Broadway musical, National Pastime. Most recently, she directed the New York premiere of Since Africa. Other New York productions: Culture Project, Vital Theatre, Directors Company, Algonquin Theatre, Theatre for the New City, Up Theatre Company and HERE. Regional: the Kennedy Center, Walnut Street Theatre, MetroStage, Northern Stage, Luna Stage, Surflight Theatre, Open Stage of Harrisburg, Gateway Playhouse, Keystone Rep, Tri-Arts and Theater Masters’ national new play festival in Aspen/NYC. On Broadway Robillard was assistant director to Mike Ockrent on Big, and Alan Arkin on Taller than a Dwarf. Robillard received an MFA in directing from Illinois State University, has taught acting and directing at several colleges and is a frequent guest director for the Department of Dramatic Writing at New York University. She is Director of Evaluations for Main Street Musicals, which is dedicated to developing new musicals throughout the U.S. Robillard is a member of the Society of Directors and Choreographers.

Meet the Cast

story:
What is The Horror Ensemble?

The Horror Ensemble is a collaborative group focused on creating immersive horror experiences that explore the ideas of fear and audience choice. The style of the event allows audience members to explore different characters and storylines by creating their own path through the experience. This can play out in many ways- through voyeurism, audience tasks, and even one-on-one moments with the performers.

To date, The Horror Ensemble has created three unique individual horror experiences in three very different spaces. The project has developed an anthology style- with the core ensemble members returning for each show to create an entirely new story and experience in a new space.

The coming return of The Horror Ensemble will be taking over the entirety of The Athenaeum Theater, resulting in our biggest, baddest, most immersive horror yet. The Athenaeum's scale, style, and historical grandeur will all contribute to the haunting nature of the experience.

Our hope is that the work of The Horror Ensemble provides an alternative to haunted houses that is grounded in the idea of creating an exciting, engaging, thought-provoking, and terrifying theatrical experience for our audience. 

Dark Day will run October 26th-28th at 10:30PM and Sunday October 29th at 7:30PM. Tickets are available here: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/978299

What We Need & What You Get

Most of our budget is going towards the rental of The Athenaeum, however there are also other expenses that go into building a production, particularly one that attempts to create the most immersive environment possible. Your contributions will be put towards:

  • Space rental
  • Creepy costumes
  • Petrifying props and practical effects (i.e. fake blood and other essentials)
  • Macabre Marketing/Advertising
  • Ghostly goodies for the audience

This production has become a labor of love. The team hopes to continue exploring this project simply because we are excited about making new discoveries and working together again to create a bigger and better production for a wider audience. No one involved is being paid from these funds. All contributions will go toward creating a higher quality experience for our audience.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that most of our supporters are not high rollers. If you can contribute please do. This could be as little as $1-5 or as much as you have in your bank account. If you are unable to contribute financially, please spread the word to your friends and any theatre or horror fans you may know. This production will only be possible with your help, and whatever form that takes is greatly appreciated.

The Horror Ensemble is:

Drew Beyer

Hampton Cade

Leo Chappell

Ebony Chuukwu

Andrew Huber

Christina Jones

Janie Killips

Ashlyn Lozano

Lauren Mangum

Ian Miller

Abbie O'Donnell

Jill Perez

Jordyn Prince

The Horror Ensemble Creative/Production Team:

Director: Lauren Fields

Production Design: Dean Corrin

Composer: Eric Richardson

Technical Director: Bryce Fields

story:
Short Summary:

  • With your funding, we will be able to pay our actors and the down payment to be in Fringe. Your contribution DIRECTLY MAKES THIS SHOW HAPPEN.
  • The creators of the show, Nick Saxton and Fletcher Wolfe, are two young artists who are passionate about comedy, theatre, and film noir. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • $400 Covers the Fringe Down Payment
  • $150 for Promotional Materials
  • $150 for Costumes and Set 
  • The rest goes to the actors 

The Impact

  • There are many obstacles for new artists to make art that will be seen. By helping to further the careers of the young talent in this production, you are symbolically fighting the good fight. 
  • A developmental version of this show was put on as a part of the Open Stage One Act Festival at the University of Minnesota and received high praise from theatre makers around the Twin Cities.
  • Plus, like...Film Noir is really dumb. Let's have fun with it. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help!

  • Fringe runs on word of mouth, so please share this campaign or the Facebook event with your friends and family! It would mean the world to us. 
  • Also, please come see the play!! Show dates are as follows:
    • August 3, 8:30 pm
    • August 6, 10:00 pm
    • August 8, 7:00 pm
    • August 11, 8:30 pm
    • August 13, 1:00 pm

story:
Founded in 2012 by a group of professional performers, Madison Lyric Stage is an arts collective for the Shoreline of Connecticut. Its mission is to present professional-quality entertainment drawn from the worlds of opera, chamber music, theater and dance. 

As we end our 2015 season, we at Madison Lyric Stage are thankful.  It has been a year of remarkable growth for our company:

  • We presented 5 main-stage shows, providing live, professional theater and music to more Shoreline residents than ever before. 
  • We launched our Apprentice Program, giving experience to 10 resident artist who appeared in 4 productions and had their own Stars of Tomorrow concert evening.  Our Apprentice Program has NO audition or application fee and the singers are paid a stipend.  MLS looks forward to continuing this program next season. 
  • We deepened our relationships with senior centers, providing live theater at a discount to this population.  We have further senior center projects in development for 2016. 

Proud as we are of these accomplishments, growth comes at a cost, and ticket prices only cover a portion of our expenses.  We have just announced our 2016 season which will include the opera 

Salomé, the musical Evita, and the drama Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?.  In order to keep producing quality, accessible, intimate  performances to the Shoreline we need your help.  Your support can "boost us into 2016."  No gift is too small and donations of any amount are most appreciated.  

Madison Lyric Stage is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Madison Lyric Stage must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
WE NEED YOUR HELP

Making a musical is a years-long process. For example, Steven and Tim started writing LIZZIE over 20 years ago! LIZZIE had a unique trajectory -- this one won’t take quite so long. We’ve already been at it for about 3 years, and 5 to 7 years is not at all unusual for the development of a new musical.

It starts with writers huddled in a room for a long time, but a pile of paper is not a musical, so before too long you start looking for actors, designers, directors, choreographers, schools, theaters, technicians, etc.

And, maybe most importantly, looking for audiences. Everything good that ever happened with our shows came about because people saw and heard what we were doing, liked it, and helped us out in one way or another.

We’re now at the point where we need a developmental production to take us to the next level. But to get one, we need to pitch the show to theaters, colleges, independent producers, and festivals -- to anyone who can help us get the show on its feet in front of live audiences, so we can see what we’ve got. To pitch the show to these folks, we hand them a script (done!) and a recording of some of the music.

That’s what we need your help with.

Friends and family and fans of our work have always been the underpinning of the whole enterprise. Words of encouragement, showing up for readings, offering feedback, buying tickets to productions, telling us we can come practice in their barn or spend a weekend at their house upstate writing. It may sound corny, but we are totally sincere when we say that YOU are the ones that make this happen, not us.

Making musicals not only takes a long time, but it is also expensive. And, unless the show is commissioned, most of the expense at first is borne by the writers. We’re not complaining, that’s how it works and it’s what we signed on for. But it’s why we’re asking for your help.

Here’s the nuts and bolts of the project. We have hired a small group of first-rate musicians, most of whom we’ve worked with on various productions and readings of LIZZIE. We plan to spend a few days rehearsing a selection of songs, hammering out arrangements, homing in on the unique Americana sound we want to create for this show. Then we’ll spend a day recording those songs. We don’t want to use a regular recording studio but find a space that has warm, sweet acoustics and record the songs live as if we were on the porch or in someone’s living room. It could actually BE someone’s porch or living room -- we’ll also accept in-kind donations!

We’re working hard to keep expenses low. Most of the money for the project is to pay the singers, musicians, and the sound engineer we’re working with. Any amount helps.

We’re really excited about the work we’ve done so far, and we can’t wait to share it with you. We’re ready to move to the next step of this crazy process. We just need your help getting over this hurdle!

Follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hesterprynnemusical

WHY HESTER PRYNNE?

We think The Scarlet Letter, a story of slut-shaming and religious hypocrisy in Puritan New England, is as urgent today as it was in 1642 when it took place, and as urgent as it was in 1850 when it was written.

We think it is urgent right now because middle school dress codes routinely forbid girls from wearing leggings because they “distract boys.”

We think it is urgent right now because 1 in 5 college women are sexually assaulted, and most of them don’t report the crime because they assume, with good reason, that they will be branded as “sluts.”

We think it is urgent right now because in a presidential race between the first female major-party nominee and an unqualified male TV star, the American public is fixated on the infidelity of the female nominee’s husband and not the extramarital affairs of her opponent.

And because outspoken, confident women celebrities like Leslie Jones are subjected to rape and death threats and relentless social media harassment criticizing their appearance and sexuality.

And because “Truvada whore” is the slang insult in the gay community for sexually active men who are taking Truvada, a drug that prevents them from contracting HIV.

And because the Catholic Church still shields priests who are accused and convicted of sexual exploitation of children.

And because conservative Christians still cherry-pick scripture to justify the oppression of women and sexual minorities while ignoring Jesus’s central message of love and compassion.

And because, though boys and men are also targets of online harassment, internet bullying of girls and women is much more likely to be sex-specific, such as rape threats, revenge porn, and misogynistic insults.

And because the majority of women who play multiplayer video games choose male avatars in order to avoid abuse.

We are telling this story now because we believe our society can do better if we commit ourselves to those founding American values of freedom in community and the celebration of each person’s dignity, worth, and potential for happiness.

Our new musical, The Life & Hard Times of Hester Prynne, based on Nathaniel Hawthorne’s The Scarlet Letter, is a jeremiad. It is our exhortation to call upon our better instincts, to stop the woman-hating, the sex-shaming, the difference-stigmatizing, to learn to love each other, to value women and men and people of all genders, to make a new world better than the old.

WRITER BIOS

Steven Cheslik-DeMeyer has been telling stories for over three decades in New York, Nashville, Austin, and on the road, as a composer, writer, and performer, including dozens of shows in the New York indie music and experimental theater scenes of the 1980s and 90s, in such venues as HERE, Dixon Place, CBGB’s, the Pyramid Club, P.S. 122, and many others. During his ten years with the neo-vaudeville duo Y’all, he made four CDs, two books, a feature film (Life in a Box), performed across the U.S., Canada, and Europe, and appeared on MTV and Comedy Central. His musical, LIZZIE (co-writer, lyrics and music) has been produced in, among other places, New York, Houston, Tampa, Portland, New Orleans, Phoenix, San Francisco, and Denmark. Productions in 2017 are scheduled in several American cities as well as London in February. Steven is a MacDowell Fellow and a graduate of the University of Texas at Austin with a degree in American Studies. He lives in New York City with his husband.

Tim Maner co-founded the tiny mythic theatre company, a staple of the NYC alt-theatre scene of the early 90s, and later co-founded HERE, the award-winning NYC arts center. As a writer/director, Tim has created over twenty original works. His last show, LIZZIE, a rock-show retelling of the bloody legend of Lizzie Borden, received three drama desk nominations, two PAMTA awards, and has played to audience and critical acclaim in New York, Houston, Seattle, Cleveland, Portland, San Francisco, and had its European premiere this past season in Denmark. (More info at www.LizzieTheMusical.com). He is currently writing a new musical, The Life and Hard Times of Hester Prynne, directing a new comic operetta The Emperor and the Queen’s Parisian Weekend, and teaching at Playwrights Horizons Theatre School. Tim has also sung in some bands, arranged and conducted a Cowgirl Chorus, and originated roles in a couple of Robert Wilson shows.

Liz Banks has worked with Tim Maner, tiny mythic, and HERE Arts Center for nigh on thirty years. Her original play Prince Charming: Anatomy of a Cybersex Love Affair was performed at HERE by a laptop using text-to-speech. Liz co-wrote book and lyrics with Tim for the six-year Hawthorne Project, building a trilogy of multi-layered multi-media events adapted from Nathaniel Hawthorne's three American novels. Also with Tim, she collaborated on book and lyrics for Frankenstein and Las Sirenas at the Ohio Theatre. She presented her adaptation of the fairy tale Bluebeard at Tanya Elder's Oral Text reading series, and adapted Poe's Hop-Frog for Tanya at The American Living Room Solo Series. Liz also acted as social media manager for LIZZIE, wrote downtown theater reviews for the NY Fringe Festival, and was a singer/songwriter with NYC bands Elizabeth City, Y'ALL's Cowgirl Chorus, and TV Goodbyes.

story:
We want to bring this story to life. And we have poured serious time and effort into it already. We need money to help us make it as well as it deserves to be made.

The money we raise will go towards the numerous costs that are included in production on a show; rehearsal space; costume; make-up; props and promotional material. Our musical instruments need strings and mic’s to be heard. We need to be heard over the music, so clip mics will be hired. Promotional material adds up, printing flyers and posters, and we would be greatful for any help to spread the word to promote this show.

We want to be able to pay our crew and the other professionals that want to work for us; set design, graphic designers, lighting designers and technical operators, so that this show can look and feel as well as it deserves to, for the work that has gone into it and the enjoyment it will generate.

 

Candlelit Tales uses melody, rhythm, dance and song to support traditional storytelling in order to bring this explosive tale to life for a new generation. Original music, enchanting singing and stunning movement, heighten the passion of the story that is told by two skillful Storytellers.

We will capture your imagination, but you might not get it back.

story:
From the seed of an idea to a fully staged production

Daphne is an original dance-theater piece with text by Alice Pencavel, direction by Paul Bedard, music by Daniel Emond, choreography by Melissa Brading, production design by Claire Moodey, and performances by Daniel and Claire, as well as Susan Mandel, Jonelle Robinson, and Alison Walter. Coming to New York's IRT Theater this fall, this adaptation of the Daphne & Apollo myth asks what being a vulnerable human means after our vulnerability is violated. This hilarious and ferocious play is sure to delight, scare, and provoke audiences. Please help us make this production happen and be sure to catch the show this September!

 

This ain't no money tree!

Making theater is not cheap, but we are committed to creating the fullest possible show we can while compensating our artists for their time. We are raising $2,500 to rehearse and create Daphne and compensate 8 artists. Please see our budget below and help us tackle a small piece of this pie! 

 

The Team

Alice Pencavel (Playwright). Work includes The Glowing Boot (United Solo; Portland Fringe), Pie Shop Play (finalist, Bay Area Playwrights), The Dutch Goose (semi-finalist, Eugene O’Neill Playwrights Conference), Totally Wholesome Foods; Bubbles; Nanners in da Face; Oh My God (Politico-Comico reading series); A Box in the Mountains (reading, Naked Angels), Nightmare (Theater in the Room, Kiev, Ukraine), Nettles (semi-finalist, Manhattan Rep), Jeans Make Art (Romanian/American Play Exchange), and others. BFA Ithaca College; MFA New School for Drama. alicepencavel.com

Paul Bedard (Director) is a New York City-based theater director and activist. He is a founder and artistic director of Theater in Asylum, which strives to provide asylum to highly-charged subjects and characters. Recent directing credits include The Debates, touring stage adaptations of the 2016 Presidential Debates; The Glowing Boot in the United Solo and Portland Fringe Festivals; The Infernal Machine at The Hangar Theatre; and ¡Olé! in the Prague International Fringe Festival. Paul is a Drama League Directing Fellow and graduated from NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts. Paulhbedard.com

Melissa Brading (Choreography) is a New York-based teacher, dancer and choreographer from Topeka, KS. She holds a BFA in dance education from the University of Central Oklahoma and teaches for the Limón Institute.  Melissa has danced for choreographers such as Hope Boykin, Nejla Yatkin, Amanda Selwyn, Chris Ferris, Sue Bernhard, and Sarah Council, and is a member of Avodah Dance. Melissa makes dances of her own and served as associate choreographer for #Coriolanus, directed by Paul Bedard and is happy to be on his team once again!  

Daniel Emond (Composer, Performer) is thrilled to make his IRT debut in Daphne! He has formed three bands, all of which regularly play around the New York/ Tri-State area and tour around the country (Lion and Spaniel, The Blue Eyed Bettys, and Daniel Emond); co-founded the Oh! Force Theatre Company, which is dedicated to fostering and developing new experimental theatre; produced three full- length albums of original music (three more currently in production); and performed in regional theaters from Sarasota, to Boston, to upstate NY. Most notably, Daniel acted, sang, and played clarinet at the A.R.T. in the broadway-bound Natasha, Pierre, and the Great Comet of 1812. Currently, Daniel is in the midst of creating a concept video album based on Melville’s Moby Dick, titled Kill the Whale. Also a dedicated music and theatre teaching artist, Daniel has completed the Kenan Fellowship at Lincoln Center Education, and has collaborated with Daphne playwright Alice Pencavel in creating three 20-minute musicals that were performed by children.  danielsswelltunes.com

Claire Moodey (Production Designer, Performer) directs, performs in, designs puppets for, and writes theater. In the last year, she directed Megan Lang's Forsaken Nation, Chiori Miyagawa's Five by Five, co-directed Marco Millions with Bess Rowen for Target Margin, and assistant directed David Herskowits on Mourning Becomes Electra. Recent performing credits include Mettawee River Theater Company's Before the Sun and Moon, Megan Murtha's Songs of Go and Pending, It's Lonely at the Top, and Are You With Us Graham Grant Graven?.  Her original work femme pathos will be performed in January 2018.

Jonelle Robinson (Performer) is an actor, model and teaching artist in NYC. Her national commercial credits include Purell, MyHeritageDNA.com, and Johnson & Johnson Band-aids. She's performed with Primary Stages (Off-Broadway) and is the Creator/Director of PiT Theatrical, a non-profit youth theatre group for teens in conjunction with The Jeanne Rimsky Theater in Port Washington, NY. She is excited to be a part of a production with her fellow Ithaca College Alums (Go Bombers!). @jo_to_the @pittheatrical

Alison Walter (Performer) is an actor, teacher, and producer in New York City and the Berkshires, MA. She studied Drama at LaGuardia High School, and received her Acting BFA from Ithaca College. LA theatre credits include Alison in Trainspotting at the Elephant Theatre in Hollywood, Helena in A Midsummer Night's Dream at Arroyo Park, and Catherine in Boston Marriage with Ophelia's Jump Productions. She teaches yoga, dance, and meditation to people of all ages in many different settings. Her first feature film as a producer, No Way To Live was officially released in July. AlisonWalterArtist.com

 

See the show!

Daphne performs:

  • Thursday, September 14th, 8pm
  • Saturday, September 16th, 6pm (Opening)
  • Sunday, September 17th, 7pm
  • Tuesday, September 19th, 8pm
  • Thursday, September 21st, 8pm
  • Saturday, September 23rd, 8pm
  • Sunday, September 24th, 3pm

Click here for tickets

Thank you so much. This show won't be possible without your support. We are so grateful to you!

story:
Short Summary

My name is SaRa Schabach.  I just started a theatre company in the DC area.  I have been involved with all aspects of theatre since I was very young.  I have a degree in Theatre and a Master's degree in Acting from Florida State University.  I worked in NYC for 4 years and just moved last year to Alexandria.  I love my new home and the community that has been so very warm and welcoming.  I do it all. Direct, Act, Build, Design, Choreograph, Stage Manage, Box Office.... you name it, I've done it.  It is time for me to build my own company and I am ready and excited for this enormous challenge.

My company will be for both old and new productions that are written for or by women, those considered minorities, and the LGBT community.  I have a deep passion for Civil Rights.  I'm so confused by the fact that we are still discussing the issue and we need to continue the conversation so that some day it will no longer be an issue.  The best way I know how to do this is through theatre.  I hope that my company will be able to educate, entertain and inspire audience members.  

I want to work.  Being an Actor is difficult.  There are a lot of us out there and not enough work to go around.  Unfortunately, I have also heard horror stories of actor's that do get work being treated terribly.  My company will be a place where I pledge...I promise...all artists will be treated with respect.  I wont tolerate any unkindness through words or action.  It will prove successful because true creativity can only be born in a place that is free of judgment and animosity.  The only intolerance I have is for intolerance.  

This company will also build an extensive community outreach program.  I would like to develop after school programs for low-income students.  I want to donate time to cleaning area parks and streams and entire communities if needed.  Everything from feeding the hungry and clothing the cold.  Although it wont be required for company members to participate in these programs, it will be strongly suggested and those who have already expressed interest are those who would be there to help the community.  Through this outreach program, we can only grow closer together as a company and gain respect for our company with in the community.  

The money donated by you today will go to filing for our tax-exempt non-profit status, building an interactive website, print business cards, make t-shirts to give away for advertising reasons, and making a brochure to hand out in the city, and begin planning the out reach programs.  With your help, Capitol R Company can start with a bang.  Art is very important.  There are many out there who believe it isn’t necessary, but with out all forms of art, we would be less human.  I want to celebrate art and creativity because with out it we are dead inside.  Let's push some buttons.  Let's make people talk.  Let's make people laugh and cry.  Help me in my greatest life changing challenge.  I want to make a difference in the world through performing arts because it is the gift I know I can give.  

If you are unable to help with this project financially, but wish to help in any other way, please contact me and I will keep you updated on the progress and find other ways for you to help.  I would also urge you to forward this to others in your circle that may be interested in helping.  

Thank you for your time,

SaRa Schabach

saraschabach@yahoo.com
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is SaRa Schabach.  I just started a theatre company in the DC area.  I have been involved with all aspects of theatre since I was very young.  I have a degree in Theatre and a Master's degree in Acting from Florida State University.  I worked in NYC for 4 years and just moved last year to Alexandria.  I love my new home and the community that has been so very warm and welcoming.  I do it all. Direct, Act, Build, Design, Choreograph, Stage Manage, Box Office.... you name it, I've done it.  It is time for me to build my own company and I am ready and excited for this enormous challenge.
My company will be for both old and new productions that are written for or by women, those considered minorities, and the LGBT community.  I have a deep passion for Civil Rights.  I'm so confused by the fact that we are still discussing the issue and we need to continue the conversation so that some day it will no longer be an issue.  The best way I know how to do this is through theatre.  I hope that my company will be able to educate, entertain and inspire audience members.

Thank you for your time,

story:
Where do you feel most at home?

In fact, what is home to you? It is a theme that resonates deeply with many of us living in what has become an increasingly global world . With backgrounds spanning from Australia and Taiwan, to Spain and Holland, we are a creative collaborative team of theater practitioners who have found their new home in Berlin and are passionate about the subjects of ‘belonging’ and the ingredients one needs to concoct the true essence of ‘home‘. We, Thin Skin Theater in cooperation with production platform SISYPHOS, DER FLUGELEFANT, have spent the last year researching, developing and finally brewing these themes which has led to the creation of BERLIN BOUND, the theater production we are proud to be premiering  at Kater Holzig in Berlin on November 22, 2012.

We wanted our piece to be performed somewhere that represented the true spirit of Berlin: "poor but sexy", alternative, where one can feel free to be who they are and where "wir haben es nicht nötig, jemand anderer zu sein (we don’t need to be someone we are not). In a city so famous for its underground electro music institutions we felt it important to find a venue that celebrated this egalitarian ethos and so chose Kater Holzig, the famous Berlin nightlife wonderland as our venue because of the way they celebrate individuality and inspire in others the hope of a better, more open-minded future.

Your much appreciated support  (be it big or small, sugar or spice) will help us manifest our dream to finally share our simmering recipe with the world! We hope you enjoy this taste of our work.

Your contribution will help us fund the rent of our venue Kater Holzig, our flyers and posters, props and costumes and rehearsal space and most importantly contribute towards the payment of our collaborative team whose collective imputs have made the development and creation of BERLIN BOUND possible. Your support will help us make our production become a reality. Herzlichen Dank!

Thin Skin Theater

Thin Skin Theater is the ensemble creation of Ana Mena, Nadine Rahimtoola and Sarah-Jane St Clair, three actresses who met while working together on ‘Shakespeare im Park’ Berlin 2011. With backgrounds spanning Spain, Holland, India and Australia, the desire to form an ensemble came from a shared passion to develop, produce and perform their own work, expressing their individual identities, together in Berlin.

www.thinskintheater.com

SISYPHOS, DER FLUGELEFANT

SISYPHOS, DER FLUGELEFANT (SdF), initiated by the director Chang Nai Wen in Berlin, recruits project-based "search-activists" in the Performing Arts. The aim is to make the mutual communication possible through a direct and unpretentious performance, which fully utilizes the immediacy of theatre -- or of Performing Arts in a larger sense - as a medium.

www.sdfprojekte.de

story:
Deathtrap is a play by Ira Levin with many plot twists, even referencing itself as a play within a play. Written in 1978, it holds the record for the longest running comedy-thriller on Broadway and was also nominated for the Tony Award for Best Play. 

It takes place in the home of Sidney Bruhl, the washed-up playwright who once made fame and fortune with successful murder mysteries for the stage. Now, with a deadly case of writer's block, Sidney plans to murder and steal the script of up-and-comer, Clifford Anderson, whose first play promises to be a smash-hit However, nothing in this play is as it appears. Wives, lawyers and psychics attempt to thwart Sidney's scheme, but no one knows what he's really after or what he'll do to get it.

Deathtrap requires not only a deflty creative and talented cast, but an intricate set and long list of props including a wall of swords, axes and guns. Our cast includes highly skilled actors Bruce Coen, Lauren Whyte, Jack Sorenson, Hope Garrett Cook, and Wilton Zenon. Your contributions will go toward the construction of the set and the aquisition of props for the production. Any extra funds will be used in other areas of the production (publicity, merchandise, etc.)

 

The Lauren-Reilly Eliot Company, founded by Cooper Helm and Scott Gremillion, is deeply committed and inspired to deliver high-quality theater and film to Lafayette! We believe theatre should not only entertain, but transport audiences to another place, another time. We believe it can be an experience that changes lives and perspectives. Our previous productions include Buried Child and At Home at the Zoo. 

 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
IT'S TIME FOR YOU TO GO UNDER THE KNIFE!

We are thrilled to announce the premiere of a new farce by Peter Zachari called UNDER THE KNIFE! Opening in March 2015, Mr. Zachari returns to THEATER FOR THE NEW CITY after his successful runs of PARKER & DIZZY'S FABULOUS JOURNEY TO THE END OF THE RAINBOW (2014) and FAT ASSES: THE MUSICAL (2013).  The show runs March 16-April 2, 2015. 


ABOUT THE PLAY

The Mount Canyon Gynecological Medical Group is going under and Dr. Roe Wade finds himself severely in debt. He turns to a broker to rent out two of his offices. One to a pair of plastic surgeons and the other to a dentist. What he doesn't know is that one of the plastic surgeons is Marcia, his ex-wife and the dentist is his long time mistress, Deidre. Deidre looks exactly like Marcia after undergoing plastic surgery. (Unbeknownst to her!) Marcia wants her alimony; Deidre wants to find her long-lost child. Both are expecting financial help from Roe, who is dead broke. Enter Budd, Roe and Marcia's son, who arrives to ask his father to pay for a wedding to marry Bernadette, a pro-life activist. Terrified his girlfriend may discover his father's controversial occupation he does whatever it takes to keep her from his father. Add a wacky receptionist, a forgetful Holocaust survivor and a treasure trove of other characters and you have UNDER THE KNIFE!

BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP TO MAKE IT HAPPEN!

We need to mount a production of this complete with costume, sound, props, musicians, publicity, the works. Your donation to this project will help make this dream of ours a reality. By contributing money to this project, you are helping the artists associated with this project to see an original production come to fruition. We have set our goal at $5,000 but if we reach that, please keep giving! Every cent raised on this site will absolutely go to the funding of this production. Please spread the word! Tell your friends about us.  And please, above all else, come and see the show! We would love to see everyone there.

The Players

PETER ZACHARI (Director / Playwright) wrote, produced and directed Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow for the New York International Fringe Festival. He has also written Fat Asses: The Musical, The 3rd Gender, Lighten Up!, which was produced off-off-Broadway, as well as Loosen Up!, Shake It Up!, Live It Up!, and One Love. His ten-minute play, I Am Seventy Going on Eighteen was selected for production at the Boston Theatre Marathon VII.  Mr. Zachari’s directing credits include Into the Woods, Footloose, Rumors, Grease, They’re Playing Our Song, Return to the Forbidden Planet and Moon Over Buffalo (Summer Theatre at Salem) as well asWest Side Story (Marblehead High School.)  For several years, Mr. Zachari taught Acting and Directing for the Department of Theatre at Salem State University.  He received his Master of Fine Arts from the University of Florida and his Bachelor of Fine Arts from Salem State University.  Peter is forever grateful to every individual who contributed to this production.  Follow Peter @PeterZachari on Twitter.

story:
What is Theater Reconstruction Ensemble?

We are a collaborative, ensemble-based company focussing on the re-imagining of classical and canonical plays and theatrical traditions. This year, we've dedicated our season to the exploration of American realism, starting with a critically-acclaimed production of Jaclyn Backhaus' Set in the Living Room of a Small Town American Play. This fall, we'll be presenting the world premiere of our first completely devised piece Salesmen: a meditation on masculinity and the American REAL! at HERE Arts Center in Lower Manhattan! After a year and a half of development, we are so excited to share this work with you, our always supportive and enthusiastic audience! 

What is Salesmen?

Through the close examination of traditions in American realism and notions of American masculinity in both the works of the 40s and 50s and in our own contemporary creative process, we've managed to create a truly unique theatrical experience entirely through memory - our own memories of iconic American films and plays, and the process of remembering a piece, without script in hand, as we create it over a prolonged period of time. Salesmen features a cast of eight men, including company members Mikey Barringer, Eben Hoffer, Patrick Scheid, and Nick Smerkanich, as well as both new and frequent collaborators Merlin Whitehawk, Hugh Trimble, Jonathan Gordon (Broadway's Orphans), and Hunter Canning, who most recently appeared in the Broadway production of War Horse and the hit web series "The Outs"!

We all can't wait to start rehearsals in September - out entire artistic team is so thrilled to be diving into this material - but before we can fully mount this extraordinary production we still have a long way to go and we need your help.

That's where you come in!

We still need to raise $8,000 by September 30th or we won't be able to do this amazing show. Any amount you are able to donate will help us make it closer to that goal, and will be immensely appreciated by our entire company. Your donation will go directly toward production design, venue costs, press and marketing expenses, and most importantly artist fees for every member of the production, making this the first show we hope to be able to pay all our collaborators for all of their hard work. So please, check out our perks, visit our website, and if you're able to, make a donation. We really believe in this piece, and need your help in order to make it a reality!

The buzz:

"Even under all the layers of meta-commentary, [TRE]’s organic hunt for an emotional authenticity that it doesn’t always find is exhilarating."   Backstage

"This fabulous production signals Theater Reconstruction Ensemble and its members as up-and-comers to watch in years to come."   Theatre Is Easy

The Three Seagulls, or MASHAMASHAMASHA! was picked as Off-Off Blogway's #8 Favorite Show of 2012!


Whether you're able to make a donation or not, please remember to join us for Salesmen: a meditation on masculinity and the American REAL!, premiering at HERE October 24th - November 9th!

Thank you!


Theater Reconstruction Ensemble

John Kurzynowski Artistic Director
Reed Whitney Producing Director
Kate Marvin and Patrick Scheid Associate Artistic Directors
Lauren Swan-Potras Development Director
