story:
Lenora Lee Dance is fiscally sponsored by Asian Pacific Islander Cultural Center, a non-profit tax-exempt organization. All donations to Lenora Lee Dance are fully deductible to the extent allowed by law.

DEAR FRIENDS,

Wishing you a very happy new year of the horse! 2013 was an explosive year for Lenora Lee Dance (LLD) with new commissioned performance works, dance film premieres, and creative engagement programs for youth and college students. Thanks to your generosity, LLD has reached over 11,000 people, collaborated with over 30 artists, and produced new large-scale performance works every year for the last 6 years with increasing visibility and relevance within the arts, Asian American and human rights communities. You have helped LLD create work with and about these communities focusing on historical and current effects of politics and events on immigrant populations, and detainment on Angel Island during the Chinese Exclusion Era. With your support, LLD is weaving together multiple artistic disciplines and socially conscious work, pushing the relevance of arts in various communities throughout the country.

YOU CAN BE PART OF THE TEAM!

In May we will be flying our cast of 9 out to perform in the NYC premiere of The Escape and Rescued Memories: NY Stories, which excavate the lives of early 20th century Chinese women migrants through dance, martial arts, film, text and music. The Escape is inspired by women who sought refuge from exploitation in San Francisco at Donaldina Cameron House. Rescued Memories: NY Stories retraces the life of Bessie M. Lee (b. 1894), who spent two years in indentured servitude after migrating to New York City. These pieces were commissioned and performed at the de Young Museum in 2013 and will premiere in New York City this May 8th & 9th, at Asia Society, co-presented by the Asian/Pacific/American Institute at New York University.

In addition to taking these performance works on tour, we will shoot more film footage, edit & premiere our 3rd film, based on Rescued Memories: NY Stories. And this coming September 26 - October 5th, we bring to you our 7th Annual Home Season performances at Dance Mission Theater, which will feature new & older works, expanding our season to a 2-week run from our previous 1-week set of fall performances.

With this growth we are taking on new and significantly greater financial challenges. The company is developing in size & programming, creating not only performance pieces, but also films, museum installations, touring & civic outreach programs - all bringing awareness to issues of violence against women & the exploitation of immigrants & youth. To make our goal of raising $30,000 this year, we ask for your generosity.

I have been able to raise a portion of the money needed through individual donations and grants, however we have hit a critical point and I am reaching out to you and the community for support.

WE NEED YOUR HELP TO RAISE $10,000 IN 30 DAYS! 

The minimum we are trying to raise is $10,000 in 30 days to support the costs of organizing and putting on the NYC tour and fall home season, and to finish the shooting and editing of the Rescued Memories: New York Stories 30 minute film. This is cutting some corners, but will allow us to:

-       Pay for roundtrip airfare for 9 collaborating artists to fly to New York City for the NYC premiere performances 5/8 – 5/9/14

-       Cover some of the artist fees for the performers, videographers, and filmmaker

-       Pay for the lighting, equipment rental and film shoots

-       Cover some of the theater rental, artist & collaborator fees for our 7th Annual Home Season at Dance Mission Theater in SF 9/26 – 10/5/14

If we exceed the goal and make our way to the $25,000 needed for the year, you will be helping to:

-       Pay for the remaining artist fees for the 20 collaborating artists 

-       Cover some of the administrative costs in conducting rehearsals, planning, fundraising, publicity, marketing, and running the company this year.

ADDITIONAL WAYS TO SUPPORT

-  If your company has a Matching Gifts Program, your donation can go twice as far.  Please contact me at Lenora@asianimprov.org to inquire about the details

-  If you have airline miles you can donate, we would greatly appreciate the contribution!!  Please email Lenora@asianimprov.org

YOU CAN HELP SPREAD THE WORD TO YOUR FRIENDS, COLLEGUES, AND NETWORKS ABOUT OUR PROJECTS AND REQUEST FOR SUPPORT! 

Audiences have been deeply touched by both of these performance pieces. We look forward to sharing them with east coast audiences this May and Bay Area audiences this fall. When you contribute at any of the following levels, you will receive special perks and gifts!! We are greatly appreciative of your generosity. Please consider deepening your impact by increasing your contribution this year. Your gifts are instrumental in the vitality of this work. 

With great love, respect and gratitude,

Lenora

P.S. Please help spread the word! 

P.P.S. For those who have already contributed in 2014, thank you so very much. If you would like to receive the perk associated with your donation level, please email Lenora@asianimprov.org to indicate this.

For information about the 5/8-5/9 NYC performances, click here.

Click here to read recent Women’s Media Center article featuring Genny Lim, Cindy Liou from API Legal Outreach, and Lenora Lee by Emily Wilson.

PHOTOS – Rescued Memories: New York Stories by Robbie Sweeny, Courtesy of Cameron House

www.LenoraLeeDance.com
story_txt:
Lenora Lee Dance is fiscally sponsored by Asian Pacific Islander Cultural Center, a non-profit tax-exempt organization. All donations to Lenora Lee Dance are fully deductible to the extent allowed by law.DEAR FRIENDS,
Wishing you a very happy new year of the horse! 2013 was an explosive year for Lenora Lee Dance (LLD) with new commissioned performance works, dance film premieres, and creative engagement programs for youth and college students. Thanks to your generosity, LLD has reached over 11,000 people, collaborated with over 30 artists, and produced new large-scale performance works every year for the last 6 years with increasing visibility and relevance within the arts, Asian American and human rights communities. You have helped LLD create work with and about these communities focusing on historical and current effects of politics and events on immigrant populations, and detainment on Angel Island during the Chinese Exclusion Era. With your support, LLD is weaving together multiple artistic disciplines and socially conscious work, pushing the relevance of arts in various communities throughout the country.
YOU CAN BE PART OF THE TEAM!
In May we will be flying our cast of 9 out to perform in the NYC premiere of The Escape and Rescued Memories: NY Stories, which excavate the lives of early 20th century Chinese women migrants through dance, martial arts, film, text and music. The Escape is inspired by women who sought refuge from exploitation in San Francisco at Donaldina Cameron House. Rescued Memories: NY Stories retraces the life of Bessie M. Lee (b. 1894), who spent two years in indentured servitude after migrating to New York City. These pieces were commissioned and performed at the de Young Museum in 2013 and will premiere in New York City this May 8th & 9th, at Asia Society, co-presented by the Asian/Pacific/American Institute at New York University.

In addition to taking these performance works on tour, we will shoot more film footage, edit & premiere our 3rd film, based on Rescued Memories: NY Stories. And this coming September 26 - October 5th, we bring to you our 7th Annual Home Season performances at Dance Mission Theater, which will feature new & older works, expanding our season to a 2-week run from our previous 1-week set of fall performances.
With this growth we are taking on new and significantly greater financial challenges. The company is developing in size & programming, creating not only performance pieces, but also films, museum installations, touring & civic outreach programs - all bringing awareness to issues of violence against women & the exploitation of immigrants & youth. To make our goal of raising $30,000 this year, we ask for your generosity.
I have been able to raise a portion of the money needed through individual donations and grants, however we have hit a critical point and I am reaching out to you and the community for support.
WE NEED YOUR HELP TO RAISE $10,000 IN 30 DAYS! 
The minimum we are trying to raise is $10,000 in 30 days to support the costs of organizing and putting on the NYC tour and fall home season, and to finish the shooting and editing of the Rescued Memories: New York Stories 30 minute film. This is cutting some corners, but will allow us to:
-       Pay for roundtrip airfare for 9 collaborating artists to fly to New York City for the NYC premiere performances 5/8 – 5/9/14
-       Cover some of the artist fees for the performers, videographers, and filmmaker
-       Pay for the lighting, equipment rental and film shoots
-       Cover some of the theater rental, artist & collaborator fees for our 7th Annual Home Season at Dance Mission Theater in SF 9/26 – 10/5/14
If we exceed the goal and make our way to the $25,000 needed for the year, you will be helping to:
-       Pay for the remaining artist fees for the 20 collaborating artists 
-       Cover some of the administrative costs in conducting rehearsals, planning, fundraising, publicity, marketing, and running the company this year.
ADDITIONAL WAYS TO SUPPORT
-  If your company has a Matching Gifts Program, your donation can go twice as far.  Please contact me at Lenora@asianimprov.org to inquire about the details
-  If you have airline miles you can donate, we would greatly appreciate the contribution!!  Please email Lenora@asianimprov.org
YOU CAN HELP SPREAD THE WORD TO YOUR FRIENDS, COLLEGUES, AND NETWORKS ABOUT OUR PROJECTS AND REQUEST FOR SUPPORT! 
Audiences have been deeply touched by both of these performance pieces. We look forward to sharing them with east coast audiences this May and Bay Area audiences this fall. When you contribute at any of the following levels, you will receive special perks and gifts!! We are greatly appreciative of your generosity. Please consider deepening your impact by increasing your contribution this year. Your gifts are instrumental in the vitality of this work. 
With great love, respect and gratitude,Lenora
P.S. Please help spread the word! 
P.P.S. For those who have already contributed in 2014, thank you so very much. If you would like to receive the perk associated with your donation level, please email Lenora@asianimprov.org to indicate this.
For information about the 5/8-5/9 NYC performances, click here.
Click here to read recent Women’s Media Center article featuring Genny Lim, Cindy Liou from API Legal Outreach, and Lenora Lee by Emily Wilson.
PHOTOS – Rescued Memories: New York Stories by Robbie Sweeny, Courtesy of Cameron Housewww.LenoraLeeDance.com

story:
My name is Lesley Eadie and I run Urban Fairytale Theatre Company, an innovative company based in Glasgow who create original work and tackle contemporary texts. UFTC is an 18-25 company looking to gain community interest company status. We want to make theatre that is relevant to society today, that's why we chose the name Urban Fairytale, to tell tales from the city by people from the city to people from the city. We want to attract an audience who like to be challenged, an audience who want to leave the theatre thinking about what they have just seen and go on thinking about it for as long as it takes to digest.

We are currently staging The Collector by John Fowles (adapted for the stage by Mark Healy) in the Govanhill Baths in the south side of Glasgow. This is an amazing project in an amazing space. You can see the trailer for the show up above.

The Collector takes the audience on a journey of discovery with the characters. Socially inept butterfly collector Frederick Clegg wins the lottery and decides to collect another species entirely in the form of Miranda Grey, a 19 year old art student. Clegg is hopelessly in love with Miranda and believes the only way to make her feel the same way is to bring her to live with him in his house in the country. Captured in the cellar of Clegg's home we see Miranda use everything in her power to get back to her family. But is it enough?

This production is being staged in the drained swimming pool at Govanhill Baths in the south side of Glasgow. The audience enter the pool with the actors and can move along the traverse stage feeling like they are in Clegg's house with Miranda. Stairs lead to the top of the deep end mimicking the top layer of Clegg's house where he lets Miranda bathe once a week. The audience will be fully immersed in Clegg and Miranda's world.

How often do you get to stand in a drained swimming pool and watch a play with the actors 2 feet away from you? I'm guessing not often. That’s what makes this project so exciting for us, the fact we are going to give the public something they have probably never seen before and unlikely to see again.

It would be amazing if you could help us. We have been working tirelessly to bring the world of this play to life. We have given our designers the chance of a lifetime and they are all under 23 years old! 

What We Need & What You Get

We need wood. Plain and simple. We are running out of wood to build the stage and we desperately need it. The actors will fall through the stage otherwise and the play just won't be the same!

See that bit in the picture where those barrels are? Well we need to keep building all the way down there...

We can promise you tickets, meet and greets with the designers and actors, free drinks at the bar, signed posters and a season ticket to all our company's productions this year, including our performance at the Tin Forest Commonwealth International Theatre Festival with The National Theatre of Scotland.

We know that it is hard for some people to contribute to a project like this but that doesn't mean you can’t help. Here’s a couple of ways you could help us if you can’t contribute: 

You could email some buddies who might be interested in helping with our project.

You could use the Indiegogo share tools, to get the work out about our project.

Thank you so much for reading this and I hope at least some of you get the chance to see The Collector and enjoy it’s unique location, fabulous acting and exceptional design work.

L xx

story:
About In Loving Memory: 

Over the course of one tumultuous afternoon, Megan Powell struggles with whether she should endure her suffering over the death of her boyfriend or end her pain completely. “In Loving Memory” is a surrealistic journey through the heart and mind of a young girl looking to make sense of life’s toughest challenges and we are thrilled to be bringing it to life!

The piece has been accepted in to the Planet Connections Festivity for this June, during which our efforts will benefit Suicide Prevention International, and we have plans to mount a full production within the coming year.

We are in need of $600 to cover our participation in the festival, rent rehearsal space and publicize the production so that it can reach as many people as possible.

 

Money, Money, Money...

Producing new theatre in NYC, or really anywhere, is extremely important; it is also extremely expensive. With your help, we will be able to move this beautifully moving piece forward so that it can reach audiences and maybe even change a few lives.

Any funds we obtain through this campaign will go directly to giving this piece the future it deserves; our primary costs being rehearsal space, the festival participation fee and publicity materials.

To show our gratitude for your help with bringing this piece to life we have some great perks for you! Check them out in the column on the right – and don't be surprised if more show up!

 

Other Ways to Help:

If you'd like to help us but can't afford to donate there are some ways to do that!

  • Share this campaign with your friends and tell them why you think this is a worthwhile project.
  • Post the campaign to your facebook wall.
  • Tweet about the campaign on Twitter.
  • Come to our free reading at the Planet Connections Festivity on June 14!

Be sure to keep checking this page for updates about our creative team, see our progress and get to know us a little better (I promise we're nice people)!!

And for more information on the piece and our upcoming reading you can check out our festival webpage!

story:
Guilty Pleasure

We are a group of students from different courses at the University of South Wales who are all passionate about theatre.

We are producing a one act play written by a creative writing student. The piece is a post modern play about a Widower, and takes him through the seven stages of guilt after the death of his wife.

The play will be performed on the 23rd and 24th of May at the Riverfront Theatre.

This is a chance for many students to show their talents, from writing to acting.

Due to a recent merger between Universities, there is now no funding given to this production, which is why we are looking at crowd funding. We need to raise money for costumes, set construction, and props.

We are all very passionate about the play, and want to be able to create a fantastic piece of theatre. Anything you donate can help us reach that goal. We are a non profit group, and anything we make will go into funding other productions at the University of South Wales.

Thank you.

story:
My name is Elizabeth Hrushowy, I am 11 years old and I have been awarded a $1000 US scholarship to attend a dance training intensive “Summer in L.A.”, taking place, July 6 – 13, 2015.

This is a dream come true as dance is my life, it is my passion and this opportunity of a lifetime is something that will positively change my life. With your financial assistance, I will be able to be a part of this educational experience as the funds will help me pay for the rest of the trip which is $4695 US.

I am committed and serious about this program and any amount you can sponsor me with will truly go a long way.

I will be working with the industry’s top instructors, professionals and leaders. I will learn to be a professional and will see if I have what it takes to make it as a dancer. Dancers are athletes and just like Olympians we need to take opportunities to travel to be able to work with the best in the world. In addition, my self esteem and confidence level will increase with my participation.

Please read Testimonials of the program here: http://www.summerinla.com/testimonials.html

Thank you for your support!

Elizabeth

story:
THE PLAY

Are You dead?
No…
Do you know someone who might die?
Erm…
Then this show is for you!*
Join bereavement expert Bella Heesom and her fabulous piano-toting assistant Esh Alladi and…
• Master the correct grip for hugs.
• Learn how NOT to use a portable urinal.
• Discover the limits of logic in the face of disaster.
And much more!
*If you think this isn’t relevant to you, you’re wrong: everyone you love is going to die.
Bella knows this from experience.                                                                                 

A bold new tragicomic play about battling grief, encompassing philosophy, religion and astrophysics. Part true story, part absurd performance lecture. Unflinching in both its intimacy and its humour.

REVIEWS FOR PREVIOUS SHOWS:
  • ‘Poignant and tender... as funny as it was moving’ Sunday Times on Mathematics of the Heart by Kefi Chadwick, Theatre503
  • **** ‘A poetic mortar-bomb... emotionally explosive’
    The Times on I Am Sad You Are Dead Mrs T by Kay Adshead, Theatre503

THE PEOPLE


BELLA HEESOM - WRITER & ACTOR

Hello! I'm Bella. I'm an actor. I trained at LAMDA, and have been working professionally in the theatre for over 5 years. This is the first play I have written. It is based on my experience of the deaths of my parents. It is obviously a very personal piece of work, and creating it has been a cathartic process. However, I am sharing it because I think its themes are universal, and I hope the story will connect with many people in lots of different ways. 

I am really proud and excited that Will and Ben, the artistic directors at the Tristan Bates Theatre, liked the script enough to include the play in their Camden Fringe programme. I hope that our week-long run this August will be the beginning of a long life for the project. I want to share my story with as many people as possible, and this is an opportunity to showcase the play and generate interest with a view to producing it again in future at other theatres.

 I am honoured and thrilled to have an incredibly talented team of creatives working on the project with me:

DONNACADH O'BRIAIN - DIRECTOR & DRAMATURG

Donnacadh and I have a rich working history. I have performed in no less than five plays directed by him, and I can tell you from experience that he's brilliant (the reviews above were for two of those previous collaborations) . His insight has been invaluable in helping me develop the script, and making it into something that will be fun to watch. You can read more about his work here: www.donnacadhobriain.co.uk

ESH ALLADI - ACTOR

Esh is a close friend and an incredibly charismatic performer. Esh also trained at LAMDA, and can currently be seen onstage in The Beaux Stratagem at the National Theatre. On our first day workshopping the play together, he had me so breathless with laughter that I couldn't say my lines. (This could be a problem.)

ANNA O'GRADY - COMPOSER

Anna is another close friend. She plays the piano as if music is a magic she has just created, and it could disappear at any moment. The music she makes is beguilingly beautiful. Her score lifts my words to a whole new level. 

ELIZABETH HARPER - DESIGNER

Elizabeth is a graduate of the MA Theatre Design course at Bristol Old Vic Theatre School. She is a talented artist, and she already has some wonderful ideas for building a space in which my story can come to life. I can't wait to see what she creates.

KEEGAN CURRAN - SOUND DESIGNER

Keegan is also a graduate of Bristol Old Vic Theatre School. He has nine years' experience of working in theatre and live events, most recently based at Tobacco factory Theatres. Keegan has some great ideas for conjuring the world of the play through sound. 

GEORGIE BARWICK - PRODUCER

Georgie came to us highly recommended by Will and Ben at the Tristan Bates Theatre after working on The Glasshouse there last year. She is a recent graduate, set to make a big splash in the theatre scene.  She will be pestering the press big-time! 

THE MONEY


Invested so far:
The Yard Theatre in Hackney Wick supported the development of the piece by giving us space for R&D, because they saw the potential of the project. The amazing creatives listed above have generously donated their time and talent because they believe in the project. I (Bella) have invested a significant amount of my personal savings. We have paid the Camden Fringe registration fee. We have hired the theatre. We have had some gorgeous promotional materials designed by the brilliant Rebecca Pitt. This is happening! And now...

What we need:

We need your help to pay for  the following:

  • Rehearsal space hire
  • Set and costume
  • Printing promotional materials (posters & fliers)
  • Expenses for the creatives making the show happen
  • Boring practical costs (public liability insurance etc)
Anything you can give will help. We have calculated that we need £2,000 to cover the above. If we raise more, then we will pay everyone involved for their hard work.
To show our IMMENSE APPRECIATION of your kind generosity in helping to make My World Has Exploded A Little Bit  the best play it can be, we are offering some lovely PERKS to donors! Take a look at the list on the right :)

THE IMPACT

I believe that theatre can change the world. Humans have always shared stories, and I think that is because of a fundamental need. Stories help us understand ourselves and the people around us. They make us feel less alone. I love autobiographical theatre, because it is so generous in its openness and vulnerability. It gives the audience an opportunity to climb inside another mind and see the world through their eyes. This is precious because it helps us to cultivate empathy. I really think the world would be a better place if we all strived for empathy on a daily basis. My World Has Exploded A Little Bit  explores the complex and difficult theme of death in a new and imaginative way. It is brutally honest about my struggle to allow myself to feel. Death is still a taboo, and that can make grieving a lonely place to be. I hope to help people feel less alone, whether they have experienced the death of a loved-one, or any other form of loss, or they are simply afraid of losing what they love. 

SPREAD THE WORD :)

If you don't have any spare pennies to give us, but you're excited by the project, you can still help it be a success! Please TELL YOUR FRIENDS :)
  • Share this campaign with anyone who might be interested
  • Tweet about the show using #myworldexploded
  • Talk about the play on Facebook and link to myworldexploded.com
  • Rave about the project in real life - in the pub, at the theatre, on the phone to your mum...
  • BOOK A TICKET TO SEE THE SHOW - HERE!

 

 *** A MILLION THANKS!!!! ***

THE IMPACT

They make us feel less alone. I love autobiographical theatre, because it is so generous in its openness and vulnerability. It gives the audience an opportunity to climb inside another mind and see the world through their eyes. This is precious because it helps us to cultivate empathy. I really think the world would be a better place if we all strived for empathy on a daily basis. My World Has Exploded A Little Bit  explores the complex and difficult theme of death in a new and imaginative way. It is brutally honest about my struggle to allow myself to feel. Death is still a taboo, and that can make grieving a lonely place to be. I hope to help people feel less alone, whether they have experienced the death of a loved-one, or any other form of loss, or they are simply afraid of losing what they love. 
    SPREAD THE WORD :)
If you don't have any spare pennies to give us, but you're excited by the project, you can still help it be a success! Please TELL YOUR FRIENDS :)

Share this campaign with anyone who might be interested

Tweet about the show using #myworldexploded

Talk about the play on Facebook and link to myworldexploded.com

Rave about the project in real life - in the pub, at the theatre, on the phone to your mum...
BOOK A TICKET TO SEE THE SHOW - HERE!

     
 *** A MILLION THANKS!!!! ***

story:
Who is David Shepherd?

Born in New York City, David Shepherd studied English at Harvard and received an M.A. in the History of Theatre at Columbia University. Disenchanted with what he perceived as a European dominated theatre on the east coast, Shepherd gravitated to the Midwest.  In 1953, Shepherd was one of the founders of the Playwrights Theatre Club in Chicago.  In 1955, with Paul Sills, he founded the Compass Players, the forerunner of Second City.

Compass launched the careers of Ed Asner, Mike Nichols, Elaine May, Jerry Stiller, Alan Alda, Alan Arkin, Barbara Harris, and Shelley Berman (to name a few) and started a revolution in entertainment. In 1972, David formed Group Creativity Projects, a non-profit organization which enables amateurs and professionals to improvise their own plays, movies, radio shows, poetry and novellas.  Along with Howard Jerome in 1972, David designed and produced the Improv Olympics - a performance sport which premiered in New York City and later spawned a citywide competition in Chicago during the early 1980s.

The Improv Olympics was adapted in Ottawa as the Canadian Improv Games (CIG) by Willie Wyllie and Howard Jerome.  Now in its 38th year, CIG is part of the curriculum for over 300 Canadian high schools nation wide.  Since the inception of Group Creativity Projects, David has invented countless other improv formats including the Responsive Scene Radio Show (listeners create their own stories on air) and MOVIExperience (improvising a movie) which culminated in the publication of his book “That Movie In Your Head.”  That book was the inspiration for Nancy Fletcher's non-profit organization Act Now, which adapted David's work by creating a movie making format for adolescent girls designed to enhance leadership and self-esteem.  His latest format is Life-Play, where people improvise over the phone.

David's work has influenced  Second City, the Groundlings, Upright Citizen's Brigade, i.O.,  Saturday Night Live, MadTV, and the work of film directors such as Christopher Guest, Paul Mazursky, Mike Nichols and Henry Jaglom. David has been presented with lifetime achievement awards by Second City, Canadian Improv Games and Chicago Improv Fest.

I have known David Shepherd for 43 years and have been directly involved or a consultant on every format he's created since 1972.  I co-produced and wrote a documentary about David, called "David Shepherd: A Lifetime of Improvisational Theatre." In the improv community, I'm known as his protege. I can say with confidence that I am an expert on David's career and life.

David, who is now 90 years old, has asked me to collect, characterize and prepare his archives for permanent placement in a publicly accessible collection.  I have completed an initial review of those archival materials, and put those materials into 10 boxes. Those boxes contain 60 years of David's improv formats.  The boxes include vintage pictures, journals, flyers, scripts, press releases, posters, awards, correspondence, video and audio tapes.  David's archives are under consideration for being added to Northwestern University Library's Special Collections, which houses the Viola Spolin Collection.

Unfortunately, his archives are in a shambles. Over the years, improv material has been misfiled and merged with family memorabilia. I have to separate family material from improv, while identifying little known formats and rearrange the memorabilia in a coherent order. This is a major undertaking, where I plan on spending seven to ten days at David's home to accomplish this task.  I live in Los Angeles. David resides in Belchertown, Mass.

This project will benefit everyone in the improv community and many in the broader U.S. theatre community. David Shepherd's work will be preserved for posterity. Quite simply, David Shepherd is a man who changed the course of American Theatre. We all deserve to have his archives carefully and comprehensively collected, sorted, cataloged and  made available to academics and other students of the history of American Theatre.

The $5,000 I am hoping to raise will cover the following expenses;

Airfare (Los Angeles to Massachusetts)
Car rental/gas
Hotel
Food
Scanning/shipping
Interns to assist with cataloging
My stipend (which covers work I have already accomplished since 2009)

story:
A Few Words about Without Words

What is it like to live without words?  Experts say if we don't learn a first language as children, we can't learn it at all. 

Without Words is an innovative new show from In/Visible Theatre.  An adaptation of Susan Schaller's book, A Man Without Words, Artistic Director Derek Davidson weaves dance, drama, sound and silence in this remarkable true story of how language divides us, connects us, but is ultimately much more than words. 

We are using a mix of hearing, hard of hearing and Deaf actors in the show. 

Without Words is part of An Appalachian Summer Festival in Boone, NC. We are also taking the show on the road for an evening in Valdese, NC and for an afternoon in Blountville, TN. 

Without Words is based on Shaller's memoir about encountering Ildefonso, a 27-year old Mexican Indian who was born deaf, never learned sign language, and lived on the fringes of human interaction. Susan, an American Sign Language interpreter, found him intelligent,observant, and isolated from the world around him, and despite the experts, she was determined to help him communicate.

You Have to Give to Receive. 

With a cast of 14, some of them coming from as far as Los Angeles, the production cost are large. But this is a story that needs to be told. Funds raised for this project will go towards: 

  • ...care and feeding of our actors and crew. The show has 14 professional cast members and a production team. 
  • ...ASL interpreters.  Since this is a show with Deaf, hard of hearing and hearing actors, we also using an ASL Master and a rotating group of professional ASL interpreters.  Interpreters are a crucial and necessary part of our process, and their pay is a very significant part of our budget. 
  • ...taking this show on the road to nearby communities with a significant Deaf populations.  We want to share this show with Deaf and hearing groups in our region, but need help with travel costs. 
  • ...all the many other costs associated with producing a show, such as building the set, props, and costumes and also really important things like insurance, ibuprofen, and band aids. 
Check out our cool perks to the right!

The Impact: 

In/Visible Theatre is committed to utilizing the power of theatre to ask unspoken questions, tell unheard stories, and give voice to invisible populations.  

In/Visible Theatre has produced several productions, including  Kill Will (our Shakespeare fight show, spring 2014), Groundwork (catch it again in United Solo Fest, NYC, fall 2015  ) and Bumbershoot, which was named one of the 20 best plays in FringeNYC 2012 by www.indietheatrenow.com.   

Risks & Challenges

In/Visible Theatre produces plays that are not only entertainment, but art. We ask hard questions and go outside of our own and society's comfort zones.

The kind of theatre we do involves risk, because it's new, unusual, and while it is accessible and entertaining to most, is also far from the mainstream.  Almost all of our work is original, and explores stories rarely investigated. This is why we need your support. Money is an expression of our values. If you value artistic risk-taking, the courage to ask difficult questions, the inquiry that leads to shining a light on the unseen aspects of our society, we invite you to join us in creating this important project. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope you can donate, as your monetary gifts are crucial to creating this important bi-cultural and bi-lingual production.  If you can't donate, please share our campaign with others.  Contact us to help volunteer to pass out postcards, distribute posters, or bring dinner or snacks for the cast.

story:
Movement Exchange provides dance education in orphanages and at-risk youth foundations, and uses movement as a tool for social change. We call this Dance Diplomacy.

                                                                                                                              

                     


   

At 25, and working in community development in Panama, Anna dreamed of a dancer's version of Doctors Without Borders. She asked, "How can dance education reach underserved populations, and how can trained dancers use their skill set to give back to the world?"

In three years, we have reached our dream of developing a sustainable dance education program. With a group of dedicated and passionate volunteers, we are changing lives through dance.  

 

                                   
                   
    


 

                        

     

                                                               


                                                                   

Our dance diplomats are U.S. dancers who teach dance in underserved populations in Panama, the U.S., and soon to be India with your support. Dance diplomats teach in orphanages, at-risk youth foundations, and universities. We are nurturing a community of service-minded dancers.


   

                                                                

                                                                    

                             


                                        

                  

                    

Our community of dance diplomats has grown in the United States. Our alumni have included professional dancers, educators, health professionals, and most actively, university students. Meet a few of our Move-Ex Chapters!

                                                         

                        

                                         


                                          


                                  



                

           

                   


                                                                 

      

                                                                

                          

We have developed relationships with inspiring organizations that are already empowering youth in their communities. BUT—this is just the beginning!

    

Active since 1960, SEC educates and rehabilitates children and adults with physical disabilities from underserved populations. They provide educational, medical, and vocational services to 700 students every year.

Shanawaz was seven years old and a polio victim when he arrived at SEC. 20 years later, despite being wheel-chair bound, he became the assistant teacher to acclaimed Bollywood dancer, Shiamakdavar. Inspired by the power of dance, he began teaching the many children at SEC Day School to dance and move beyond their conditions.

Shanawaz and the SEC Day School recently presented a dance piece and won 1st Prize from The Create Foundation - Trophy for Artistic Excellence.

                                                 


Ek Prayaas—“an effort” in Hindi— supports, educates, and develops the lives of underprivileged children in West Bengal. Housing 130 children between the ages of four and fourteen, Ek Prayaas offers both academic and vocational training, with a mission to advance “literacy into learning.”

Movement Exchange will provide dance education to Ek Prayaas in alliance with the local Kolkata dance school, DNA Danceworks. We believe the best way to immerse our sustainable model into new communities is by first developing partnerships with local established dance leaders.

      

 
These are two partnerships that Movement Exchange has cultivated in India thus far. With YOUR support, we will continue to build the formative connections necessary to unite communities and empower youth through the universal language of dance.

                                                              

Movement Exchange is committed to understanding, with empathy and integrity, the communities in which we serve. Your donation will contribute to the research required to provide sensitive and customized dance education that is relevant to the physical, developmental, and emotional needs of our participants. 

                                                              

In the same way we have established our Panama program, Movement Exchange maintains sustainable impact as a number one priority. Not only will we bring dance diplomats to new communities in India for outreach and exchange, but we will ensure sustainable dance education for at-risk youth in two main ways:

                                          

Igniting local interactions— empowering         Donating to our partners, and
relationships between local Indian dancers      employing local Indian dancers
and at-risk youth foundations by creating        to give back to their own
dance education programs that did not           communites.
previously exist.


      

              

   

                            

                          

           

   

    

         All donations are tax-deductible, and our perks are pretty awesome.

story:
Alicia's Cabaret Show! 

Hello!

I am producing and hosting my first cabaret show in New York City! 

As a lifelong lover of cabaret, vaudeville, and musical theater, this adventure is a dream come true! After producing theater and cabaret shows growing up, I am venturing into new waters by launching my own show on a New York stage. 

Cabaret theater is special because it offers the kind of entertainment our culture doesn't often see: a live, intimate, collective experience. Cabaret performers are also wildly diverse in their talents and aesthetics--something unique in today's mainstream entertainment. Cabaret is home to all kinds of people and source material: from popular tunes to bawdy humor to touching torch songs, the cabaret is always welcoming! 

Our first show is particularly important because we want to produce more shows. The video and audio of this show will be used to book and promote future cabaret shows (in increasingly larger venues!). Your contribution will help create a place for the many talented cabaret performers of New York to showcase their talents and entertain audiences from around the world! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $650:
  • Musicians - $250
  • Performers (4) - $200
  • Sheet Music - $60
  • Video Recording - $90
  • Audio Recording - $50
  • As a contributor of $10 or more, you will receive program credit as a Producer of a New York City show PLUS a fancy certificate declaring your Producer status!
  • Contributors of $20 or more will also receive gorgeous professional prints from the show!
  • Contributors of $50 or more will receive gorgeous professional prints autographed by the cast PLUS an audio recording!
  • Contributors of $100 or more can special request any song which I will perform and post on social media dedicated just to you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, please share this link with anyone you think would be interested and supportive! Please share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, and any other social media tools you use!

story:
o f  b o n e s | | h o l l y e  b y n u m   is a modern dance company based in Brooklyn, NY. o f  b o n e s  seeks to create a unique modern dance experience through a minimal, stripped down choreographic approach in order to challenge audiences and performers to be present, conscious, and aware. Since it's launch on October 15, 2013,  o f  b o n e s || h o l l y e  b y n u m  has produced an evening length production, created multiple works, and directed two dance shorts in collaboration with director, Christopher Vitiello.

In October 2014, we will be producing our second annual choreographic concert, “mouthfull.” at the Center for Performance Research in Brooklyn, NY.  o f b o n e s | | h o l l y e b y n u m  seeks to provide up and coming choreographers with an opportunity to cultivate their developing artistic voices by feasible financial means.  We aim to bring together an array of modern, contemporary dancers and choreographers from across New York City to create an evening of high-quality performances. 

Last year marked our first production of “mouthfull.” and the premiere of  o f  b o n e s | | h o l l y e  b y n u m. At our first attempt at self-producing, we were able to sell out the show.  We received tremendous positive feedback from our audiences and selected choreographers. This year we received a high quantity of aspiring applicants, eager to present their work.  We hope to continue our success by making “mouthfull.” an annual opportunity as we build and expand our network of dancers and collaborators.
There are many inherent financial obstacles that self-producers face. The struggle to find funding in the current economy for emerging artists can be disheartening. Without proper funding, planning, and organization, a production is significantly limited and faces a small chance at success. To develop an artistic voice requires ample time for experimentation, investigation, and most importantly, opportunity for presentation and audience feedback. By committing to "mouthfull." as an annual project, we hope to help as many choreographers as possible in getting their work out of preliminary stages and onto the ever-competitive New York City dance scene. We aim to gain public support and popularity through thoroughly researched planning, fundraising, and networking.  With our previous success, we are confident that "mouthfull." will continue to evolve into a successful choreographic platform and a coveted dance performance for the community.

We have set a goal to raise $1500 by October 15. Every penny of your donation will contribute to funding for production elements necessary to create an evening length performance, including the venue, costumes, marketing costs, and compensation for the hard-working dancers.  

Any contribution, no matter how small, will help!

Unable to make a donation? Please consider helping us to spread the word by sharing our campaign video, posting about us on social media, following our Instagram and Facebook pages, and/or shouting it out your window at any given time. Any contribution, no matter how small, means the world to us. Thank you.

In October 2014, we will be producing our second annual choreographic concert, “mouthfull.” at the Center for Performance Research in Brooklyn, NY.  o f b o n e s | | h o l l y e b y n u m  seeks to provide up and coming choreographers with an opportunity to cultivate their developing artistic voices by feasible financial means.  We aim to bring together an array of modern, contemporary dancers and choreographers from across New York City to create an evening of high-quality performances. 
Last year marked our first production of “mouthfull.” and the premiere of  o f  b o n e s | | h o l l y e  b y n u m. At our first attempt at self-producing, we were able to sell out the show.  We received tremendous positive feedback from our audiences and selected choreographers. This year we received a high quantity of aspiring applicants, eager to present their work.  We hope to continue our success by making “mouthfull.” an annual opportunity as we build and expand our network of dancers and collaborators.There are many inherent financial obstacles that self-producers face. The struggle to find funding in the current economy for emerging artists can be disheartening. Without proper funding, planning, and organization, a production is significantly limited and faces a small chance at success. To develop an artistic voice requires ample time for experimentation, investigation, and most importantly, opportunity for presentation and audience feedback. By committing to "mouthfull." as an annual project, we hope to help as many choreographers as possible in getting their work out of preliminary stages and onto the ever-competitive New York City dance scene. We aim to gain public support and popularity through thoroughly researched planning, fundraising, and networking.  With our previous success, we are confident that "mouthfull." will continue to evolve into a successful choreographic platform and a coveted dance performance for the community.
We have set a goal to raise $1500 by October 15. Every penny of your donation will contribute to funding for production elements necessary to create an evening length performance, including the venue, costumes, marketing costs, and compensation for the hard-working dancers.  
Any contribution, no matter how small, will help!
Unable to make a donation? Please consider helping us to spread the word by sharing our campaign video, posting about us on social media, following our Instagram and Facebook pages, and/or shouting it out your window at any given time. Any contribution, no matter how small, means the world to us. Thank you.

story:
Hey Kids, Let's Put on a Play!

We’re rewriting the script, and we’ve booked a theatre.  Now comes the fundraising!

My name is Bob Murphy.  I’m a New York-based playwright and composer.  I wrote “Love, Sex and Death in the Amazon” in response to an intense period of my life, in an effort to reach some kind of – closure?  reconciliation?  - and also, to explore the ways that Brazil and its people have influenced me.  The story in a nutshell:

An over-compensating American travels to the Amazon with a high-maintenance Brazilian mother, and many issues arise:  how do you navigate through uncharted territory without a guide?  How do you resolve hostilities that refuse to resolve?  And how do you let go of a loved one who won’t leave? 

Help Us Pay the Rent!

This will be the first of two projected fundraising campaigns.  We're hoping in this campaign to raise the $12,000 needed for rental of the theatre for the run of the play in October.

Donations to the current campaign are unfortunately not tax-deductible.  We are currently applying for fiscal sponsorship with a major nonprofit organization; we hope to run the second fundraising campaign through this organization, and donations to that campaign will be tax-deductible.  (If you are interested in donating to the tax-deductible campaign in February, please let me know.)

Here's the rental costs: 
  • Paradise Factory rental, four weeks @ $3,000/wk:   $12,000
(we will be renting the space one week for technical rehearsals, then performing a three-week run.)

Production Details & Costs

Although we're on a shoestring budget, shoestrings cost a bit more in NYC.  Whatever amount you can donate, you will be making a vital contribution towards making our production a reality!

The current production budget breaks down as follows:

  • Theatre and rehearsal space rental - $12,000
  • Rehearsal space rental:  $2,500
  • Actors, director, and designer fees - $12,000
  • Production personnel - $3,000
  • Production materials/rentals - $4,500
  • Marketing/PR - $4,500
  • Additional expenses - $1,400
  • Current budget total - $39,900
We're producing this play on an Actor's Equity Showcase Code contract.  An Equity Showcase production means the budget can be any size - literally, two actors, some rehearsal cubes and a passion.  Your generous contribution will help us to create a world where the play can more fully thrive.

(Please note: campaign perks have been edited to include comp tickets for the show.  Indiegogo wouldn't allow me to edit the $100 perk, but for a $100 donation you'll also receive two comp tickets for the run of the show.)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the resources to contribute, perhaps you can help us by spreading the word to friends, by email, Facebook or word-of-mouth?

Thank you for your time and generosity.

Bob Murphy

story:
Time for Class

We are a group of local, young artists all of whom have high school/college level theatre experience. To continue our craft, we are looking to bring performance to our town during the summer months. 

Don't forget your supplies

To achieve our goal, we need to start with materials. Your contributions will help us pay for: 

  • Costuming
  • Printing
  • Renting Space
  • Set Design
  • Rights to Perform
  • And all the little things we'll need in between

    Today's lesson

    Along with bringing arts into a small community, we want to create a performance that will remind the audience of the shared experiences we face during our high school years.

story:
a story of hope. a story of love. a story of freedom.

Inspired by The White Umbrella by Mary Frances Bowley (founder of Wellspring Living), Bluebird's next project artfully portrays the journey from bondage to redemption. Choreographed by Rebekah Diaddigo to original music by Todd Locke with cinematography by Caleb Diaddigo, this collaboration traces our heart's story from death to life.


the project

A stage production of White Umbrella premiered at the anti-trafficking fundraiser, Dance Upon Injustice. But we believe this was just the beginning. In creating this trilogy we want to share the White Umbrella story with a wider audience. 

The goal of this mutimedia project is threefold:

-to tell the White Umbrella story cinematically through dance

-to raise awareness about the issue of sex-trafficking

-to support the work of Wellspring Living*

Bluebird: uncaged is a collective of artists dedicated to using art for the greater good, specifically to bringing hope and dignity through dance. We do this through workshops, uncaged adventures, live performances and multimedia.

*anything over our goal will be donated to Wellspring Living


art for the greater good

Dance can travel places where words fall short. Through previous projects such as Breaking Free and Beautiful Things we’ve seen the impact that relevant and redemptive art can have on the community. This project is no different.  White Umbrella is about more than just making a video or telling a story cinematically through dance. Your contribution not only helps raise awareness about the realities of sex-trafficking but also equips Wellspring Living to restore lives of trafficking survivors.

Use of the finished product as well as any contributions over our goal of $7500 will be donated to Wellspring Living. Wellspring’s mission is to confront the issue of childhood abuse and exploitation through awareness, training, and treatment programs for women and girls. 




practically speaking

Our goal is $7500. This guarantees we will be able to produce the most excellent production we are capable of. Expenses include compensation for dancers and crew, equipment rental, costuming, catering during filming, and postproduction work. 

If we don’t meet our goal, all donations will be put towards this project, the process will just be a little slower. 

We’ve got some fun perks planned as well. From items provided by Bluebird: merch to behind the scenes peeks at the process to invitations to our release party, we want YOU to be a part of bringing hope and dignity through dance.


thank you!

We are incredibly grateful for each and every contribution to this project. Thank you for being on this journey with us and helping to tell the White Umbrella story.

PS--We’d be thrilled if you could show us a little social media love. It's easy with the share tools!

story:
Our Story

We are Mercury Opera, a professional, independent opera company based in Edmonton, Canada and dedicated to producing extraordinary opera productions that will attract a wide audience to what is most often seen as a rarefied, stuffy art form.  We present first rate opera (that "everyone will like" says Mike Ross of the SUN and) in unusual spaces.  Mercury Opera's origins are in NYC (profiled on ABC NEWS' Life time Live)but in 2008 debuted in Edmonton to resounding success among critics and audiences alike.

This August 23 -27th, 2011 for 5 performances,we return to our Edmonton roots,(on the heels of of Pagliacci staged inside the famed Circus and Sideshow in Coney Island)and the heart of Little Italy, to present Puccini's timeless classic Madame Butterfly, a tearjerker about Cho cho san the teenaged geisha with a heart of gold, and Lieutenant Pinkerton, the US Naval Officer who breaks it. In one night Mercury Opera will transport you to the romantic,the beautiful, the exotic and ultimately the tragic, in an exquisite rendition of Puccini's tale spun with a new twist and fresh air setting in post World War 2 Japan, during the US occupation.


The Impact

We are endeavoring to bring arts and culture to McCauley's Giovanni Caboto Park, an inner city neighbourhood resplendent with charms, which has been marked for revitalization within the city of Edmonton. We want to create a yearly opera festival that will be enjoyed during the summer in Edmonton, as an adjunct to the already existing festival base.  


What We Need & What You Get

The $2,000 we're campaigning for, will be applied directly to production costs.  Mercury Opera has no physical operating overhead yet; the Artistic Producers/Staff aren't paid for their year-round administrative and production work, and the company is run out of a home office.  Though we pay our artists reduced fees,we still have to import several of them internationally, provide their travel expenses and housing,and in addition we also book a live professional orchestra.  The costs of marketing and printing even with sponsorships are high.  We also need to raise our tent.  As our performance venue is a tent, it requires infra structure, a power generator,porta potties, and security (one week).  We anticipate a sell out after the first two performances, and are projecting a 60% capacity audience (conservative based on our past sell out crowds) which could cover most our production costs, with the exception of all the sweat equity and donated services thusfar. The fact is, we still need cold hard cash to pay for our venue,artists' travel, printing, advertising, equipment and percussion rentals up front.


What you Get

1.  The show.  This is the greatest perk we can offer-association and the feel good aspect of making a contribution to something beautiful and ground breaking in a community that needs it.  We are building from the ground up.  You will be mentioned in our production program and named on our website as a supporter for one year from the closing date of the production no matter what level of contribution.

2.  Our gratitude and your satisfaction.  Canada is learning that if its artistic life is to stay vibrant, we must develop a stronger culture of philanthropy and private investment.  

3.  If you contribute over $1000 in cash/goods and or services; we'll put you and your plus-one on our VIP guest list for the opening night performance.  Reception, media, excitement ... and the show.  It'll be an evening of excitment, drama, a memorable experience, simply put,a great time. 


Other Ways You Can Help

1.  Share share share!  Spread the word about the show, the company, and the campaign to people you think might be interested.  "Like" our Facebook page.  Visit our website and send the link to all your friends.  

2.  Contribute anything!  It ALL helps.  A toonie = cream for coffee in the rehearsal hall.  $5 = photocopying one part $10 = kung fu shoes for one performer for one week of the run. $15 a parasol for a geisha costume-we need 5 of them.  $20 = one hour of a theatre technician's labour.  Sponsor a cast dinner ie. Pizza 73, beer excluded (or included ;  )). Tim Horton's donuts for the orchestra 18 players-who are reducing their per service rate.  There's no such thing as too small.

3.  See the show, and tell your friends.  Send them in droves!

story:
Short Summary

We are graduate students at the Savannah College of Art and Design working towards our Masters of Fine Arts in Performing Arts.  For our MFA thesis project, we are producing the musical comedy I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change.  In a series of vignettes this show addresses "everything you have ever secretly thought about dating, romance, marriage, lovers, husbands, wives and in-laws, but were afraid to admit."

We open on January 10th in SCAD's Mondanaro Theatre!  We hope to see you all there!


What We Need & What You Get

We've assembled our cast and crew and are excited to start rehearsals, but we still need help funding our project.  Your contributions will help us pay for:

  • The licensing rights
  • Hiring musicians
  • Printing posters and programs
  • Building the set
We appreciate all donations, big or small! Even $1 gets us one step closer to our goal!

Rewards:

  • Pledge $20 or more and get a seat reserved for you at the theatre!
  • Pledge $50 or more and receive a free dvd of the performance!

The Impact

We chose this particular project because it would challenge us as artists.  With each actor playing upwards of 10 different roles and a minimalist design aesthetic we hope to differentiate our characters using nothing but our physicality and vocal technique.  It is an exciting challenge for any actor.  Moreover, it makes for an entertaining evening of theatre!


Risks & Challenges

We have a limited amount of time to produce our show.  But we are dedicated and enthusiastic and we are sure that it can all be accomplished in the time allotted.  Most of the major tasks have already been addressed.  We have assembled a fantastic cast, director, and stage manager.  We have secured a theatre, a performance date, and the licensing rights.  And we're excited to begin rehearsals!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute at this time, help us get the word out! Share this page with your friends and of course come see the show!

story:
49th Parallel Dance Company

Choreographers Ariana Champlin and Carolyn Schmidt established 49th Parallel Dance Company in New York City in August 2010. In November 2010, the company expanded to run its operations out of both New York City and Vancouver, British Columbia. Being situated in the heart of two creative hubs has allowed the company to grow and make connections to dance communities across North America.  


This fall the company will make it's way to Maine with their evening length piece Watering Hole! With shows at two beautiful historical theaters we are beyond excited for our first Maine tour and we need your help to get us there!!! 


Your contribution will help ten dancers travel from New York City to Portland Maine, (that's seven hours on buses, trains and cars all the way there!) it will also help towards hours in the studio for rehearsals, food, (yes, contrary to popular belief  dancers do eat!) and paying these amazing artists for their hard work and electric performance on stage! Here's the best part, we're giving a portion of the proceeds to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society!!! This is a foundation that is very close to my heart and I will be SO happy to contribute through 49th Parallel Dance Company as I join family and friends to walk in the Light the Night walk in Maine just a week after our shows.  

Help Us to Get There:

We're asking for you to help us raise $800 to send us on our Maine tour and back again. (We  really don't want to have to ride a moose back to NYC) Any amount that you can give is greatly appreciated be it anywhere from $5 to $500! Let us show you how you will be helping us...

  • 14 hours of transportation, each dancer's round trip travel will cost $80 (that's $800 right there folks) 
  • 25 hours in the studio for rehearsals 
  • Two 50 minute shows...the funds will help to pay the dancers for their hard work and energetic performances. 
  • Last but not least, a portion of the proceeds will go to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society! 

More About the Company:

The mission of 49th Parallel Dance Company is to foster connections between distanced dance communities and to explore movement innovation through the blending of multiple dance genres. Operating out of New York City and Vancouver, Canada, company directors Ariana Champlin and Carolyn Schmidt are committed to creating opportunities for professional and pre-professional dance artists in both locales through creative processes, productions and educational initiatives. 


One of our goals is to present dance that is accessible and enjoyable to all audiences, in the past we have performed to audiences ranging in age from fifteen to eighty five, to artists and non-artists alike and we have enjoyed a plethora of outlooks on our work from each performance, so far each one positive. 


We work in conjunction with other emerging artists to support the dance community’s arriving professional artists in all disciplines, as well as to push our own boundaries within our work. We have a history of collaborating with emerging bands, composers, costume designers, videographers and we often rent studio space from local and emerging dance studios. 49th Parallel dancers are diverse geographically, ethnically and come from an array of dance training backgrounds. Currently our dancers come from five U.S. States, four Canadian Provinces and five different countries including, India, Singapore and Mexico. Although our company work falls under the umbrella of contemporary dance, we are cultivating the use of other techniques and dance forms within our artistic practices. 


If you're curious to know more about the company, take a look at our website: www.49thparalleldanceco.com and our Facebook page, 49th Parallel Dance Company! 

    “To be creative means to be in love with life. You can be creative only if you love life enough that you want to enhance its beauty, you want to bring a little more music to it, a little more poetry to it, a little more dance to it.” 

Thank You:

Every single dollar will help us immensely and we greatly appreciate your contribution! 

Other ways you can help us? Spread the word and share this page to everyone you know! We have until the end of September to reach our goal and hopefully surpass it! 

49th Parallel Dance thanks you from the soles of our feet for keeping us in the studio and on the stage!!! 

We thank you even more for giving towards the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society!!!!!

Sincerely, 

-Ariana Champlin

More About the Company:
The mission of 49th Parallel Dance Company is to foster connections between distanced dance communities and to explore movement innovation through the blending of multiple dance genres. Operating out of New York City and Vancouver, Canada, company directors Ariana Champlin and Carolyn Schmidt are committed to creating opportunities for professional and pre-professional dance artists in both locales through creative processes, productions and educational initiatives. 


One of our goals is to present dance that is accessible and enjoyable to all audiences, in the past we have performed to audiences ranging in age from fifteen to eighty five, to artists and non-artists alike and we have enjoyed a plethora of outlooks on our work from each performance, so far each one positive. 

We work in conjunction with other emerging artists to support the dance community’s arriving professional artists in all disciplines, as well as to push our own boundaries within our work. We have a history of collaborating with emerging bands, composers, costume designers, videographers and we often rent studio space from local and emerging dance studios. 49th Parallel dancers are diverse geographically, ethnically and come from an array of dance training backgrounds. Currently our dancers come from five U.S. States, four Canadian Provinces and five different countries including, India, Singapore and Mexico. Although our company work falls under the umbrella of contemporary dance, we are cultivating the use of other techniques and dance forms within our artistic practices. 

If you're curious to know more about the company, take a look at our website: www.49thparalleldanceco.com and our Facebook page, 49th Parallel Dance Company! 


“To be creative means to be in love with life. You can be creative only if you love life enough that you want to enhance its beauty, you want to bring a little more music to it, a little more poetry to it, a little more dance to it.”
